editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO THE GENTRIE OF ENGLAND.
div.p: WOrthie Gentlemen (omitting all elaborated Eloquence, which oftentimes is vÅ¿ed as a varniÅ¿h, to couer vnprofitable labours; As cunning GoldÅ¿mithes doe enrich their baÅ¿eÅ¿t Siluer, when they Gilt it with their pureÅ¿t Gold) J purpoÅ¿e to render to you an accompt of two reaÅ¿ons, which induced me to take this paine, and to publiÅ¿h this worke.

1. Jt is common among PhiÅ¿itions; That though profound Learning, and frequent Experience, haue furniÅ¿hed them with abundant skill, in their Honourable profeÅ¿sion: yet they doe Å¿till
Å¿triue to make their knowledge more perfect, in the diÅ¿couerie of the imperfections of other mens bodies, then of their owne: Jn like Å¿ort it is the common custome of our times; that many hopefull Gentlemen (whom Nature and Arts haue beautified, with the rich treaÅ¿ures of their bountie) do endeauour to be more exact and refined, in knowing the Religion, Lawes, Gouernment, Maners, Strength, and Sites of forraine Countries, then of that Kingdome wherein themÅ¿elues were borne.

But as that man is wiÅ¿e in vaine, who is not wiÅ¿e vnto himÅ¿elfe; So it is a Å¿imple grace (nay to Å¿peake plainly, it is a foule diÅ¿grace) to a Gentleman (eÅ¿pecially to Å¿uch a one, as hath, or doth intend to Å¿pend much time abroad to know the faÅ¿hions of forraine Nations) to be ignorant in the State of his owne Countrie at home. The HiÅ¿torie of which, affordeth as much varietie and profitable inÅ¿truction, to captiuate the Readers delight in the peruÅ¿all, as the faireÅ¿t Pictures doe contentment, when with their artificiall beauties, they doe allure mens eyes to looke and to gaze vpon them.

To this end therefore, that hencefoorth Å¿uch worthy Gentlemen as are purpoÅ¿ed, in long traueling, to enlarge their experience, by the view of
foraine Countries, may first be furniÅ¿hed with a conuenient knowledge of their owne; J vndertooke this labour, and doe preÅ¿ent it vnto you, with this my firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on which induced me thereunto.

2. The Å¿econd reaÅ¿on of my Å¿o doing, Å¿pringeth out of mine owne conceit; which (as J coniecture) deceiues me not. For, in regard that the HiÅ¿tories of this Kingdome, are frequently interrupted, yea blemiÅ¿hed, by too too many interuening Occurrences, and by a multitude of extrauagant ObÅ¿eruations (which doe much differ from the true Method, and Nature, of a well digeÅ¿ted and compoÅ¿ed Chronicle; and thereby doe extend it into a needleÅ¿Å¿e and an vnprofitable length) J am reÅ¿olued that the Readers capacitie (to obÅ¿erue and to remember) is much weakned thereby: And that many yong Gentlemen, who doe egerly Å¿triue to attaine to much knowledge in a Å¿hort time, doe rather bend their Studies and their courÅ¿es, to reade ouer the more narrowly contracted HiÅ¿tories of other Countries, then the voluminous DiÅ¿courÅ¿es of their owne.

Wherefore to inlighten their knowledge much, by reading this little; J haue thruÅ¿t forth into the World this Å¿hort HiÅ¿torie, of the Raignes, Deeds, and Actions, of twentie of our EngliÅ¿h Kings; which J will neither praiÅ¿e, least J
wrong it by mine owne commendation; nor diÅ¿praiÅ¿e, leaÅ¿t you (beleeuing mee on my word) Å¿hould thinke your time ill Å¿pent, to read what I haue written.

J know that Å¿uch as are worthily deÅ¿cended, or who by learning are made worthy, will not only winke at Å¿ome imperfections, becauÅ¿e Å¿ome knowledge is to be gained by the reÅ¿t: but will alÅ¿o take in good part the preÅ¿entment of a Å¿mall gift; if it be deliuered with a friendly hand. To Å¿uch only, and to none other (which are you) doe J dedicate theÅ¿e my labors: Being confidently aÅ¿Å¿ured, that they cannot want their expected reward, which is nothing, but your kinde acceptance, and gracefull loue.

closer.dateline: Fare you well, from my houÅ¿e in Exeter the twentieth of Ianuarie. 1615.

div.head: TO MY MOST DEARE Father WILLIAM MARTYN EÅ¿quire.

lg.l: THough my vnpractis'd MuÅ¿e might well conceale
Her Å¿elfe from th'eye-reach of a publique view;
Yet my devoted heart, Å¿tir'd on with zeale,
And dutie (which are owing both to you)

I will not Å¿peake of your vnwearied paine

TheÅ¿e ruder lines, your labors little neede,

div.head: To my moÅ¿t loued and deareÅ¿t Father WILLIAM MARTYN ESQVIRE.
div.l: I Could (deere Sir) haue Å¿poke, with farre more eaÅ¿e,
In copious ProÅ¿e, than in Å¿trict VerÅ¿e, your praiÅ¿e;
But that I knew, your fame would farre out-goe
All foote-leÅ¿Å¿e ProÅ¿e; my VerÅ¿e (not full Å¿o Å¿low
Hauing the helpe of feete) Å¿erues thus farre forth,

div.head: To my most dearly loued Father WILLIAM MARTYN EÅ¿quire.
div.l: WHil'Å¿t others Å¿end you Lines trickt out with Art,
My Infant yeares Å¿hall onely Å¿end mine heart:
Looke for no greater gift, from Å¿o Å¿mall Å¿tore;

l.hi: He that giues all he has, can giue no more.

div.head: TO MY DEARLY HONORD FATHER-IN-Law WILLIAM MARTYN EÅ¿quire.

lg.l: A Publique good, muÅ¿t quell your priuate feare.
The profit of a Writers induÅ¿trie,
Should be imparted to a generall Eare;
For good is better'd by communitie.
Nor may detraction, or the injurie
Of Å¿ome mens cenÅ¿ures, daÅ¿h what he doth write:
If, but what only pleaÅ¿eth all mens Å¿ight,
No worke Å¿hould come to light, no worke Å¿hould come to light.
What though you gather'd haue the Å¿euerall flowr's
Of other Bookes, into this HiÅ¿torie?
DiÅ¿till'd to Spirit by you, they're wholly yours:
So honie, Å¿uckt from the varietie
Of flowr's, is yet the honie of the Bee.
And though, in theÅ¿e dayes, Miracles are fled,
Yet this Å¿hall of your Chronicle be read,

l.hi: It brings back Time that's paÅ¿t, and giues life to the Dead.
