div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING WILLIAM THE CONQÆ²EROR.
div.p:
AFTER the death of King Edward (who was the Å¿onne of Egeldredus, and of Goditha his wife) Harold her brother, and Å¿econd Å¿onne to the Earle Godwin, vÅ¿urped this kingdom, and cauÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe to be crowned King, the Crowne being formerly giuen by King Edward vnto William the Å¿euenth Duke of the Normans, and baÅ¿e Å¿onne to Robert their Å¿ixt Duke. To whoÅ¿e vÅ¿e and behoofe, Harold had formerly Å¿worne to keepe the Å¿ame. Whereof, when Duke William was certainely enformed, Hee charged him (by his Letters, and by MeÅ¿Å¿engers) with his promiÅ¿e, confirmed by his Oath; and required him (in friendly Å¿ort, and without blowes) to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e him of his Crowne. But proud Ambition (arming him with a ReÅ¿olution to remaine a King in deÅ¿pight of threats, or Fortune) made him, rather to quoine diÅ¿honorable excuÅ¿es, then to giue Å¿atisfaction as hee had Å¿worne: And for anÅ¿were, to returne, That promiÅ¿es, and vowes raÅ¿hly made, and by compulÅ¿ion (as his was) eÅ¿pecially for a Kingdome, wherevnto the State had giuen no free conÅ¿ent, were not (at all) to bee regarded. And therefore (Å¿eeing the Dukes Rule and Dominions were as ample,
and as large elÅ¿ewhere, as Nature and Art had enabled him to manage, and to command) he wiÅ¿hed him to bee contented with his owne, and not aduenture to claÅ¿pe more within his hand, then he was well able to hold faÅ¿t, Nor to couet that which hee Å¿hould not enioy.

As this anÅ¿were bred DiÅ¿content: So rage began to reÅ¿olue on Armes. For the Duke (aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by his Martiall friends) leuied a Å¿trong Armie; and furniÅ¿hed it with all abiliments and neceÅ¿Å¿aries for the Warre: with which (through the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Å¿ome natiue Nobles, who adhered to his part) hee Å¿afely landed in SuÅ¿Å¿ex: where (hauing prouidently Å¿heltred himÅ¿elfe, againÅ¿t all Å¿uddaine Å¿tormes) hee challenged Harold to a Å¿ingle Combat; thereby to decide the Å¿trife, without much bloud. But Harold entertained not the Challenge; but Å¿ent him word, That to gaine, or keepe a Kingdome, it required more blowes then two could giue.14. October. 1066. So that (within fewe dayes after) a fierce and cruell Battaile (of the continuance of one whole day) without intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, or breathing, was fought betwixt them. But in the Euening, HAROLD, being deadly wounded with an Arrow, left both his Kingdome and his life: And Duke William (almoÅ¿t with equall loÅ¿Å¿e of his men) became Victor in the field.

The Saxons Raigne endedAnd thus ended the Saxons Raigne; which (from the firÅ¿t yeare of Hengistus, in the yeare of our Lord God foure hundred Å¿euentie and fiue, vntill the time of this ConqueÅ¿t in the yeare of our Lord God one thouÅ¿and Å¿ixtie and Å¿ixe) had continued: (Sauing that now and then, it was interrupted by the Danes) the Å¿pace of fiue hundred foureÅ¿core and eleuen yeares. The Duke (hauing thus Å¿laine Harold, and gained his Kingdome) began to raigne as King: And (on ChriÅ¿tmas day then next following) hee was crowned by Aldredus ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke, by the enforced conÅ¿ents of the EngliÅ¿h Nobles: Who (with an outward applauÅ¿e, but with an inward griefe and Å¿orrow) Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elues to be his Å¿ubiects; the KentiÅ¿h men excepted. By whom (is hee trauailed to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe of the Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle of Douer) he was preuented in his iourney, and compaÅ¿Å¿ed round about by valiant men of War, who (carying greene boughs in their hands, and reÅ¿embling a moouing Wood) enuironed the King, and all his followers, ere they were aware therof; And proteÅ¿ted manfully to die, rather then they would (by Å¿eruile baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e) be depriued of thoÅ¿e ancient Lawes and CuÅ¿tomes, whereby their Countrie was then ruled. The King (perceiuing his owne danger,
and their reÅ¿olution) hearkned to their demaunds; and not onely granted their requeÅ¿ts, but (for their bold and valorous attempt) hee honoured them with this preheminence; That euer afterwards, the KentiÅ¿h inhabitants Å¿hould make the Vantgard of the Field.

This gained hee that Countrie,The Conquerors Policies. and became Å¿ole Lord and Soueraigne of each whole Kingdome: and ruled it as a Conqueror, with more Policie than by profitable Lawes; and with more Å¿eueritie than did become the Gracious diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of a fauourable King.

For firÅ¿t of all (becauÅ¿e he preÅ¿umed, that Å¿uch as were conquered, did rather feare than loue, and would no longer obey, than the yoake lay heauie ouer their neckes) by receiuing HoÅ¿tages of the beÅ¿t and deareÅ¿t eÅ¿teeme, hee Å¿ecured the fidelities of Å¿uch as were either honourable, or potent, and Å¿ent them into Normandie, becauÅ¿e Å¿uddaine force and Å¿trength Å¿hould not depriue him of Å¿o Å¿ure a meane of his Å¿afetie.

Then (to depriue the EngliÅ¿h of all commaund, and to make them feeble, and his Normans Å¿trong) he Å¿eized their chiefeÅ¿t Offices, both of Honour, and of Profit, into his owne hands, and conferred them vpon Å¿trangers: Whereat the EngliÅ¿h grieued much, but found no remedie: for WeakeneÅ¿Å¿e was enforced to yeeld to Power, and vÅ¿urping Policie tyrannized ouer the OppreÅ¿Å¿ed, and bereaued them of their Right.

And (becauÅ¿e in thoÅ¿e daies the Clergie was had in great reuerence among the people; in regard, that their authoritie was not confined within the bounds of their Spirituall IuriÅ¿dictions) hee reÅ¿olued to clip their wings, becauÅ¿e they Å¿hould no longer Å¿oare Å¿o high; and did ordaine, That from thenceforth they Å¿hould not commaund with anie Temporall Authoritie whatÅ¿oeuer.

He was not ignorant, that the hope of Libertie did oftentimes incite Å¿uch as vnwillingly were made Å¿eruile, to watch for oportunitie to procure their Freedome: and therefore (to preuent Å¿uch dangers as might otherwiÅ¿e enÅ¿ue) he vtterly diÅ¿armed and diÅ¿weaponed all the Natiues of the Land, turning their Hopes into DeÅ¿paire; and preuenting their Expectations for ReleaÅ¿ement, with the preÅ¿ent Extremitie of their Bondage. Thus weakened he Å¿uch as were truly valiant, and thus made he them to Å¿uffer much who (if they had beene at libertie) would haue beene able to repell great force.

And (becauÅ¿e the concourÅ¿e of much people might giue them Å¿ome occaÅ¿ion, both to conferre of the eÅ¿tate which they were in,
and alÅ¿o to conÅ¿ult of the meanes of their deliuerance from their Thraldome) he debarred the EngliÅ¿h from frequent and common meetings, eÅ¿pecially in the night: which to preuent, he cauÅ¿ed a Bell in euerie Village, Towne, and Citie, to be rong at eight of the clocke in the euening; vpon the Å¿ound whereof, all EngliÅ¿h men were enjoyned to couer their fire, and to keepe themÅ¿elues within their dores. And this ceremonie was, and is yet called, Couer le fiew, or the raking vp of the Fire.

To diminiÅ¿h the Nobilitie, he vÅ¿ed to tranÅ¿port them for his Warres beyond the Seas: and if they returned backe againe, then might they well perceiue, that he rather meant their deÅ¿truction, than regarded their Å¿eruice: for no reward was giuen to them, though they were valiant, nor anie Å¿hew at all was made, that their forwardneÅ¿Å¿e was accepted by the King.

And thus dealt he likewiÅ¿e with the vulgar Å¿ort; by whoÅ¿e manhood he fought his Å¿harpeÅ¿t battailes in Normandie and in France: thereby leÅ¿Å¿ening their numbers, and making his owne power more eminent among Å¿uch, as he enforced to lament their owne misfortunes, and in vaine to meditate vpon their preÅ¿ent woe.

He alÅ¿o erected Å¿trong Forts and CaÅ¿tles in Å¿undrie places of this Realme, which were commaunded by his followers; whoÅ¿e bitterneÅ¿Å¿e was Å¿uch againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h Nation, as that they dared not to make Å¿hew, that they repined at any thing, which wickedly they did amiÅ¿Å¿e.

As long as the EngliÅ¿h abounded in Riches, and in Wealth, he knew they were not altogether heartleÅ¿Å¿e; and therefore he depriued them of thoÅ¿e comforts. And (to encreaÅ¿e his owne Å¿tore) he practiÅ¿ed Å¿ubtile trickes on both eÅ¿tates: for he robbed the Clergie of all their beÅ¿t and richeÅ¿t Plate and Ornaments (which had been conÅ¿ecrated to holy vÅ¿es) alledging, That Theeues and Traiterous Rebels had hid them there, to deceiue him of his forfeitures, and Å¿ecretly to Å¿upport themÅ¿elues therewith, to his great hurt.

He alÅ¿o enacted and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed Å¿trait and Å¿euere Lawes, and publiÅ¿hed them in his owne Language; by meanes whereof, manie (who were of great eÅ¿tate, and of much worth) through ignorance did tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e, and their Å¿malleÅ¿t offences were great enough to entitle the Conquerour to the Lands and Riches which they did poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e. All which he Å¿eized on, and tooke from them, without remorÅ¿e.

Then he diÅ¿allowed the Patents, and the Graunts of former Kings, and publiÅ¿hed them to be meerely void; and hauing Å¿equeÅ¿tred them into his owne hands, he Å¿old them againe to the true
owners for great Å¿ummes of money, if they could pay them: but otherwiÅ¿e he gaue them to his Normans, and to the French.

He procured a generall view to be taken of his Å¿ubiects Lands, and cauÅ¿ed them to be juÅ¿tly meaÅ¿ured, and their cattell to be numbred, and thereby he taxed them, according to Å¿uch proportions as he pleaÅ¿ed; and (by Å¿uch vndue Exactions) he Å¿craped and Å¿cratched together the TreaÅ¿ure of this Realme, little regarding the wants and pouertie of his conquered people, if (by anie meanes) he could augment his owne Å¿tore.

He erected Å¿undrie Courts for the adminiÅ¿tration of his new Lawes, and of IuÅ¿tice; and leaÅ¿t his Iudges Å¿hould beare too great a Å¿way, by reaÅ¿on of his abÅ¿ence, he cauÅ¿ed them all to follow his Court vpon all remoues: Whereby he not onely curbed their diÅ¿poÅ¿itions, which incited them to be great, but alÅ¿o tyred out the EngliÅ¿h Nation with extraordinarie troubles, and exceÅ¿Å¿iue charges in the proÅ¿ecution of their Suites in Law.

To open a wide dore, and to giue the more free acceÅ¿Å¿e vnto the French and Normans (if the EngliÅ¿h Å¿hould happen to rebell) he ruinated all Churches, Chappels, Villages, and Townes, which Å¿tood within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of manie myles in HampÅ¿hire, and made the New ForeÅ¿t there; vtterly diÅ¿peopling thoÅ¿e places where God was formerly Å¿erued, and frugall Husbandrie maintained; making them an habitation for wilde and Å¿auage BeaÅ¿ts: which act and deede he coloured with the pretence of fitneÅ¿Å¿e, and conueniencie for his recreation in Hunting, when great affaires and important buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e would giue him leaue. But God reuenged his owne cauÅ¿e by the vntimely death of Rufus his Å¿onne, and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿or; who (as he hunted) was Å¿laine with an arrow in the Å¿ame ForeÅ¿t.

Aboue all other pleaÅ¿ures he placed his chiefeÅ¿t delight in Hunting: and for the furtherance thereof, when he had Å¿eized into his owne hands all the ChaÅ¿es and ForeÅ¿ts of this Kingdome, then (to preÅ¿erue his Game from diÅ¿turbance, and from Å¿poile) he made and executed moÅ¿t Å¿harpe and bitter Lawes againÅ¿t Å¿uch, as (vnlicenced) preÅ¿umed to hunt in them; as the loÅ¿Å¿e of eyes, limbes, and Å¿uch like: But they were afterwards made more milde and gentle, by Å¿uch as by Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion wore his Crowne.

He gaue large territories and Å¿patious fields vnto his fauorites; who did diuide them into Farmes, for their particular vÅ¿es and neceÅ¿Å¿ities, and the reÅ¿idue of them they graunted or leaÅ¿ed to their Å¿laues and Å¿eruants; thereby creating Manors, and entitling themÅ¿elues the Lords of them. The King alÅ¿o vpon thoÅ¿e his gifts proportioned thoÅ¿e grounds, diuiding them into Hydes of Land, euery
Hyde containing twentie acres, and eight Hydes making a whole Knights fee. The Tenures which he reÅ¿erued, were Knights Å¿eruice in capite: by meanes whereof, his Tenants were enioyned to doe him manie neceÅ¿Å¿arie and honorable Seruices, either in his Warres, or to his Royall perÅ¿on. For the performance whereof, he tooke their Oathes in publike Courts, both of Homage and of Fealtie. And by reaÅ¿on of this kinde of Tenure, he diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of the bodies of their Heires in marriage as he liÅ¿ted, and retayned in his cuÅ¿todie and WardÅ¿hip, to his owne vÅ¿e, their whole Inheritance, vntill they accompliÅ¿hed their age of one and twentie yeares. Which Tenures are continued at this day. And, by his example, others of great poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions did the like.

And thus may we plainely Å¿ee (as in a Mappe) the perfect Modell and DeÅ¿cription of his rigorous and Å¿harpe Gouernement; wherein he rather practiÅ¿ed the licentious power of an inÅ¿olent Conqueror, than the gratious kindneÅ¿Å¿e of an annointed King. By meanes whereof, many feared, few did loue him: and Å¿uch as pleaÅ¿ed him beÅ¿t, were many times in great hazard (vpon Å¿mall occaÅ¿ions) to be frowned on.

ANNO. 2.In the Å¿econd yeare of his raigne, by reaÅ¿on of his Taxes, which exceeded beyond meaÅ¿ure, the inhabitants of Northumberland, and of Deuon, Taxes cauÅ¿ed Rebellions. did rebell. But Å¿uch was his valour and expedition, that (ere they were aware thereof) his forces (like a loftie Sea, or a whirling Wind) ruÅ¿hed violently vpon them, and eaÅ¿ily Å¿ubdued them, to their paine.

ANNO. 3.And not long after, Swanus then King of the Danes (being animated and Å¿et on edge by the daily perÅ¿waÅ¿ions and enticements of Å¿uch EngliÅ¿h Nobles,The Danes inuade, and are put to flight. as to preuent their owne ruine and deÅ¿truction were fled to him for Å¿uccour) arriued with a Å¿trong Armie in the North: where the inhabitants (endeuoring the enjoyment of their former libertie) with bold courage aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted them in their inuaÅ¿ion. But the King almoÅ¿t no Å¿ooner Å¿aw them) than he compelled them vpon the looÅ¿ing hand) to flye vnto their Å¿hippes. And (to reuenge the infidelitie of the EngliÅ¿h) he vtterly Å¿poyled and harrowed their beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t fruitfull Lands,The EngliÅ¿h are plagued. lying betwixt Yorke and Durham. So that by reaÅ¿on thereof (for the Å¿pace of nine yeares after) thoÅ¿e grounds lay waÅ¿t, and vnmanured; and great numbers of people, of all ages, died miÅ¿erably, with famine, and with want.

ANNO. 4.The next yeare after he Å¿ummoned a generall Conuocation of his Clergie. In which (with much aÅ¿peritie and bitterneÅ¿Å¿e) he accuÅ¿ed diuers and Å¿undrie graue and learned BiÅ¿hops, Abbots, Priors, and Religious Prelates, of many Å¿urmiÅ¿es, faults, and offences:
for which he vtterly depoÅ¿ed and depriued them, both of their Dignities, Goods, and Liuings: all which he conferred vpon Å¿uch, as (either through his fauour, or for great Å¿ummes of money) were able to procure them.

TheÅ¿e fearefull preÅ¿idents of inÅ¿ufferable cruelties,Another Rebellion. prouoked Marcarus, and Edwyn, then Earles of Northumberland, and of Mercia, together with Egilwynus, then BiÅ¿hop of Durham, to rebell. But the King (like a Lyon encountring their weaker forces) draue Edwyn into Scotland; where trecherouÅ¿ly he was murdered. He tooke Marcarus, and impriÅ¿oned him in the Tower of London: where (manie yeares after) he remained, with little hope of his deliuerance. And the BiÅ¿hop (being a priÅ¿oner in the Abbey of Abbington) was cruelly famiÅ¿hed to death.

At this time great Å¿trife, touching the Primacie, aroÅ¿e,ANNO. 7. The Primacie of Canterburie. ANNO. 9. betwixt the ArchbiÅ¿hops of Canterburie, and of Yorke: which continued almoÅ¿t two yeares. But at length, Thomas was adiudged to be Å¿ubordinate to Lanfrank, then ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie, and the other Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe accordingly.

OÅ¿wald, BiÅ¿hop of Salisburie, ANNO 13. Secundum vÅ¿um Sarum. was a moÅ¿t deuout and religious man: he deuiÅ¿ed a certaine forme of Prayers to be daily vÅ¿ed in his Church: which was Å¿o generally liked by the Clergie, that they were publiÅ¿hed in bookes, and vÅ¿ed in other Churches. Whence proceeded the common Å¿aying of Secundum vÅ¿um Sarum.

In the fifteenth yeare of this Kings Raigne (by the inÅ¿tigation,ANNO 15. and with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Philip the French King) Robert, his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, rebelled in Normandie: A Rebellion in Normandie which occaÅ¿ioned his father to goe thither with an Armie. But he was Å¿o Å¿tiffely encountred in the field, that by his Å¿onne he was vnhorÅ¿ed, and in great perill of his life. But he reÅ¿cued him againe, reconciled himÅ¿elfe, receiued pardon, and the King (with much loÅ¿Å¿e) returned againe into England.

And within few yeares after,ANNO 20. to be reuenged of manie iniuries and wrongs to him done by the Å¿aid Philip, from Normandie, The Conqueror inuadeth France. hee carried a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie into France: where (with fortunate Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, and with abundance of crueltie) he Å¿lew burnt, Å¿poyled, and ranÅ¿acked his People Townes, and Countrey. But Å¿o much was he trauelled in thoÅ¿e affaires, and Å¿o extreamely did he heate himÅ¿elfe
in thoÅ¿e eager conflicts, that preÅ¿ently he fell Å¿icke, and within few daies after he died,The Conqueror falleth Å¿icke, and dieth. after he had much Å¿orrowed and lamented for the Tyrannies which he had exerciÅ¿ed on the EngliÅ¿h Nation: and at laÅ¿t he was buried at Cane in Normandie, in the Abbey of S. Stephen, which himÅ¿elfe had builded. But his Funerals were interrupted by a Norman Gentleman:This dead dogge could not bite. who would not permit him to be interred there, vntill a Å¿atisfactorie recompence was vnto him giuen for that Å¿oyle, which the Conquerour had vniuÅ¿tly taken from him.
Thus this victorious Conquerour, whoÅ¿e minde was not to be confined with one Kingdome whileÅ¿t he liued, could (being dead) hardly obtaine a place to be buried in.

He left behinde him one daughter, named Adela, and three Å¿onnes: Robert, to whome he gaue his Duchie of Normandie: William, Å¿urnamed Rufus, becauÅ¿e his complexion was verie redde; and Henrie: both which Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿iuely were Kings.

The deÅ¿cription of the Conqueror.He was of an indifferent Å¿tature, Å¿trongly compoÅ¿ed in his limbs, and comely in his behauiour; Å¿terne of countenance, and of an vndaunted Å¿pirit: reÅ¿olute in all his actions; quicke in his Expeditions; wiÅ¿e, diÅ¿creet, and politike in the managing of his affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. He banqueted, and hunted verie much; coueted all; oppreÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿uch as he Å¿ubdued (to keepe them low) and alwaies held his deereÅ¿t friends in an awfull regard of his loue.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING WILLIAM RÆ²FÆ²S.
div.p: WHEN William the Conqueror died, Robert his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne (being in Germanie) accommodated himÅ¿elfe (with great Å¿ufficiencie) to thoÅ¿e affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es wherewith his father had entruÅ¿ted him: Å¿o that, by means of his abÅ¿ence, the Conquerors laÅ¿t Will and TeÅ¿tament, the furtherance by Lanfrank, then ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie (who, by reaÅ¿on of his great learning, and Å¿ingular vertues, was verie deere and reuerend in the peoples eyes) and by manie coÅ¿tlie gifts, enlarged with vnaccuÅ¿tomed bountie,9. Septemb. 1087. William (his younger brother) was crowned King.

The King oppreÅ¿Å¿eth the EngliÅ¿h Nation by Taxes and other cruelties.The King (by theÅ¿e meanes) more Å¿trongly fixing his foote in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of this Kingdome, and being better aÅ¿Å¿ured of his eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment than he was before, began forthwith to tread in his fathers Å¿teppes, and (with like oppreÅ¿Å¿ions and Å¿eueritie) to humble the haughtie courage of the EngliÅ¿h: and finding by the Rules of Policie, That Plentie puffeth vp, and that Penurie robbeth Å¿uch as are hardie of the chiefeÅ¿t RequiÅ¿ites which might enable them to reÅ¿iÅ¿t, impoÅ¿ed on them manie vnuÅ¿uall Payments, and intolerable Taxes; which by his greedie miniÅ¿ters and Å¿awcie officers were leuied with Å¿uch deÅ¿pight and crueltie, that thereby they might well perceiue, that he meant nothing more than to cut the nerues and Å¿inewes of their Å¿trength.

An old BiÅ¿hop made a young Earle.About the Å¿ame time, Odo his vncle, being BiÅ¿hop of Bayon, repaired into England; where (by reaÅ¿on of the Kings regardfull affection towards him) he found Å¿uch welcome and friendly entertainment, that he was created Earle of Kent.

The old BiÅ¿hop, and young Earle, preÅ¿uming too much on his Nephewes loue, and mounting his conceits aboue the height of a conuenient pitch, tooke vpon him more authoritie to rule, than either a Å¿tranger, or a Å¿ubject, in wiÅ¿edome Å¿hould affect: which altered the pleaÅ¿antneÅ¿Å¿e of the Kings countenance into frownes, and made him much leÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿teemed, than otherwiÅ¿e he would haue beene.

The Kings vncle rebelleth.The BiÅ¿hop (whoÅ¿e heart was haughtie, and whoÅ¿e minde aÅ¿pired to more than ordinarie greatneÅ¿Å¿e) Å¿o inwardly grudged, that the Line of Soueraigne MajeÅ¿tie Å¿hould tye him Å¿hort, that openly he did rebell; and in Å¿uch Å¿ort (by the helpe of the EngliÅ¿h Normans) diÅ¿tempered the Å¿oundneÅ¿Å¿e of the Commonweales Peace with manie turbulent and dangerous mutinies, in Å¿undrie places of the Land, that the King (contrarie to his naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, and contrarie to the former Rules of his Policie) was compelled to Å¿trengthen his owne part by the EngliÅ¿h Nation;The King through neceÅ¿Å¿itie flattereth the EngliÅ¿h. whome (with better vÅ¿age, fairer Å¿peeches, releaÅ¿ement of injurious Taxes, and great gifts) he made Å¿o firme and faithfull to him, that (by their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance) he more than well hoped to preuaile. And Å¿uch was his new courteÅ¿ie and kindneÅ¿Å¿e to manie of the reuolted Lords, that (leauing the BiÅ¿hop and his aÅ¿Å¿ociates) they adhered firmely vnto the King.

TheÅ¿e fractions and theÅ¿e diÅ¿orders in the publike State begot new conceits in Malcolyne King of Scots: The Scots rebell. who on the Å¿uddaine railing a faire Armie of aduenturous men of warre, inuaded the Northren parts of this Kingdome. The newes whereof appalled not the King, but rather it inÅ¿pired him with a Å¿pirit of Å¿uch inuincible courage, that marching firÅ¿t againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hop and his complices,The BiÅ¿hop is ouerthrowne. with an high hand he obtained a quicke victorie, and enforced the vnwiÅ¿e BiÅ¿hop, his vncle, to abiure the Land.

And forthwith (being mounted aloft, vpon the wings of Furie, ANNO. 3. The Scots ouerthrowne. and Å¿corning to be checked by reÅ¿iÅ¿tance) he ruÅ¿hed with Å¿uch manlike violence vpon the hardie Scots, that the greateÅ¿t numbers of them were quickly Å¿laine in the field; and Malcolyne was not onely compelled to acknowledge his Å¿ubiection,The Scots Å¿ubiection. by renewing of his former Oath, but willingly he became a Pentioner to the King.

In the Å¿ixt yeare of his Raigne his proÅ¿peritie was interrupted by the obÅ¿tinate Rebellion of Rees, the laÅ¿t King of the Welchmen:
ANNO. 6. The Welchmen rebell, and are Å¿ubdued. who Å¿o infeÅ¿ted him with broken warres, that, for many moneths together, being vrged to fight with Mountaines (to which vpon all enforcements they fled) in Å¿tead of combating with men, he could finde no reÅ¿t. But Å¿uch was his reÅ¿olution, his valour, and vndaunted courage, to withÅ¿tand the Å¿trongeÅ¿t puÅ¿h of all extremities, that in the end he Å¿lew their King, and (by a glorious victorie) he better Å¿ecured the Å¿ubjection of the Welchmen, than any of his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors had done before.

Not long afterwards,The Scots rebell againe. Malcolyne the King of Scots (being vnkindly and diÅ¿gracefully denied acceÅ¿Å¿e to the EngliÅ¿h Court, where he intended a friendly conference vpon many matters of great weight and conÅ¿equence) returned into Scotland; and being infected with a million of diÅ¿contents, the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of his paÅ¿Å¿ions publiÅ¿hed it Å¿elfe, with much danger, to the Northren parts: which he inuaded with a Å¿trong Armie; Å¿poyling, robbing, burning, wounding, and killing (without controlment) in all places, as he liÅ¿ted: vntill he beÅ¿ieged a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle; which for manie daies was valiantly defended by Robert Mowbray, then Earle of Northumberland: who at length Å¿eeming to yeeld to the frowardneÅ¿Å¿e of his diÅ¿aÅ¿terous fortune, and comming out of his CaÅ¿tle gate well mounted, with the keyes thereof faÅ¿tened vnto his launce,The King of Scots Å¿laine. and making low obeyÅ¿ance to the King in token of his Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, and daÅ¿hing his Å¿purres into his horÅ¿e, he ranne vpon the King, and with his launce (in Å¿tead of tendering him the keyes) he pierced out his eye, and Å¿lew him on the place: Which hauing done, he eÅ¿caped, flying like the winde, leauing the diÅ¿mayed Scots behinde him, to lament their irrecuperable
loÅ¿Å¿e, and with much Å¿orrow to returne into Scotland with their breathleÅ¿Å¿e King.

As on the Sea-Å¿hore one waue Å¿ucceedes another: Å¿o in humane affaires there is no end of troubles. No Å¿ooner was this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e concluded, but another did begin. For Robert Duke of Normandie (conceiuing himÅ¿elfe to be much wronged, by a Å¿uppoÅ¿ed breach of the Kings former promiÅ¿es) reÅ¿olued to tranÅ¿port a faire Armie into England, for the regayning of his Right: but the King (purpoÅ¿ing rather to aduenture offenÅ¿iue Warres abroad,A good Policie. than with aÅ¿Å¿ured loÅ¿Å¿e to defend himÅ¿elfe at home) gathered a Å¿trong power of able and willing men of warre, with which he Å¿ayled into Normandie. The French Å¿trengthen Robert Duke of Normandie against the King. But Philip of France Å¿o friendly backed the Duke in thoÅ¿e employments, that the EngliÅ¿h forces found themÅ¿elues too weake to doe him any harme. So this vnexpected reÅ¿iÅ¿tance compelled the King to caÅ¿t his plot into a new mould, and by Å¿leight and policie to effect that, which by open violence he could not doe. Wherefore (not making himÅ¿elfe ouer-much beholding to long deliberation) he Å¿ent many of his chiefeÅ¿t Commanders into England; who (with more than ordinarie diligence and Å¿peede) in Å¿hort time waged a Å¿trong Armie of twentie thouÅ¿and men: who (being readie to be embarked) were vnexpectedly greeted with this faire offer,A politike and a pleaÅ¿ing Taxe. That Å¿uch of them as would Å¿euerally giue tenne Å¿hillings to the King, towards his leuying of new forces in Normandie, Å¿hould be diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed from that journey. This demaund (in regard of each particular giuer) was not great: but the entire value thereof, when it was collected, amounted to a good Å¿umme; becauÅ¿e there were few, or none, who by this payment procured not their diÅ¿charge. And the French King (being Å¿ecretly corrupted with the gift of the greater part of this money) made preÅ¿ent choiÅ¿e rather to Å¿hrinke from his kinde friend,Quid non Regina pecunia? than to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him at his neede: Å¿o that the good Duke (being left alone, and yet accompanied with the Å¿enÅ¿ible apprehenÅ¿ion of his owne defects, and making a vertue of his neceÅ¿Å¿ities) contented himÅ¿elfe to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to the commaund of his aduerÅ¿e fortune.A compoÅ¿ition For, making an enforced Peace with his brother, and pawning to him his Duchie of Normandie for tenne thouÅ¿and pounds; himÅ¿elfe in perÅ¿on, with other ChriÅ¿tian Princes, waged warres in the Holy Land.

The Welchmen rebell.As Å¿oone as the King was returned into England, the Rebels in Wales Å¿ummoned him to a new Warre; which he vndertooke with great celeritie and with much valour. But the craggie Mountaines, the Å¿teepie Hils, the thicke Woods, and the watrie MariÅ¿hes (vnto which the Welchmen vÅ¿ed continually to flye vpon euerie feare of
danger) Å¿o toyled and tyred the EngliÅ¿h forces, that the King (to encreaÅ¿e his Å¿trength, and to furniÅ¿h himÅ¿elfe with more fitting meanes to Å¿ubdue thoÅ¿e Rebels) was compelled, without honour, to returne.

But thoÅ¿e his new preparations were interrupted by another Rebellion in the North:The Earle of Northumberland rebelleth. which was occaÅ¿ioned and conducted by Robert Mowbray, Earle of Northumberland; who madly expreÅ¿Å¿ed the malecontentednes of his diÅ¿ordered paÅ¿Å¿ions, becauÅ¿e the King (as he conceiued) had not requited his Å¿eruice done vpon Malcolyne, the King of Scots, with any worthie or condigne reward.A couragious King. But Å¿uch was the haughtie Å¿pirit and courage of the King, that thoÅ¿e vnexpected troubles, which benummed the Å¿enÅ¿es of the vulgar, did Å¿et an edge vpon his valour, making him to Å¿corne feare, and to entertaine hope; and animating him, with a Å¿etled reÅ¿olution, to dare fortune to doe her worÅ¿t. For he no Å¿ooner Å¿aw his reuolted Å¿ubjects of the North,The Rebels Å¿ubdued. but he loaded them in Å¿uch Å¿ort with blowes and wounds, that Å¿uch as fled not he made a prey vnto death, or made them miÅ¿erable examples to their friends; who might bemoane them, but could not releaÅ¿e them, of their loÅ¿Å¿e of Eares, Eyes, Hands, NoÅ¿es, or Feete. Thus did the King beate downe their pride, and tooke the Earle as hee fled, and Å¿ent him to the CaÅ¿tle of WindÅ¿our, where hee was committed to a Å¿trong PriÅ¿on.

Then did the King (with new Å¿trength) march againe into Wales: The King could not Å¿ubdue the Welchmen in two Expeditions. but his former miÅ¿haps were preÅ¿idents to his later Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e. For albeit that Furie made him more aduenturous than ReaÅ¿on gaue him warrant, in regard that his magnanimous Å¿pirit could not digeÅ¿t the counter-checks of Å¿uch a Å¿cattered Rabble: yet (when hee had weakened his Å¿trength, and impaired his Armie, by the loÅ¿Å¿e of manie valiant men, vpon the vaÅ¿t and deÅ¿olate Mountaines, which affoorded him nothing but Repentance) he was enforced (farre againÅ¿t his will) the Å¿econd time to returne, leauing the Welch Rebels vncorrected; and therefore exceedingly emboldened in their Å¿inne. WhoÅ¿e inÅ¿olencies bred in the King Å¿uch a Å¿trong reÅ¿olution to reuenge, that foure yeares after (when they Å¿uÅ¿pected not any approaching danger) he Å¿ent againÅ¿t them the two Earles of Shrewsburie, and of CheÅ¿ter, with a Å¿trong Power:The Welchmen Å¿odainely inuaded are ouerthrowne who finding them rioting in the IÅ¿le of AngleÅ¿ey, Å¿et vpon them, Å¿lew diuers, wounded more, Å¿uffered few to eÅ¿cape; and Å¿uch as were taken priÅ¿oners, were eyther executed with manie Torments, or diÅ¿membred, with Å¿uch Depriuements, as happened to the Rebells in the North.

ANNO 10.Now when the King (by the helpe of the EngliÅ¿h Nation) had obtained many memorable victories againÅ¿t the Scots, Welchmen, and the Northren Rebels;An vngratefull King. and (by their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance) had in Å¿uch Å¿ort eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed his affaires, that all feare of future perils was quite baniÅ¿he â¢ ; imitating the example of Å¿ome vnthankfull Mariners: who (by the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of a Å¿ound Ship) hauing eÅ¿caped the boiÅ¿terous rage of an hideous TempeÅ¿t, will leaue her in the Roade, Å¿ubject to the furie of the windes, and to the violence of the waters: Hee not onely forgot his honourable atchieuements by their meanes, but vnthankefully he requited them, who had freed him from manie vnÅ¿peakable dangers. For, as in former times, Å¿o now againe he dis-heartened them,The EngliÅ¿h Nation is miÅ¿erably oppreÅ¿Å¿ed. by manie intollerable exactions, new impoÅ¿Å¿itions, and mercileÅ¿Å¿e oppreÅ¿Å¿ions: turning their longings after Libertie into a Å¿eruile Bondage; their expectations for Fauour, into DeÅ¿paire; and their Plentie into Å¿uch Pouertie: that though thoÅ¿e Times gaue them leaue Å¿orrowfully to bewayle their griefes; yet Hope adminiÅ¿tred to them no comfort for Reliefe. Yea, Å¿uch was his impietie,Extreame couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e in a King. and Å¿uch was his couetous deÅ¿ire, by all vnjuÅ¿t meanes to enrich himÅ¿elfe; that impiouÅ¿ly he Å¿old for money the greateÅ¿t and the beÅ¿t Promotions, both in Church, and in Commonweale: and did prohibite AnÅ¿elme, then ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie, to aÅ¿Å¿emble any Conuocations, or Synods, for the well ordering of the Clergie, or for the correcting of Å¿uch as did offend; without his leaue and licence: by meanes whereof, he Å¿ecretly filled his coffers with much TreaÅ¿ure.

The ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie robbed, & rifled.TheÅ¿e indignities, and theÅ¿e irreligious practiÅ¿es, were Å¿harpely reprehended by AnÅ¿elme: yet found he no reformation of thoÅ¿e monÅ¿trous abuÅ¿es. Wherefore (being vnable anie longer to Å¿upport Å¿o ponderous a burthen, both to his ConÅ¿cience, and alÅ¿o to his EÅ¿tate) he reÅ¿olued to forÅ¿ake the Realme, and appeale to Pope Vrban the third;Appeale to Rome. though by the King he was prohibited Å¿o to doe. But in the beginning of his journey, as he paÅ¿Å¿ed towards Douer; himÅ¿elfe,The King likely to haue been excommunicated. and all his followers (by the Kings vncharitable appointment) were euilly entreated, and robbed of their chiefeÅ¿t wealth. Yet went he forth, and at Rome complained to the Pope: who forthwith would haue excummunicated the King; had hee not formerly pronounced that Sentence againÅ¿t the Emperour Henrie the fourth (who was the firÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian Prince Soueraigne that euer was excommunicated by anie BiÅ¿hop of Rome: The Emperor Henry the fourth was the firÅ¿t excommunicated ChriÅ¿tian Prince.) and by his Clergie he was aduiÅ¿ed to Å¿ee the end and effect of that Sentence; and Å¿hould not heate anie more yrons, before he Å¿aw how the former would be quenched.

Manie Letters and Å¿undrie MeÅ¿Å¿engers were Å¿ent vnto the King;Commaunds from Pope Vrban the third. admoniÅ¿hing him not to intermeddle anie more with the inueÅ¿ting of BiÅ¿hops; by giuing to them the CroÅ¿Å¿e, Ring, and PaÅ¿torall Staffe: nor with the Temporalties of anie EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Promotions, either when they were vacant, or otherwiÅ¿e. Nor Å¿hould prohibite the aÅ¿Å¿embling of anie Conuocations or Synods, touching the Churches affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e: Nor Å¿hould prohibite the execution of anie Canons; albeit they were not by Regall authoritie confirmed.

But the King little reÅ¿pected thoÅ¿e Commaunds,The King regards not the Popes commaunds. and Å¿toutly anÅ¿wered, That, touching them all, hee would Å¿till doe as hee pleaÅ¿ed; and would not looÅ¿e Å¿o faire a flower belonging vnto his Crowne.

But whileÅ¿t theÅ¿e buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es were thus acted, the King was oftentimes Å¿harpely rebuked by Ralph, the BiÅ¿hop of ChicheÅ¿ter, The King is reproued, and is the worÅ¿e. for thoÅ¿e vnjuÅ¿t grieuances and wrongs which were offered to the ArchbiÅ¿hop, and his followers, at the time of their departure towards Rome. But, like as a man, the deeper he is wounded, the more impatient he is to be Å¿oundly Å¿earched: Å¿o the King (knowing his offence to be impious and vngodly) refuÅ¿ed to be admoniÅ¿hed: and, in Å¿tead of reforming of thoÅ¿e things which had been done amiÅ¿Å¿e, he heaped many diÅ¿gracefull wrongs vpon the good BiÅ¿hop, and his DioceÅ¿Å¿e; within which (of his own wilfull obÅ¿tinacie, and becauÅ¿e hee would proclaime his will to be a Law) hee Å¿uÅ¿pended many Churches, and conuerted their Reuenewes to his owne vÅ¿e.

But his later meditations better informing him than his former neglect, and vnaduiÅ¿ed paÅ¿Å¿ions:The King repenteth. he not onely receiued the BiÅ¿hop into his extraordinarie grace and fauour; but enriched him and his See with many honourable Priuiledges and Princely gifts: Yet afterwards he baniÅ¿hed him out of his Kingdome.

It happened, that (as he hunted in the New-ForeÅ¿t) he was informed, that the Frenchmen had compaÅ¿Å¿ed the Citie of ConÅ¿tancia in Normandie with a Siege, which was both Å¿trong, and dangerous. Whereupon (leauing his Sports, his Nobles,Wonderfull courage, and all his Companie) with great expedition he poÅ¿ted towards the Sea: and, without any preparations fitting for Å¿uch a journey, he leapt into a Barke; and commaunded the Mariners to weigh their anchor, and to hoyÅ¿e their Sayles. But Å¿uch was the furious violence of a boyÅ¿terous Å¿torme, that (not daring to doe what they were commanded) they refuÅ¿ed to obey: Whereat the King was much enraged, and did enforce them to yeeld to his reÅ¿olued humor; affirming, That they had neuer heard, that a King was drowned by the diÅ¿temper
of anie winde. And Å¿uch was his fortunate PaÅ¿Å¿age in a time Å¿o dangerous, and Å¿o much were the Frenchmen daunted with the vnexpected newes of his Å¿uddaine landing:Fortunate Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e. that inÅ¿tantly they abandoned the Siege; and by their quicke departure preuented the hazard which they much doubted.

ANNO 13.And within two yeares after his returne into England, and in the thirteenth yeare of his Raigne (as he hunted in the Å¿aid New-ForeÅ¿t,The King Å¿laine as he hunted. which his Father had made, and which himÅ¿elfe had enlarged, by depopulating of Å¿undrie Townes, Villages, and Farmes, and with the vtter ruine of manie Churches, Chappels, and Religious houÅ¿es) he was Å¿laine with an arrow: which being Å¿hot vnto a Deere, vnfortunately glanced vpon him, as, not long before, his Nephew Richard, and Sonne vnto Duke Robert of Normandie, had beene there Å¿laine.

And thus ended the troubleÅ¿ome, yet victorious, Raigne of King William, third Å¿onne to the Conqueror: who being of a wanton diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, neglecting marriage, and daily Å¿olacing himÅ¿elfe among his whores and concubines, died without any lawfull iÅ¿Å¿ue of his bodie. He was of a comely Å¿tature; firmely compacted in his limbes; very Å¿trong, actiue, and healthie; exceeding lecherous, and couetous; of an high courage, and nobly valorous; conÅ¿tant in his reÅ¿olutions; Å¿corning Fortune, and all Troubles. Thus he liued, and thus he died; getting much, and Å¿uddainely leauing all.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE FIRST.
div.p: WHEN King William the Å¿econd died; Robert, ANNO 1100. his eldeÅ¿t brother (fortunate in all his proceedings, Å¿auing onely in his SucceÅ¿Å¿ion to this Crowne) warred victoriouÅ¿ly (as manie other ChriÅ¿tian Princes did) in the Holie Land: where (in regard of his honourable deedes and heroicall actions) he refuÅ¿ed to be made King of IeruÅ¿alem.

By meanes of his abÅ¿ence, a fit oportunitie was offered vnto Henrie, his youngeÅ¿t brother, to Å¿it as King in his Throne: whereunto (without labour, or difficultie) he aÅ¿cended, through the fauourable affection of the Nobles and common People: whoÅ¿e hearts were the more firmely engaged to his Å¿eruice, becauÅ¿e he was borne in England after his father was crowned King: and alÅ¿o, becauÅ¿e his Å¿ingular WiÅ¿dome, rare Learning, milde DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, and princely Vertues, were plaine and apparant demonÅ¿trations, that his Gouernment would be accompanied with honorable Atchieuements; gracefull, Å¿afe, and profitable both to the Church, and alÅ¿o to the Common-weale.

No Å¿ooner was he crowned, and proclaimed King, but WiÅ¿dome
did informe him,A true vÅ¿e of Riches. That it was expedient, that his EÅ¿tate Å¿hould Å¿trongly be Å¿upported againÅ¿t the hazards of future Time, and his brothers Title. Wherefore (hauing Å¿eized vpon the plentifull heapes of the laÅ¿t kings TreaÅ¿ure) he diÅ¿perÅ¿ed them frankly into the hands of Å¿uch,Good policies worthie of a noble King, and to be noted. as vpon all occaÅ¿ions, and in all dangers, were able to affoord him their beÅ¿t counÅ¿ell, and the beÅ¿t reliefe. Then hee dignified Å¿uch as were great, with the greateÅ¿t Offices; and with ample Titles of much Honour: And mitigated the rigour of the former new Lawes; and promiÅ¿ed reÅ¿titution of the old. His care was great, that in Weights and in MeaÅ¿ures there might be no defect: but that all, in all places, Å¿hould be fewred by Å¿uch Standards as he had made. He alÅ¿o acquited the People from the Taxe of Dane-gelt; and from all other vnjuÅ¿t payments and demaunds impoÅ¿ed vpon them by the two former kings. He gaue free libertie to the Nobles and Gentlemen of this Realme (for their pleaÅ¿ure,Flatterers baniÅ¿hed the Court. and better recreation) to incloÅ¿e Parkes for Deere, and free Warrens for their Conies, and Å¿uch like Game. And as Traitors to his Vertues, State, and kingly Gouernment, he exiled and baniÅ¿hed from his Court and PreÅ¿ence all baÅ¿e Flatterers; NiceneÅ¿Å¿e in Behauiour, LuxuriouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e in ConuerÅ¿ation; SumptuouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e in Apparell; and Superfluitie in Dyet. He ordained puniÅ¿hments by death for all Å¿uch as violently Å¿poyled or robbed in the High wayes. With indefatigable trauell and paine hee corrected and reformed the monÅ¿trous Pride, intolerable CouetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿ecure Negligence and Slouth of the Clergie. He recalled from BaniÅ¿hment AnÅ¿elme, and reÅ¿tored him to his ArchbiÅ¿hopricke of Canterburie: and gaue him full power to aÅ¿Å¿emble Conuocations and Synods at his pleaÅ¿ure,The King leaueth the inueÅ¿ture of BiÅ¿hops to the Pope. for the amendment of Å¿uch things as were vnÅ¿ufferable in the Church. He left vnto the Pope his power and authoritie to inueÅ¿t BiÅ¿hops, by giuing to them the Ring, the CroÅ¿Å¿e, and the PaÅ¿torall Staffe. All Å¿uch EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Promotions and Dignities, as, by the lewd aduice and counÅ¿ell of Reynulph, BiÅ¿hop of Durham, his brother had Å¿eized into his owne hands, and conuerted to his owne vÅ¿e; he voluntarily and freely conferred vpon HoneÅ¿t, Graue, Learned, and Worthie Men: and committed the Å¿aid BiÅ¿hop a priÅ¿oner to the Tower of London; R bert Duke of Normandy inuadeth England. from whence he afterwards eÅ¿caped, and eagerly incited Robert, Duke of Normandie, by the Sword to lay his clayme to this kingdome. Who thereupon (to maintaine his demaund in that behalfe) rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong Armie; which he intended, with all conuenient expedition, to tranÅ¿port into this Realme. But as king Henrie, by thoÅ¿e precedent prouiÅ¿ions, had endeared himÅ¿elfe in the Peoples loue: Å¿o had he the more confirmed
it, by taking to wife Mawlde, the Å¿iÅ¿ter of Edgar, King Henries title made Å¿tronger by his marriage. King of Scots, and daughter vnto Malcolyne, by Margaret his wife, Å¿iÅ¿ter to Edgar Adelinge (who died without iÅ¿Å¿ue) and daughter to King Edward, the Å¿onne of Edmund Iron-Å¿ide, the victorious and valiant King of the Saxons.

When Duke Robert, with his Armie, was arriued in England, the noyÅ¿e of Trumpets, the Å¿ound of Drummes, and the Å¿warming multitudes of well-approued Souldiors, fit for the Warre, affoorded none other thing but a fearefull expectation of much trouble. But as a threatening lowring Cloud is Å¿ometimes diÅ¿perÅ¿ed by a fa â¢â¢ e Å¿hining Sunne: Å¿o theÅ¿e approaching conflicts (by the diÅ¿creete mediation and counÅ¿ell of worthie friends) were Å¿uddenly preuented; and a friendly peace,A peace concluded betwixt the two brethren. betwixt the two brothers, was louingly concluded, vpon Å¿uch like conditions, as formerly had beene agreed on in William Rufus his daies: whereat the Norman Lords were much diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed, and returned diÅ¿contented with their Lord.

But Å¿uch were the malignant Å¿pirits of the Enuious;The King inuadeth, and preuaileth in Normandie. or Å¿uch was the greedie diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of thoÅ¿e who were Couetous; or Å¿o eager was the Kings appetite to enlarge his Dominion: that manie great quarrels, for Å¿mall and trifling cauÅ¿es, began vpon the Å¿uddaine to preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elues vnto thoÅ¿e two brethren. InÅ¿omuch, that King Henrie paÅ¿Å¿ed with a Å¿ufficient and a well-ordered Armie into Normandie: where he was aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by manie of the Dukes diÅ¿contented Nobles. By meanes whereof,The Duke is forÅ¿aken by his Nobles and Gentrie. the King (in Å¿undrie skirmiÅ¿hes and conflicts) Å¿o preuailed, that with little danger, and Å¿mall reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, hee chaÅ¿ed the forÅ¿aken Duke from place to place; and wonne from him the Cities of Roan, Cane, Valoys, and manie others: and then hee returned into England with much honour.

The Duke perceiuing that his Lords and Gentrie refuÅ¿ed to giue him anie helpe; and that the Kings EÅ¿tate, Strength, and Riches Å¿o encreaÅ¿ed, that no hope of recouerie (by Å¿triuing and by Å¿trugling) was left vnto him, Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe to his two Enemies, Time and Fortune, (the Å¿cornefull deluders of Å¿uch as repoÅ¿e their confidence vpon them) and came Å¿ecretly and priuatly into England; preÅ¿ented himÅ¿elfe to the King his brother; and referred to his owne cenÅ¿ure and will, both himÅ¿elfe, his Duchie, and all Debates and ControuerÅ¿ies whatÅ¿oeuer. But the King (eyther becauÅ¿e hee knew that the Duke was too vnconÅ¿tant;The Dukes Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion is Å¿cornefully deÅ¿piÅ¿ed. or for that Å¿ome Å¿ecret whiÅ¿perers had prepared him to prejudicate his brothers Truth, and honeÅ¿t Meaning)
with an eÅ¿tranged countenance, and a diÅ¿dainefull eye, departed vnkindly from the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed and perplexed Duke; coyly refuÅ¿ing to accept of his Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, which in all humilitie by him was profered.The Duke returneth, and the King followeth.

The Duke (being pierced to the heart, that his misfortunes Å¿hould Å¿o much wrong him) returned with all expedition into his owne Countrey; reÅ¿oluing, That in the open Field he would rather die as a valiant man, than thus be trampled on by DiÅ¿honour and by DiÅ¿grace. And the king (conjecturing rightly what he pretended) followed him with many thouÅ¿ands of men: and Å¿o often he encountred the weake Duke with his great Å¿trength,The Duke is taken, and his eyes are put out. that within few dayes he tooke him, and brought him as a priÅ¿oner into England: where (becauÅ¿e he hearkened to Natures enticement; which perÅ¿uaded him to Å¿eeke his libertie, and to practiÅ¿e his eÅ¿cape) both his eyes (by the kings commaundement) were plucked out. After which time he liued as a miÅ¿erable and as a wretched captiue more than the Å¿pace of twentie yeares. At length, being dead, in GloceÅ¿ter he was buried.

A Rebellion by the Earles of Shrewsburie and of Mortaigne.About the Å¿ame time Robert BelaÅ¿me, Earle of Shrewsburie, trayterouÅ¿ly did rebell: but wanting Wealth, Wit, Courage, and Strength (the foure Champions of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Field) he was enforced to flye into Normandie. Where finding William, Earle of Mortaigne and of Cornwall, much diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with the king, for that (as he Å¿urmiÅ¿ed) he kept from him vnjuÅ¿tly the Earledome of Kent; he Å¿o much inÅ¿inuated himÅ¿elfe into his loue and counÅ¿els, that eaÅ¿ily he perÅ¿uaded him to rebell. So both of them joyning both their forces together, they made a goodly Å¿hew, as if they would work wonders.They are taken, and impriÅ¿oned. But Å¿mall oppoÅ¿ition enforced them to take a plaine view of their raÅ¿h errors; and (leauing that which they had) to make hard Å¿hifts for the Å¿afegard of themÅ¿elues. Wherein their ill Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e was a juÅ¿t reward for their foule offence: for by the kings Power they were taken, and by him held as priÅ¿oners whileÅ¿t they liued.

New troubles betwixt the King and the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie about the Temporalties of the Clergie and inueÅ¿ture of BiÅ¿hops.The king hauing now caÅ¿t anchor, as he was reÅ¿olued, in a Å¿afe harborow; and nothing fearing the blaÅ¿ts of any Fortune which might attempt to Å¿hake his Å¿ettlement in this kingdome: and finding that manie inconueniences did daily preÅ¿Å¿e him with much diÅ¿honor and diÅ¿grace; becauÅ¿e he intermedled not with the Temporalties of BiÅ¿hoprickes when they were vacant; nor with the inueÅ¿ture of BiÅ¿hops, as his AnceÅ¿tors had done: and being informed, That thoÅ¿e things were inÅ¿eparable incidents vnto his Crowne; and that his neglect to vÅ¿e them depriued him not of
his Right vnto them; reÅ¿olued, That he would not any longer forbeare to chalenge, and to put in practiÅ¿e, thoÅ¿e things which Å¿o juÅ¿tly did belong vnto him. Whereat AnÅ¿elme, the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie, was much diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed; and did vtterly refuÅ¿e to conÅ¿ecrate Å¿uch new BiÅ¿hops, as had receiued their InueÅ¿tures from the king. But Gerald, then ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke, cheerefully performed that Ceremonie, vpon the kings commaund.

This new quarrell tranÅ¿ported AnÅ¿elme the Å¿econd time from England vnto Rome: AnÅ¿elme goeth to Rome the Å¿econd time, & complaineth to Pope PaÅ¿cal the Å¿econd. The ArchbiÅ¿hop preuaileth. where he complayned to Pope PaÅ¿chal the Å¿econd of thoÅ¿e, and of manie other, wrongs: all which were controuerted, and debated with the Å¿trongeÅ¿t oppoÅ¿itions on either partie. But two yeares after, AnÅ¿elme (with the licence and fauour of the king) returned: and in a Synod of the Clergie, holden by him in London, by the Popes authoritie, it was enacted, That from thenceforth no Temporall man Å¿hould giue InueÅ¿ture to any BiÅ¿hop by the CroÅ¿Å¿e and Ring.

Within three yeares after, AnÅ¿elme died: and the Temporalties of that Dignitie being Å¿eized into the kings hands,The King entreth vpon the Temporalties of the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie. were (for the Å¿pace of fiue yeares) taken, receiued, and conuerted to the kings vÅ¿e. And if at anie time (as hee was often) hee were entreated by the BiÅ¿hops to conferre that See vpon Å¿ome other; his anÅ¿were was, That he onely kept it for a Å¿ufficient and a worthie man.

In the yeare of our Lord one thouÅ¿and one hundred and eight, hee erected the BiÅ¿hopricke of Ely, The BiÅ¿hoprick of Ely founded in Anno 1108. and endowed it with large and honourable PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions: which wonne him much fauour with the Pope, and procured him the loue of his owne Clergie.

Thus, when the King (for a few yeares) had enjoyed the benefite of an happie Peace,Normandie inuaded. and held all Normandie Å¿ubject to his owne commaund; his tranquilitie and his pleaÅ¿ure were enuied by Lewis le GroÅ¿Å¿e, then king of France: who firÅ¿t of all procured Fulke, Earle of Angeou (vpon a weake pretence) to Å¿eize vpon the Countrey of Mayne; and then animated Baldwyne, Earle of Flanders, to declare againÅ¿t the king in Armes, for the with-holding of a yearely penÅ¿ion of three hundred markes; which the Conquerour gaue onely vnto Baldwyne, the fifth Earle of Flanders, during his life. But the Å¿ame had afterwards beene payd to his Sonne, and Nephew, by the courteÅ¿ie of the Å¿ucceeding kings; becauÅ¿e the Conquerour had beene well aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted in his Warres with England by the Å¿aid Baldwyne the fifth. All theÅ¿e made Å¿trong preparations to inuade the Kings Duchie of Normandie: But the
newes thereof rowÅ¿ed the King from his bed of eaÅ¿e;The King Å¿ayleth into Normandie, & preuaileth filled him full with Princely reÅ¿olutions; occaÅ¿ioned him to paÅ¿Å¿e the Sea with an Armie of rough and tough Nobles, Gentrie, and common Souldiors. And Å¿hortly after his landing (looÅ¿ing no time) he Å¿et vpon the Earle of Angeou and his aÅ¿Å¿ociates: And after he had beaten him Å¿oundly on euerie Å¿ide, he enforced him to Å¿aue himÅ¿elfe by a Å¿hamefull flight.
Another victorie.And neere vnto the Towne of Nice (which was Å¿urprized and holden by the King of France) King Henrie encountred the other two.

This Battaile was made famous by the continuance of nine houres; and was on all parts fought with Å¿uch eager and manlike reÅ¿olution, that albeit the King of England wonne the Field, and had the long chaÅ¿e of his flying enemies; yet he boldly and truly would confeÅ¿Å¿e, that hee then fought not for victorie, but for his life.

A peace is concluded.At length, when the heat of Anger was well quenched, and when manie lay cold on the floore of death, who in their life times had blowne the coales of contention betweene thoÅ¿e foure Princes;A Mariage. they all were reconciled vnto peace: and the King married to his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne William the daughter of the Å¿aid Fulke. But in their journey towards England, the Å¿aid young Princes, Richard, and Marie CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Perch, two others of the Kings children; his Neece Lucie, A great misfortune. with her husband the Earle of CheÅ¿ier; and more than an hundred and foureÅ¿core others, were vnfortunately drowned by the careleÅ¿Å¿e folly of the drunken Mariners.Drunkennes.

This vnexpected newes (being accompanied with manie millions of Å¿orrowes, and of dolefull paÅ¿Å¿ions) much grieued the King: but made him not heartleÅ¿Å¿e, as moÅ¿t Princes would haue beene in the like caÅ¿e.The Kings admirable patience. For WiÅ¿dome had Å¿ufficiently inÅ¿tructed him, with patience to Å¿uÅ¿taine and beare thoÅ¿e burthens, which could not by any meanes be Å¿haken off. And likewiÅ¿e, the King was at that time affoorded but little leiÅ¿ure to fixe his cogitations on thoÅ¿e miÅ¿haps, becauÅ¿e the obÅ¿tinate Rebellion of the Welchmen drew him vnwillingly into a new Warre. For when he Å¿aw and perceiued, that though he were a King, yet vrgent neceÅ¿Å¿itie commaunded him to Armes; and that IuÅ¿tice did require him (by the Sword) to judge and to execute thoÅ¿e lewd and graceleÅ¿Å¿e Malefactors:The Welchmen rebell, and are Å¿ubdued. hee marched with a Å¿trong Power into Wales; when the Rebels (truÅ¿ting ouer-much to their owne valour; which little, or nothing at all, helpeth in TreaÅ¿onable Plots and Imployments) reÅ¿olued to abide the vtmoÅ¿t puÅ¿h of their fortune:
which yeelded to the King a Å¿peedie and a Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull end of thoÅ¿e Warres. For (with little danger, and as Å¿mall a loÅ¿Å¿e) he gaue them the ouerthrow, and permitted the waÅ¿tfull deuouring Å¿words of his aÅ¿Å¿ociates to Å¿urfet vpon the carkaÅ¿Å¿es of thoÅ¿e Rebels; whome neither gentle vÅ¿age, nor former executions of that nature, could perÅ¿uade to performe thoÅ¿e duties which good Å¿ubjects doe owe vnto their Prince.

Then returned the King, loaden with much honour,Maulde the kings daughter married to the Emperour Henrie the fifth. and was joyfully receiued by all his people; eÅ¿pecially by Mauld his daughter: whome he forthwith Å¿ent to be married vnto the Emperour Henrie the fifth, her affied husband, with a princely portion of Siluer and of Gold; which (in the nature of a Taxe) was leuied vpon the common people of their Land; which he tooke for an ayde towards her marriage. And the Å¿ame cuÅ¿tome,Aid purfi â¢ e marrier. for the marriage of the eldeÅ¿t daughter of the Kings of this Realme, hath beene and is continued vnto this day.

At the Å¿ame time he deuiÅ¿ed and ordered the manner and faÅ¿hion of a Court in Parliament; Anno 1114. The High Court of Parliament f â¢â¢â¢ t establiÅ¿hed at Salisburie in April. appointing it to conÅ¿iÅ¿t of the three EÅ¿tates, of which himÅ¿elfe was the Head: So that his Lawes, being made by the conÅ¿ents of all, were not diÅ¿liked of anie.

It chaunced, that about fiue yeares after the death of AnÅ¿elme, Ralph, BiÅ¿hop of RocheÅ¿ter, The King inueÅ¿teth the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie. was by the King appointed to Å¿ucceede him; and (notwithÅ¿tanding all former CounÅ¿els, Decrees, Commaundements, Letters, and Threatenings from the Pope) he receiued his InueÅ¿ture from the King. Then died the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke: To which See Thurston, the kings Chapleine, Å¿hould haue beene preferred.Pride. But Pride hauing a more large rule and dominion in him, than LowlineÅ¿Å¿e and Humilitie; hee refuÅ¿ed to Å¿weare obedience to the See of Canterburie; which his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors had both Å¿worne and performed. And becauÅ¿e the king (diÅ¿liking his obÅ¿tinacie) would not inueÅ¿t him; he appealed, and went to Rome: where (by the fauor of Å¿ome Cardinals,
Thurston inuested by the Pope.
The King is highly diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed. ThurÅ¿ton preuaileth, and the King yeeldeth. who had the Popes CenÅ¿ure at their commaund) he Å¿o preuailed, that the Pope not onely freed him of his Å¿aid obedience and Å¿ubjectionâª but alÅ¿o inueÅ¿ted him, and gaue him the Pale: whereat the king was extraordinarily diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed, and prohibited his returne. But in the end (the Popes threatenings menacing nothing but CurÅ¿es, SuÅ¿penÅ¿ions, Excommunications, and Å¿uch like) he was permitted to returne, and to enjoy the dignitie of his Place.

In the Å¿euen and twentieth yeare of his Raigne died the Emperour Henrie the fifth, not hauing anie iÅ¿Å¿ue by Maulde the Kings
daughter and heire. At which time Å¿hee being aged about foure and twentie yeares,Mauld the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e married to Geoffrey Plantagenet. and being much Å¿ued vnto by moÅ¿t of the greateÅ¿t Princes of the ChriÅ¿tian World; the king (to Å¿trengthen his Realme againÅ¿t the kings of France) married her to Geoffrey Plantagenet, the Å¿onne and heire apparant of Fulke, then Earle of Angeou. By whome Å¿he had iÅ¿Å¿ue three Å¿onnes: Henrie, who was (after Stephen) king;Her iÅ¿Å¿ue. Geoffrey, and William.

This faire off-Å¿pring enriched the king with the trueÅ¿t endowment of good content; for that (as he conceiued) he Å¿aw in them the Å¿etled continuance of his Line in the Crowne of this Realme.An oath to maintaine the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Crowne in the Kings Line. And (to make it the more Å¿ure) within the Å¿pace of fiue yeares hee tooke three Å¿olemne Oathes of his Nobilitie and greateÅ¿t Officers of his kingdome, That with their beÅ¿t aduice, and with the hazard of their goods, lands, liues, and fortune, they Å¿hould Å¿upport and maintaine the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of his daughter, and of her heires.

The King Å¿urfeteth and dieth.Finally, when he had raigned more than fiue and thirtie yeares, he Å¿urfetted on a Lamprey; of which he languiÅ¿hed a few dayes, and died; and was honourably buried in the Abbey of Reading, which himÅ¿elfe had founded.

This king was WiÅ¿e, Learned, Milde, Valiant, and IuÅ¿t, beyond moÅ¿t of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors; more enclined to Peace than vnto Warre: Å¿o that hee made Warre his Champion Å¿toutly to chalenge his Rights, and to reuenge his Wrongs. He neuer leuied but two Taxes vpon his People: the firÅ¿t was, to maintaine his Warres againÅ¿t the king of France: and the Å¿econd was, to preferre his daughter in marriage with the Emperour. He waxed rich with his owne, and yet he was very liberall: but he onely extended his bountie to Å¿uch as merited it by their publike Seruice; and hee confined his Gifts within the Limits of Thrift and of MeaÅ¿ure. He eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed Lawes, which were profitable to Å¿uch as were vertuous; but Å¿harpe vnto malefactors who did tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e: againÅ¿t whome he cauÅ¿ed them to be put in execution with more Seueritie than Mercie: he being perÅ¿uaded, that Pitie extended to Å¿uch as were wicked, hardened them in their Å¿inne, and too much encouraged Å¿uch, as nothing but correction could either terrifie or reforme. To his friends he was a Å¿ure Pillar, whereunto in all neceÅ¿Å¿ities they might boldly leane: and to his enemies he was rough and Å¿tiffe, vntill time preÅ¿ented occaÅ¿ion of more loue; and then he was verie flexible, and eaÅ¿ie to be reconciled. And, as he would neuer forget good Å¿eruice done, nor anie good turnes performed for him: Å¿o would he Å¿eldome, or neuer, take reÅ¿t, vntill by Å¿ome worthie gift, or correÅ¿pondent requitall, he had Å¿hewed himÅ¿elfe thankfull to Å¿uch as deÅ¿erued well. He
was too laÅ¿ciuious in his courÅ¿e of life; vÅ¿ing manie concubines: by whome he had twelue knowne baÅ¿tards. He erected the two BiÅ¿hoprickes of Ely, and of Carelyle; and founded the MonaÅ¿teries of CirceÅ¿ter, Reading, and Shyrborne; with the Priorie of DunÅ¿table, and Å¿ome others: all which he beautified with manie Priuiledges and PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, anÅ¿werable to their Dignities and Charge.

Yet did he not retaine the chiefeÅ¿t roome in the Clergies loue: becauÅ¿e that (after the death of AnÅ¿elme) hee rejected the Popes Decrees, to which he had formerly Å¿ubjected himÅ¿elfe: and inueÅ¿ted BiÅ¿hops; receiued Homage of Prelates; Å¿eized their Temporaltie â¢
â¢ hen their Sees were vacant; gaue no allowance to any Canons of the Church, except they were ratified and confirmed by the King; compounded with PrieÅ¿ts for annuall penÅ¿ions, to keepe their wiues, or to take them (though vnto them the holy eÅ¿tate of Matrimonie was forbidden:) which penÅ¿ions he enforced them to pay, whether they had wiues or no.
Thus (in this King) ended the iÅ¿Å¿ues males of the Conquerour: and the Crowne of this Realme was deuolued to his generall Heires.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING STEPHEN.
div.p: THe experience of all Ages hath made Å¿ufficient proofe,Stephen vÅ¿urpeth. that the eager appetite which moÅ¿t Men haue to gaine Wealth and Riches, hath made them careleÅ¿Å¿e to performe thoÅ¿e common Duties, which doe belong to HoneÅ¿tie and to Right. But if a Kingdome may be obtained (though with the breach of a moÅ¿t Å¿olemne Oath) no Å¿cruple is then made. For the deÅ¿ire of Soueraignetie, and to enjoy a Crowne, makes men play faÅ¿t and looÅ¿e, and to hazard the loÅ¿Å¿e of their Soules, by the wilfull periurious violating of their Faith.

This proued too true at this time: For albeit that Stephen Earle of Boloigne, the Å¿onne and heire apparant of Stephen Earle of Bloys, and of Adela the Conquerours Daughter, was one of the chiefeÅ¿t,The former Oath is forgotten. whome king Henrie the firÅ¿t had obliged by manie Å¿olemne and publicke Oathes, to further the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Mauld the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, being his Daughter; and of her children: yet (when the king was dead) hee finding, that all the Nobles (though Å¿worne as himÅ¿elfe was) applyed themÅ¿elues to wait vpon his pleaÅ¿ure: he either vtterly forgot, or (at leaÅ¿t) he cared not for the vowes of former times; but cauÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe to be crowned king.

And Å¿o well was hee inÅ¿tructed by the former examples of his Progenitors; that, as they did, Å¿o did hee endeuour (by WiÅ¿dome, and by Policie) to lay a Å¿ure Foundation to his EÅ¿tate. And becauÅ¿e Riches are the Synewes and the Strength of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Kings;Good policie. hee therefore (to enrich himÅ¿elfe) Å¿eized vpon the TreaÅ¿ure of his vncle,The Kings liberalitie. the laÅ¿t deceaÅ¿ed King: Which hee cloÅ¿ed not vp in CheÅ¿ts, or in Bagges, as idle Archers doe their Arrowes in their Quiuers, when (for their honeÅ¿t recreation) they Å¿hould Å¿hoote: but with a large and an open hand hee bountifully diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of them among Å¿uch, as eyther by Armes, or by CounÅ¿ell, were beÅ¿t likely to Å¿tand him in the greateÅ¿t Å¿tead. He alÅ¿o created Å¿undrie Noblemen: and dignified manie others with the honourable Title of Knighthood; whoÅ¿e loue by thoÅ¿e meanes he procured. And (becauÅ¿e benefits receiued doe more pleaÅ¿e the vulgar and common Å¿ort of People, than Right or ReaÅ¿on can doe) he therefore releaÅ¿ed vnto them the Dane-gelt, and all other extraordinarie Burthens and Exactions whatÅ¿oeuer: cauÅ¿ing a large Charter thereof, and of the mitigation of the Seueritie and Penalties of Å¿undrie Lawes, to be made; and bound himÅ¿elfe by a Å¿olemne Oath to keepe and to obÅ¿erue the Å¿ame. He alÅ¿o renounced the future SeiÅ¿ures of all EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Dignities and Promotions,Priuiledges graunted to the Clergie. when they Å¿hould become vacant. Hee gaue to the Church and Church-men Å¿uch gracefull and profitable Priuiledges and Immunities as they would demaund. And (among other things) he freely exempted them from the authoritie of the Temporall MagiÅ¿trate, for all offences whatÅ¿oeuer; except the Ordinarie Å¿hould bee pleaÅ¿ed, that hee Å¿hould deale therewith. Finally, he endeuoured to doe all things juÅ¿tly, and pleaÅ¿ing vnto all.CaÅ¿tles and FortreÅ¿Å¿es erected. To preuent Å¿uddaine Eruptions, Rebellions, and IncurÅ¿ions, tending to the generall diÅ¿turbance of the common Peace; by hauing manie Å¿trong and fortified places for good defence: himÅ¿elfe erected manie Forts, FortreÅ¿Å¿es, Bulwarkes, and CaÅ¿tles; and licenced his Nobles, and his Gentrie, and Clergie, to doe the like. He gaue vnto Dauid the King of Scots, and vncle to Mauld the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e (becauÅ¿e hee Å¿hould not Å¿econd her in her demaunds,The Scots flattered by the King. or warlike attempts) the whole Prouince of Cumberland; and created his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne Henrie Earle of Huntingdon. Yet notwithÅ¿tanding, not long after (in her quarrell) hee entred into the Northren parts of this Kingdome;The King of Scots ouerthrowne by the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke. which hee tormented with fire and Å¿word. But in the end he was encountred by ThurÅ¿ton, then ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke; who compelled him (being purÅ¿ued with vnÅ¿peakable dangers) to flye into Scotland;
and to leaue behinde him, dead vpon the ground, more than tenne thouÅ¿and men of his Armie.

In the Å¿ixt yeare of his Raigne, Mauld the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e,Mauld the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e landeth in England. being accompanied with her baÅ¿e brother, Robert, Earle of Glocester, landed with an armie in England; and was quickly Å¿trengthened and emboldened in her EnterpriÅ¿e by the plentifull acceÅ¿Å¿e of manie of the EngliÅ¿h, and of Raynulph Earle of CheÅ¿ter, with a luÅ¿tie crew of bold and forward Welchmen. Hereupon the King (impoÅ¿ing no confidence in delay; but Experience inÅ¿tructing him, that aduiÅ¿ed Expedition is the chiefeÅ¿t enabler of good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e) leuied a Å¿trong armie; and marched with good reÅ¿olution againÅ¿t the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, and her Forces: who greeted him with Å¿uch MuÅ¿icke as her warlike Troupes did gallantly preÅ¿ent. So that a cruell and a bloudie Battaile (with equall hopes) for manie houres was fought betweene them. But at length,King Stephen ouerthrowne. the Kings common Souldiors (Å¿triuing faintly, and, as cowards, rather endeuouring to Å¿aue themÅ¿elues by flight, than manfully to defend their King) did baÅ¿ely leaue the King: who, with his Nobles and Gentrie, Å¿corning to turne their backes, maintained their part, with as much courage as manhood could affoord;King Stephen taken priÅ¿oner. till (in the end) the King was taken, and committed to the CaÅ¿tle of BriÅ¿toll: where hee remayned a priÅ¿oner about the Å¿pace of three moneths; and was at the laÅ¿t deliuered,King Stephen is Å¿et at libertie. to free the Earle of GloceÅ¿ter, who had beene taken, and was impriÅ¿oned by the Queene.

After this victorie thus obtained, the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e (with manie honourable Triumphs and Solemnities) was receiued into the Cities of Circester, Oxford, Winchester, and London. The Londoners attempt to Å¿urprize the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e But the Londoners deÅ¿iring the ReÅ¿titution of King Edwards Lawes, and not obtaining their requeÅ¿t) conÅ¿ulted to Å¿urprize the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, and to deliuer her vnto the King. By meanes whereof, good counÅ¿ell aduiÅ¿ed her to flye: which Å¿uddainely Å¿he did; and came vnto Oxford: Where (within few dayes, and vnexpectedly) Å¿hee was enuironed with a Å¿trong Siege: So that deÅ¿paire of good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e dis-heartening her,The EmpreÅ¿Å¿e beÅ¿ieged in Oxford. and teaching her a readie meanes for her eÅ¿cape; taking the benefit of the Snow (which at that time lay thicke vpon the ground) Å¿he, with her chiefeÅ¿t complices, apparrelling themÅ¿elues in white linnen, Å¿ecretly iÅ¿Å¿ued forth;A politike flight. and poÅ¿ting with all Å¿peede towards the Sea, they embarked themÅ¿elues, and Å¿ayled into Normandie.

Manie yeares together, after theÅ¿e turmoyles, this Realme enjoyed a bleÅ¿Å¿ed Peace: And in the Å¿euenteenth yeare of this Kings
Raigne died the moÅ¿t valorous and hardie knight Raynulph Earle of CheÅ¿ter: Henry Short-Mantel heire apparant to the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e. and Å¿o did Geoffrey Plantagenet, husband to the EmpreÅ¿Å¿e. And Henrie, Å¿urnamed Short-Mantle, her eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, tooke to wife Elianor, the daughter and heire of the Earle of Poytou: which Elianor not long before (for neereneÅ¿Å¿e in bloud, and after Å¿he had borne him two daughters) was diuorced from Lewis the Å¿euenth, then King of France. So that Prince Henrie was now Duke of Normandie, in the right of his Mother; Earle of Angeou by deÅ¿cent from his Father; and Earle of Poytou in the right of his wife: by whome (not long after) he alÅ¿o had the Earledome of TholouÅ¿e.

This worthie Prince (by manie of his friends and valiant men of Warre, who longed to haue employment in Å¿o faire a journey) was incited to leuie a Å¿trong armie, and to tranÅ¿port them into England; and by their helpe, and the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of other wel-willers, to attempt the recouerie of his Right: and the rather, for that king Stephen, and EuÅ¿tace his onely Å¿onne, did now begin to warre vpon manie of thoÅ¿e, who held their CaÅ¿tles for the Prince his vÅ¿e. His Å¿trong Expectation, and hope to be enthroned in this Kingdome, through the fauour of diuers Lords and Commons of this Realme; eaÅ¿ily perÅ¿uaded him to lend a liÅ¿tening eare to their whiÅ¿perings: So that to giue vnto them good content, and to forward the attayning of his owne deÅ¿ires,Henry Short-Mantel inuadeth England. hee rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong power of willing and able men of Warre. Which (beeing brauely conducted by noble Captaines, well skilled in thoÅ¿e Affaires) arriued Å¿afely in England: where King Stephen and his Å¿onne diÅ¿dained to be idle; for they had prouided with an equall Å¿trength to encounter him.

Both armies had daily newes the one from the other: they threatned much, did Å¿omewhat, but it was but little: Yet in thoÅ¿e Expeditions, EuÅ¿tace the kings Å¿onne by miÅ¿aduenture was vnfortunately drowned;Prince EuÅ¿tace drowned which ouercame the king with infinite paÅ¿Å¿ions of Å¿orrow and extreame griefe. But it made a quiet end of this quarrell. For now, the king (not hauing anie Å¿onne which might Å¿ucceed him) was well pleaÅ¿ed to lend a liÅ¿tening eare to the faire proffer of a friendly Peace.The quarrell is comp â¢ unded & ended. And thereupon hee adopted Prince Henrie for his Sonne; proclaymed him to bee the Heire apparant of his Crowne; gaue him manie honourable and kingly Gifts; aÅ¿Å¿ured him of his vnchangeable loue and friendÅ¿hip.

And by theÅ¿e meanes all Armes were caÅ¿t aÅ¿ide, and Peace
triumphed; hauing gotten a certaine and a Å¿ure Victorie with few blowes. And the Prince, with his followers, returned into Normandie: where they were with much honour and incredible joy receiued.

And the next yeare after, king Stephen died,
King Stephen dieth.
The Saxons bloud reÅ¿tored to the Crowne of England. See the deÅ¿cent in the Raigne of King Henrie the firÅ¿t. when hee had raigned almoÅ¿t nineteene yeares; and lyeth buried in the Abbey of FeuerÅ¿ham in Kent, which himÅ¿elfe had founded. And by the happie SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of this Henrie, the Saxon Bloud was againe reÅ¿tored vnto the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE SECOND.
div.p:
WHEN Henrie was returned into Normandie; the French King (fearing leaÅ¿t Time, and his Fortunes, would make him too puiÅ¿Å¿ant and too great for his bordering Neighbours; and intending to deale roughly with him, before he Å¿hould be the abÅ¿olute MaÅ¿ter and Commander of his owne Å¿trength) very iniuriouÅ¿ly Å¿eized vpon diuers of his FortreÅ¿Å¿es and CaÅ¿tles in Normandie, and elÅ¿ewhere, which (queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e) ought to haue beene Å¿ubiect to his Gouernment. But Henrie (being wiÅ¿e,Henry Short-Mantels valour and courage. and full of courage and heroicall Magnimitie; and foreÅ¿eeing, that if hee Å¿hould Å¿hrinke as a coward, and not make himÅ¿elfe knowne by his valour to the world, when the wrongs which were done vnto him were too apparant) rayÅ¿ed a faire Armie: and (for the regayning of one of thoÅ¿e his CaÅ¿tles) he girded it round about with a Å¿trong Siege. And whileÅ¿t he was thus employed to winne his right,He Å¿ayleth Å¿peedily into England: but firÅ¿t winneth the CaÅ¿tle which he had beÅ¿ieged. the newes of King Stephens death came freÅ¿hly vnto his eares. And (to preuent Å¿uch vÅ¿urpation, as oftentimes, in the abÅ¿ence of the lawfull Kings, depriueth them of their Crownes) he was by his neereÅ¿t and deareÅ¿t friends aduiÅ¿ed to abandon the Siege; and, without tarrying, to tranÅ¿port
himÅ¿elfe into England. But his anÅ¿were was full of diÅ¿cretion and true valour to this effect:A reÅ¿olute Å¿peech. The Kingdome of England (quoth hee) Å¿hall henceforth be at my commaund, in deÅ¿pight of thoÅ¿e who dare to croÅ¿Å¿e mee moÅ¿t: And Å¿o Å¿hall theÅ¿e intruding Frenchmen ere I goe hence.

This ReÅ¿olution redoubled his honour among his friends; and Å¿o it did among his enemies. Strangers baniÅ¿hed: and the cauÅ¿e whyHee alÅ¿o baniÅ¿hed the greateÅ¿t part of Strangers, who (in thoÅ¿e dayes) by multitudes flocked hither; and by their extraordinarie Sparing, and painefull InduÅ¿trie, procured to themÅ¿elues much Wealth, and beggered Å¿uch as were Natiues borne.

But Thomas Becket (falling into the relapÅ¿e of his former follie) did not onely refuÅ¿e to doe the like,Becket again withÅ¿tandeth thoÅ¿e Lawes. but expreÅ¿Å¿ed great Repentance for the former Oath which he had taken. The Pope not onely abÅ¿olued him of that Oath, and enioyned him to Å¿ome priuate Penance: but hee alÅ¿o required him, without yeelding, Å¿toutly to perÅ¿iÅ¿t (with a Å¿trong ReÅ¿olution) in his opinion.

Hereupon the kings anger towards Becket daily encreaÅ¿ed more and more. And when this newes from Rome was diuulged,

The Kings anger againÅ¿t Becket.But when the King perceiued into what corner the winde did blow, and that the Pope had filled Becket with the blaÅ¿ts of pride and vaine-glorie: he (being more and more exaÅ¿perated) Å¿ent vnto the Å¿aid Abbot, and required him to turne Becket out of his houÅ¿e, or otherwiÅ¿e he proteÅ¿ted, he would not leaue one Monke of his Order in all France.

The King Å¿ayleth into France. He conferreth with Becket. His offer to Becket.King Henrie (deÅ¿iring to Å¿ee an end of theÅ¿e troubles, if by any meanes conueniently hee might) vpon the Å¿uddaine Å¿ailed into France.
