And becauÅ¿e Å¿hee was euerie way vertuous, diÅ¿creete, and wiÅ¿e;Queene Elianor is made Regent of England. hee committed the whole Gouernment of this Realme, in his abÅ¿ence, to her care. And (becauÅ¿e her owne Experience had informed her, what anguiÅ¿h and what Å¿orrow poore helpeleÅ¿Å¿e Captiues did endure) Å¿hee Å¿et at libertie all Å¿uch as were impriÅ¿oned for ordinarie offences,Non ignara ma â¢ i, miÅ¿eris Å¿uccur â¢ ete diÅ¿cit. or for Å¿mall Debts, which her Å¿elfe did pay: and adminiÅ¿tred the Common-weales affaires with great Moderation, Integritie, and IuÅ¿tice, vntill her Å¿onne the king came home, and was with all Solemnitie and Å¿trange Triumphs annointed and crowned king.

This king (imitating the milde diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of his mother; and
commiÅ¿erating the troubles of Å¿uch as were afflicted) freed out of euerie PriÅ¿on all Å¿uch as were his Debtors,A mercifull King. or were enthralled for anie tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion which concerned himÅ¿elfe; and whome, without injuÅ¿tice done to others, he might acquite. And in the whole courÅ¿e of his Gouernment he Å¿o prouided, that IuÅ¿tice with Mercie Å¿hould be extended vnto all.

Too much honor elateth.He heaped manie Honors and profitable Promotions vpon his brother Iohn, whome he created Earle of Lancaster, and gaue vnto him the Prouinces of Nottingham, DeuonÅ¿hire, and Cornwall: and married him to the Å¿ole and onely Daughter and Heire of the Earle of GloceÅ¿ter; from whome he receiued the LordÅ¿hip of that Countrey.

TheÅ¿e great and kind fauors required, that he Å¿hould be thankfull. But oftentimes it happeneth, that as the addition of too much Oyle extinguiÅ¿heth the Lampe, which otherwiÅ¿e would burne, and yeeld her light; and as the ouer-abundance of too much water, falling vpon a Wheele, maketh it the leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿eruiceable for the vÅ¿e to which it is employed: So the conferring of too much Honor, and of too manie Titles of Dignitie, vpon Å¿uch as are not capable of them all, altereth and changeth their milde and gentle diÅ¿poÅ¿itions, and maketh them altogether vnthankefull for thoÅ¿e benefits which they haue receiued. And oftentimes they are incited and prouoked thereby to affect things of higher conÅ¿equence and moment than are fitting; and to conjecture, that the greateÅ¿t fortunes are moÅ¿t agreeable to their EÅ¿tates. So that they neuer ceaÅ¿e to attempt great things: which in the end will rather be hurtfull to them, than doe them anie good.

An vnthankfull brother.This proued true betwixt the king and his brother Iohn. For when the king had powred on him plentifull Å¿howers of his bountie and great abundance; and had aduanced him in Honor, and in EÅ¿tate, aboue all others: his thoughts mounted aboue the Moone, and made him vnnaturally and vnthankfully to affect the Crowne; and to boaÅ¿t, That his endowments were Å¿ufficient, and fitting for a king. And though he wanted oportunitie, yet he reÅ¿olued to puÅ¿h hard for the Crowne, if Time and Fortune would preÅ¿ent it to him.

This king (for his inuincible valour, and haughtie courage) was eÅ¿teemed to be almoÅ¿t matchleÅ¿Å¿e in the ChriÅ¿tian world: Å¿o that he was Å¿urnamed Cuer de Lyon, Cuer de Lyon. or the Lyons Heart. And (to Å¿ay the truth) he was Å¿uch a one, as (vpon good aduice and counÅ¿ell) dared to attempt anie thing, if it were honourable to be atchieued, and poÅ¿Å¿ible to be done.

His fathers TreaÅ¿ure enriched him exceedingly with great Å¿tore of Siluer and of Gold. And Å¿uch was his contempt of Riches,A bountifull King. and Å¿uch was his Bountie to Å¿uch, as either deÅ¿erued well, or left in him anie impreÅ¿Å¿ion of Noble worth, that he beÅ¿towed on them great Gifts with Å¿uch alacritie and cheerefulneÅ¿Å¿e, that in Å¿hort time he vnbowelled all his Bagges and CheÅ¿ts; little foreÅ¿eeing, that future BuÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es might require the expence of more than the great Plentie which was left vnto him: and that (when he wanted) he Å¿hould be enforced to make hard Å¿hift to relieue himÅ¿elfe.

In the beginning of his Raigne,The King reÅ¿olueth to warre in the Holy Land vpon the Popes motion the Pope Å¿ollicited him with Å¿trong perÅ¿waÅ¿ions, and manie promiÅ¿es of his BleÅ¿Å¿ings, to wage Warre in his owne perÅ¿on againÅ¿t the Turkes in the Holie Land; and to attempt the winning of IeruÅ¿alem from the Infidels and vnbeleeuing Men: who maliciouÅ¿ly oppoÅ¿ed themÅ¿elues againÅ¿t the Incarnation, PaÅ¿Å¿ion, and AÅ¿cenÅ¿ion of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us. Which journey he vndertooke, becauÅ¿e Frederick the Emperour,Frederick, Philip, Leopold. and Philip the Å¿econd, Å¿urnamed AuguÅ¿tus, king of France, Leopoldus then Archduke of AuÅ¿tria, and manie other ChriÅ¿tian Princes, had engaged themÅ¿elues (both with Men, Money, and all other ProuiÅ¿ions) to further thoÅ¿e Attempts. And thereupon he entred into Couenants with the king of France, and the reÅ¿t of that Vnion,Their Couenants and Agreements. That their generall meeting Å¿hould be in Sicilia: and that Å¿uch Wealth and Bootie, as GOD and good Fortune Å¿hould make them Owners of, Å¿hould equally be Å¿hared and diuided among them and theirs.

TheÅ¿e things being thus concluded (although the kings profuÅ¿e Expences, and great Gifts exceeding meaÅ¿ure, had made him bare and needie) yet would he not burthen his People with anie Taxe to Å¿upplie his wants.The King in his wants would not taxe his people. But rayÅ¿ing great Å¿ummes of Money out of his owne EÅ¿tate; among other things, he Å¿old his CaÅ¿tles of Barwick and of Rokesbrough to the king of Scots for tenne thouÅ¿and pounds: and the LordÅ¿hip and Earledome of Durham vnto Hugh then BiÅ¿hop of that See, for much money.He leuieth money of his owne State. He alÅ¿o enriched himÅ¿elfe with Siluer and with Gold, by the Sale of Å¿undrie Honors, LordÅ¿hips, Manors, Offices, Priuiledges, Royalties, and other things, vnto Å¿uch as parÅ¿imonie and Å¿paring had made Owners and PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors of great plentie; and did proteÅ¿t,His willingneÅ¿Å¿e to vndertake this voyage. That (for the performing of Å¿o great and honorable a Seruice) he was not vnwilling to Å¿ell his Citie of London, if anie were of abilitie to buy it, rather than he would be chargeable vnto others.

And thus the king hauing furniÅ¿hed himÅ¿elfe with all prouiÅ¿ions fit and neceÅ¿Å¿arie for his journey; and hauing leuied a Å¿trong Armie,
in which were manie Lords,William Longchamp made Regent of England. Knights, and Gentlemen, whoÅ¿e reÅ¿olutions encreaÅ¿ed his hopes of good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e: he committed the principall Gouernment of his Kingdome vnto William Longchampe, then BiÅ¿hop of Ely; who (not long after) was made the Popes Legate.The King departeth. And then he Å¿ayled with his whole Armie to the IÅ¿le of Cyprus: which (with braue courage) after manie hot and dangerous Encounters, hee wonne; and Å¿old the Å¿ame to the Knights Templars for thirtie thouÅ¿and Marks.He winnes Cyprus: and Å¿ells it for 30000 marks

And from thence (according to his former appointment) he tranÅ¿ported his Armie into Sicilia; where he met with Philip the French king: and vpon their firÅ¿t enter-view, they pleaÅ¿ed each other with manie paÅ¿Å¿ages of familiaritie and of loue. But this faire Sunne-Å¿hine was quickly vayled and couered with a cloud of skorne and diÅ¿contentment.A iarre betweene the King and Philip King of France. For when the French king was denyed to haue anie part or Å¿hare with king Richard in his atchieuement of the IÅ¿le of Cyprus (both becauÅ¿e hee was abÅ¿ent when it was taken; and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e it was affirmed by king Richard, That their Couenant extended onely to Å¿uch things, as they Å¿hould winne and gayne in the Holie Land) he waxed angrie, and vÅ¿ed manie high and diÅ¿dainefull tearmes, and made publike Å¿hew of inward diÅ¿content.King Richard neglected the French Kings anger. All which king Richard did Å¿et at nought; and told him to his face, That doe what he dared, he Å¿hould not be a partner in that Bootie.

It Å¿tood not with king Philips honour, to waxe cold Å¿o Å¿oone in this great Enterprize, whereon the eyes of all the ChriÅ¿tian World were fixed; and daÅ¿tardly to returne home. But howÅ¿oeuer hee had diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of himÅ¿elfe, and of Å¿uch Forces as hee commanded, yet king Richard was reÅ¿olued to goe forth; Å¿o that (NeceÅ¿Å¿itie enforcing them to Å¿ome agreement) they proceeded in their Iourney.The ChriÅ¿tian Princes doe preuaile. In which, they all, and their Confederates, performed manie honourable and wonderfull deedes of Armes; terrifying and daily diminiÅ¿hing the Turkes Numbers and Forces with continuall Å¿laughters, and giuing them but little leyÅ¿ure, or courage to reÅ¿iÅ¿t.

And (among manie other Å¿trong Townes, Forts, CaÅ¿tles, and GarriÅ¿ons of great Å¿trength and importance, which they conquered) they wonne (after a long and a Å¿harpe Siege) by maine Batteries and reÅ¿olute AÅ¿Å¿aults,Acon w â¢ on. the Å¿toutly defended Citie of Acon: Vpon the walls whereof a forward knight aduanced the Banner and the Colours of Leopold the Archduke of Austria. King Richard trampleth on Leopolds colours. But king Richard, skorning that too much Grace and Honour Å¿hould be done vnto the Duke, and his owne deÅ¿erts be thereby
blemiÅ¿hed, he hauing firÅ¿t of all entred into the Citie, ranne vp vnto the Wall; plucked downe that Banner, and thoÅ¿e colours; and trampled them with his feete: Wherat the French King was much diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed, and gaue his tongue libertie to Å¿peake great things.The French King is angrie. But King Richard (neglecting his frownes; and laughing at his diÅ¿content) affirmed, that in Å¿o doing hee had onely righted himÅ¿elfe of thoÅ¿e Iniuries which were done to him: And that, if any were diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to looke Å¿ower thereat, hee was careleÅ¿Å¿e of his anger,King Richards courage. and in the field would be ready to maintaine his doings againÅ¿t any.

The French King Å¿welling at the heart, to Å¿ee King Richard thus careleÅ¿Å¿e, reÅ¿olute, and bold:The forces of the Empire and of the French King and of Leopold, do leaue K. Richard. And Å¿eeming to diÅ¿truÅ¿t leaÅ¿t by Å¿ome Å¿ecret league, or other compact, betwixt King Richard and the Turkes, Å¿ome danger might aÅ¿Å¿aile him and his followers, Hee tooke an vnkind leaue, and carying away with him all Å¿uch troupes as belonged to the Emperour, to Leopold, and to himÅ¿elfe, hee left the King of England, and returned home.

This his departure diÅ¿comforted not King Richard: But with his owne Souldiours,King Richard preuaileth. and with the forces of Å¿ome other ChriÅ¿tian Princes, who Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elues to his direction and Gouernement, hee perÅ¿iÅ¿ted in thoÅ¿e Warres, and proÅ¿ecuted his attempts with Å¿uch conÅ¿tancie, and heroicall magnanimitie, that he preuailed, and became Victorious, when the greateÅ¿t dangers aÅ¿Å¿aulted him moÅ¿t to make him feare. And (among many other things which boldly he attempted) hee returned vnto the Ile of Cyprus; He winneth Cyprus again and by force hee valiantly wonne it from the Knights Templers, vnto whom he had formerly Å¿old it, and then exchanged it for the Citie of IeruÅ¿alem, with Guy of LeÅ¿ingham the laÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian King; who held, and did poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e it. By meanes whereof,He is Å¿tiled King of IaeruÅ¿alem. King Richard was Å¿tiled King of IeruÅ¿alem; and Å¿o were many of his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ours long after.

Thus while he became victorious,England is badly Gouerned. and daily triumphed ouer the Turkes miÅ¿eries; his Kingdome of England was badly Gouerned at home by the BiÅ¿hop of Ely; to whom hee had committed the charge thereof. For hee (being the Grand-child of a Ploughman, and the Å¿onne of a Cow-heard in the North: AÅ¿perius nihil eÅ¿t humili. quam Å¿urgere in altuÌ. and being aduanced to that BiÅ¿hoppricke, and made Lord Chancellour of England; Legate to the Pope; and Protector of all this Realme) tyrannized, as himÅ¿elfe liÅ¿ted, ouer all Å¿ortes of people; ExerciÅ¿ed on them Å¿trange and vnuÅ¿uall oppreÅ¿Å¿ions, both in the Church,A begger on horÅ¿e-backe will ride. and alÅ¿o in the Common-weale; and was Å¿o infinitely ambitious and Å¿o proud, that he would neuer ride abroad for his paÅ¿time, and for his recreation, except hee were attended and waited on by a thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e, and
more; and was Å¿erued by the Å¿onnes of the greateÅ¿t Nobles in this Land, vnto whom he gaue in marriage, with Å¿ome portions, diuers of his baÅ¿e and ruÅ¿ticke kinne.The ambitious BiÅ¿hops fall. But at length he grew to bee Å¿o contemptible, lothÅ¿ome and vile, in all the peoples eyes, that (fearing what would be the Å¿equell of his vnlimited inÅ¿olencie and pride,) He reÅ¿olued to forÅ¿ake this Kingdome. And comming (for that purpoÅ¿e) into Douer, He diÅ¿guiÅ¿eth himÅ¿elfe, and is dragged on the Sands. diÅ¿guiÅ¿ed in the habit of a woman, and hauing vnder his arme a piece of Country-cloth, which hee offered to the Å¿ale, hee was deÅ¿cried and diÅ¿couered, and by the common people was furiouÅ¿ly and Å¿hamefully dragged and drawne vpon the Sands, and was afterward Å¿ent vnto London: where the Lords and greateÅ¿t Nobles committed him to the Tower; in which he remained vntill the kings returne,He is reÅ¿tored. and then he was reÅ¿tored both to his libertie and Offices. But Å¿hortly after, as he trauelled towards Rome, he died;He dieth. whereat much joy was conceiued generally by the EngliÅ¿hmen.

Of theÅ¿e Affaires, and of his euill Gouernment, king Richard was informed in the Holie Land: as alÅ¿o of the great diÅ¿contentment of his brother Iohn, The cauÅ¿es which haÅ¿tened king Richards returne. for that the BiÅ¿hop of Ely, and not himÅ¿elfe, was (in the kings abÅ¿ence) made Gouernor of this kingdome: and how that he had Å¿eized manie of the kings Townes, Forts, and CaÅ¿tles, into his hands; and onely wanted the peoples fauour to make himÅ¿elfe a king.

He likewiÅ¿e was informed, what Sallyes, Inrodes, and InuaÅ¿ions, the French king (after his returne home) had made in Normandie, thereby to reuenge himÅ¿elfe of thoÅ¿e pretended iniuries and wrongs, which he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed he had receiued from king Richard in the Holie Land.

TheÅ¿e Tidings thus concurring, and the good deÅ¿ire which king Richard had to preuent the ruine of his owne EÅ¿tate; enforced him (when he poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed the greateÅ¿t hopes of ConqueÅ¿t) to conclude a peace with the Turks for three yeares.
King Richard Å¿aueth his life by Å¿wimming. He is taken priÅ¿oner, and Å¿old to the Emperour Henry the Å¿ixt.
He is ranÅ¿omed.
He reuengeth his iniuries vpon the French king. But in his returne, he was (by the violence of a raging Å¿torme) compelled after a dangerous Å¿hipwrack to Å¿aue his life by Swimming, neere vnto HiÅ¿tria; which lyeth betweene Aquileia and Venice: and comming to the Territories of Leopold in AuÅ¿tria, he was taken priÅ¿oner; and by him Å¿old to the Emperour Henrie the Å¿ixt, the Å¿onne of Frederick, for threeÅ¿core thouÅ¿and Marks; who (taking of him good Å¿ecuritie for his RanÅ¿ome, aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed vnto one hundred thouÅ¿and pounds) did Å¿et him at libertie: So that with Å¿peedie journeyes he poaÅ¿ted vntill be came into Normandie; where he rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong Armie, and marched furiouÅ¿ly into France, and reuenged himÅ¿elfe Å¿oundly of
all Å¿uch iniuries and wrongs, as in his abÅ¿ence were done vnto him by the French king. And then he reduced to his Å¿ubiection all Å¿uch Peeres in Normandie, as by the Frenchmen, in his abÅ¿ence, had beene taken from him.

Thus whileÅ¿t the King was buÅ¿ied abroad; his brother Iohn, Duke Iohn Å¿ubmitteth himÅ¿elfe to the King his brother, and is pardoned. Earle of LancaÅ¿ter, repaired to him, and not onely Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe to his grace and mercie, but voluntarily Å¿urrendred to him all Å¿uch Forts and CaÅ¿tles as he had Å¿eized into his hands: excuÅ¿ing himÅ¿elfe, as being prouoked and enforced to diÅ¿loyaltie by the extraordinarie pride and inÅ¿olent behauiour of William Longchampe BiÅ¿hop of Ely; who vnworthily had diÅ¿ordered the gouernment of the whole Realme. Vpon which Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, and his contrition for his offence, he obtained not onely the kings pardon, but alÅ¿o his eÅ¿peciall grace and fauour.

Then did they both come into England: He vÅ¿eth vniuÅ¿t means to pay his Debts and RanÅ¿ome. where the king (to make payment of his RanÅ¿ome) ranÅ¿acked the TreaÅ¿ures of diuers Religious HouÅ¿es, and grieuouÅ¿ly taxed the People; and Å¿ummoned his High Court of Parliament, in which he cauÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe to be againe crowned King.He is crowned anew. And to augment his owne EÅ¿tate, hee reÅ¿umed into his hands all Å¿uch Honors, LordÅ¿hips, Manors, CaÅ¿tles, Offices, and Priuiledges,He reÅ¿umeth the Lands which he Å¿old, and payes nothing for them. as he had formerly Å¿old to his owne Å¿ubjects for his Å¿upplyes; and enforced the Buyers to content themÅ¿elues with Å¿uch profits thereof, as they had taken. Then foureÅ¿core thouÅ¿and pounds of his RanÅ¿ome were payd:Leopold is accuÅ¿ed, and releaÅ¿eth part of the Kings RanÅ¿ome. but the reÅ¿idue was diÅ¿charged by Leopold; who was accurÅ¿ed by Pope Innocent the third, for that hee had iniuriouÅ¿ly made king Richard a priÅ¿oner, in his returne from his Warres in the Holie Land.

Then the king rayÅ¿ed a new Armie, and tranÅ¿ported it into France; and from that time forward he ceaÅ¿ed not (with variable Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e) to warre with the French king: vntill at length taking a priuate view of the beÅ¿ieged CaÅ¿tle of Chalons, neere to Lymoys, The King warreth in France. he was deÅ¿cried by a common Å¿ouldior; who Å¿o grieuouÅ¿ly wounded him with an arrow, that within three dayes after he died, when he had raigned almoÅ¿t nine yeares; and was buried at Founteuerard in France at his fathers feet.He is Å¿laine.

After hee was wounded, as is before mentioned, hee wonne the CaÅ¿tle by terrible aÅ¿Å¿aults, and cauÅ¿ed all Å¿uch as he found therein to be Å¿laine; except the malefactor: who being demanded by him how he dared to Å¿hoot vnto the perÅ¿on of a king, made anÅ¿were, That in thoÅ¿e Warres he had loÅ¿t his father, and his brother,Vltio Diuina. and that he was exceeding glad that fortune had Å¿o aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted him in his reuenge. Then when he expected nothing but a preÅ¿ent terrible
death,The King pardoneth him who Å¿lew him. the king gaue him his pardon; and cauÅ¿ed him to be Å¿afely conducted out of his Armie.

In the beginning of this Kings Raigne, certaine Out-lawes, to the number of one hundred and more, being reÅ¿olued and deÅ¿perat men (whoÅ¿e chiefeÅ¿t leaders were named Robin Hood and Little Iohn) robbed and Å¿poyled in diuers places of this Land.Robin Hood and Little Iohn. They neither hurted, nor much wronged anie, except they would runne themÅ¿elues into danger by reÅ¿iÅ¿tance. They attempted againÅ¿t none,HoneÅ¿t Theeues. but againÅ¿t Å¿uch, as being rich, gayned by vÅ¿urie; or gaue no entertainement by good HoÅ¿pitalitie to their Neighbours, and to the poore. They Å¿pared all women, and were bountifull benefactors to Å¿uch as Å¿tood in need. Thus they continued diuers moneths; vntill their chiefeÅ¿t Leader Robin Hood, by meanes of a Å¿harpe Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e (being let bloud, and being betrayed) bled himÅ¿elfe to death. And then the whole Rout of this theeuiÅ¿h Companie was diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, and the Malefactors Å¿ecretly repaired home to their owne houÅ¿es.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING IOHN.
div.p: IOHN PLANTAGENET (Earle of Lancaster in his owne Right, and Earle of GloceÅ¿ter in the right of his wife; and being the yongeÅ¿t Å¿onne of King Henrie the Å¿econd) Å¿ucceeded, and was crowned king: albeit that Arthur Plantagenet his nephew,Arthur Plantagenet was lawfull heire. and Å¿onne to Geoffrey his elder brother, was then liuing. The whole courÅ¿e of this Kings Gouernment was accompanied with continuall troubles: and his two PerÅ¿ecutors were Pope Innocent the third;The Kings two perÅ¿ecutors. and Philip the Å¿econd, then King of France.

The French King feared the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of Englands Å¿trength, and the proÅ¿peritie of this Kingdome was hurtfull vnto his eyes:The French king taketh part with Arthur againÅ¿t King Iohn. and glad he was, if (at anie time) the leaÅ¿t occaÅ¿ion would offer him Å¿ome Å¿eruice to further his deÅ¿ignes againÅ¿t King Iohn. For proofe hereof, he proteÅ¿ted a world of loue to the Å¿aid Arthur; informed him of his Title to the Crowne of England, and of his vndoubted right to the Duchies of Normandie, and of Britaine; animated him to rayÅ¿e his Å¿pirits, and to aduance his courage to winne them all. If he were deÅ¿titute of Friends, which might aduiÅ¿e and counÅ¿ell him; he and his Nobles would Å¿upplie that want: if he Å¿tood in need of Siluer and of Gold, to feede and to nouriÅ¿h the great bodie of that Warre; he Å¿hould be Å¿upplyed with Å¿ufficient Å¿tore:
And if he would haue valiant men to fight for him, and for thoÅ¿e his Rights, hee would Å¿upplie him with manie thouÅ¿ands, who Å¿hould aduenture to Å¿pend their beÅ¿t bloud in his Quarrels.

TheÅ¿e large and friendly proffers (which indeede proceeded rather from a jealouÅ¿ie which the French King had of himÅ¿elfe, by reaÅ¿on of King Iohns GreatneÅ¿Å¿e, than from anie inward affection or heartie loue which hee bare vnto Arthur, the lawfull and the rightfull Heire of this Crowne) and the longing deÅ¿ire which made this young Gallant hopefull of thoÅ¿e great atchieuements; perÅ¿uaded him verie eaÅ¿ily, not onely to accept of the French Kings friendÅ¿hip, but alÅ¿o to vÅ¿e his aide. So that partly by the helpe of the Normans, and partly by the French Kings meanes,Arthur Plantagenet leuieth an armie. hee leuied a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie; and wonne diuers places both of Worth and of Strength in Normandie. But the Kings Lieutenant, and his other Agents in that Duchie, defended themÅ¿elues valiantly, perÅ¿iÅ¿ted in their Duties, and fought it out diuers times;King Iohn goeth into Normandie with an Armie. vntill King Iohn himÅ¿elfe came into that Countrey with a Å¿trong Armie, and fought manie cruell Battailes with his Nephew.

But oftentimes it falleth out, that by Warre (which is the enemie of Peace) Peace it Å¿elfe is procured. For when thoÅ¿e two Princes had exchanged Å¿tore of blowes, and when their Armies had made hauocke each of other; and death had drenched her Å¿elfe in their bloud: they entred into certaine Capitulations for Peace;A peace is concluded. which, for a Å¿hort time, gaue them Å¿ome reÅ¿pit of breathing. But the Å¿ame was againe interrupted by Philip the French King;The peace is broken by the French kings meanes. who promiÅ¿ed Arthur a doubling of his Å¿trength, and fed him with much aÅ¿Å¿urance of proÅ¿perous Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e; and made him confident to renew thoÅ¿e Warres. And hereupon the French King carried a faire Armie into Normandie; with which hee Å¿poyled, ranÅ¿acked, and depopulated manie places in that Duchie.

But King Iohn (who wanted nothing but money to encounter with Å¿o peruerÅ¿e an enemie) was warned by his Lords, Gentlemen, and the inferiour Å¿ort of his common people, That Å¿hame would wait vpon him for his neglect, in Å¿uffering his Honour to be trampled on, and his Territories in Å¿uch Å¿ort, without blowes, to be taken from him. And (to whet the dull edge of his courage,The EngliÅ¿hmens forwardneÅ¿Å¿e to buckle with the French. deiected by reaÅ¿on of his wants) they voluntarily and freely granted him a large Taxe to Å¿upport his neceÅ¿Å¿itie: and euerie luÅ¿tie Ladde boldly proffered his Å¿eruice, to buckle Å¿trongly with the French.

By theÅ¿e meanes King Iohn was quickly furniÅ¿hed and Å¿trengthened both with Money and with Men;King Iohn paÅ¿Å¿eth into N â¢ rmandie the Å¿econd time with an Armie. and with a Å¿trong Armie he landed in the Duchie of Normandie: where his numbers were euerie day augmented, by the repaire of manie thouÅ¿ands, who were well appointed, and did reÅ¿olue with him to expect the Å¿ame lot and the Å¿ame fortune. And not long after, the two Armies met, and fought together with Å¿uch deÅ¿perate boldneÅ¿Å¿e,The two Armies fight. that each of them tooke pleaÅ¿ure to giue blowes, wounds, death. Each of them rejoyced in the ruine of the other; and thoÅ¿e Å¿olemne Å¿pectacles of Å¿orrow which would haue made others Å¿ad, gaue them occaÅ¿ion of much mirth.

But things which are violent cannot long endure. This fearefull Å¿torme muÅ¿t bee changed into a pleaÅ¿ant calme.The Frenchmen flye. And Å¿o it was. For the Frenchmen were diÅ¿couraged, and fled; and Arthur, the Kings Nephew, and the rightfull Heire vnto his Crowne,Arthur is Å¿ent priÅ¿oner to Roan. He is drowned. This Warre ended. was taken priÅ¿oner, and Å¿ent to the CaÅ¿tle of Roan: where (leaping from the walls with an intent to eÅ¿cape) he was drowned in the Ditch. And thus ended his Life, his Title, and thoÅ¿e Warres.

But the next yeare following, the French King himÅ¿elfe, pretending Title to the Å¿aid Duchie of Normandie, rayÅ¿ed an exceeding great power; and Å¿o Å¿odainely, and with Å¿uch furie,The French King Å¿odenly w â¢â¢â¢ eth all Normandie. did inuade it, that (wanting preÅ¿ent meanes of reÅ¿iÅ¿tance) the whole Duchie (to preuent vtter deÅ¿olation and ruine) yeelded, and Å¿ubiected it Å¿elfe to the French king.

But in the meane time a new SchiÅ¿me or Faction did appeare. But the Pope (imitating the proud example of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, who coueted to Å¿wimme againÅ¿t the Streame, and Å¿eldome, or neuer, granted anie kings requeÅ¿t, leaÅ¿t they Å¿hould in Å¿ome Å¿ort be thought to be yeelding) neglected the kings entreatie, and confirmed him that was choÅ¿en firÅ¿t. At length, this queÅ¿tion and this doubt was controuerted and diÅ¿puted on in Rome: and thereupon, the Pope (making a colourable Å¿hew to content the King, to pleaÅ¿e the Monkes, and to end this SchiÅ¿me; but indeede to preferre Stephen Langton, the Cardinall of ChriÅ¿ogone, to that Dignitie) aduiÅ¿ed the Å¿aid Monkes to elect the Å¿aid Stephen.

Stephen Langton is choÅ¿en ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie on the Popes motion, and againÅ¿t the commandement of the King.The King perceiuing well what was intended and meant thereby; required the Å¿aid Monkes not to proceed to the Å¿aid Election, nor to deale anie further in that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. This later choice Å¿o Å¿harpely exaÅ¿perated the king, that by his Letters to the Pope he proteÅ¿ted plainely, That from thenceforth he would take a Å¿trict account of all Å¿uch of his Å¿ubjects whatÅ¿oeuer, as for anie matters concerning Right, or IuÅ¿tice, Å¿hould be gadding vnto Rome. And did alledge, That he had BiÅ¿hops, Prelates, Nobles, and MagiÅ¿trates of his owne, who could and Å¿hould (according to the Lawes and CuÅ¿tomes of his Kingdome) decide and determine all ControuerÅ¿ies and Doubts, which Å¿hould ariÅ¿e either in the Church, or in the Commonweale. The Pope (according to his cuÅ¿tome and faÅ¿hion) not onely
anÅ¿wered prowdly,The Popes prowd and peremptorie anÅ¿wer. Foure BiÅ¿hops authorized to interdict the King. That the Election of the Cardinall Å¿hould Å¿tand: but required the King, to giue him the quiet poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his See; to recall Å¿uch Monks from baniÅ¿hment as he had exild; and to reÅ¿tore to them their goods, on which hee had Å¿eized by reaÅ¿on of their laÅ¿t choice: and did authorize foure BiÅ¿hops within this Land, to interdict and to curÅ¿e the King, and his Realme, if hee refuÅ¿ed to doe as by the Pope he was enioyned.

The King (perceiuing that thoÅ¿e foure BiÅ¿hops were much elated by reaÅ¿on of their new authoritie: and that they thought the time to be long, ere the King had replied and Å¿ignified his intent and reÅ¿olution) Å¿eized vpon their lands and goods;The King Å¿eizeth on the foure BiÅ¿hops lands and goods. and did proclaime, That he reÅ¿olued to take the like courÅ¿e with all Å¿uch, as receiued any Promotions, InueÅ¿titures, or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical degrees, from the Å¿aid Cardinall; or went vnto Rome vpon any occaÅ¿ion without his licenÅ¿e, or did appeale for any cauÅ¿e thither; or did attempt to put in execution any commaund from the Pope, within his Kingdome.

The Pope (being aduertiÅ¿ed hereof) Å¿ent into England his two Legats, Pandulphus and Durant (men of prowd Å¿pirits, and prone to put in practiÅ¿e al things as they Å¿hould be required) TheÅ¿e two perÅ¿waded the King to be reconciled to Stephen Langton; The Popes Legats curÅ¿e the King and his ayders. to the foure BiÅ¿hops; and to the Prior and the Monks of his Couent of S. Austins; and to reÅ¿tore to them their Places, Lands, and Goods, that peace, and amitie, by meanes of his Å¿o doing, might be renewed betwixt the Pope and him. The King (fearing to be accurÅ¿ed, and being deÅ¿irous to preuent future inconueniences) yeelded, and promiÅ¿ed to perform all whatÅ¿oeuer was required, except it were to allow the Å¿aid Election of the Å¿aid Cardinall: and proteÅ¿ted faithfully, That if another might be choÅ¿en, hee then would with all Å¿peed and expedition, preferre him to Å¿ome other BiÅ¿hoprique, or better place of Dignitie within his Realme. But the two Legats (in Å¿teed of gratifying the Kings requeÅ¿t) pronounced the Popes curÅ¿e; not only againÅ¿t him, but alÅ¿o againÅ¿t all Å¿uch as gaue him attendance, or things neceÅ¿Å¿arie; or kept him company. They likewiÅ¿e abÅ¿olued all his Å¿ubiects from their oathes, dutie, and Å¿eruice towards him, and required all ChriÅ¿tian Princes to make warre vppon him, as vpon the arch and grand enemy of the Church of God.This Kingdom is giuen to the French King. The Pope alÅ¿o pronounced and publiÅ¿hed againÅ¿t him his Å¿entence of depriuation, and gaue his Crown and his Kingdom to Philip the French King, if by any Å¿ecret plot, or open violence and hoÅ¿tility, he could expell or murther him.

TheÅ¿e were the fruits of this vnholy holy Father, the Popes Religion
and Gouernment. And this vÅ¿urping arrogancie was a badge of his vnÅ¿ufferable pride: in that he preÅ¿umed to do what no earthly creature can do, nor what a ChriÅ¿tian ought to attempt to do, againÅ¿t the Annointed of God; and againÅ¿t Å¿uch a one, as the Almightie hath placed in a Kingdom to gouerne and to rule his people.The King confronteth the Pope and his Legats. The King was not (as yet) terrified with this Thunder, but was in good hope that all thoÅ¿e Fulminations would quickly flaÅ¿h, and as Å¿oone vaniÅ¿h away, as the Lightning doth. And being thoroughly reÅ¿olued to confront the Pope, and his buÅ¿ie Legats, in contemning them and their greateÅ¿t power,He taketh an oath of his people. he took a Å¿olemne oath of his Subiects for his defence, and their faithfull Å¿eruice. And then with a Å¿trong Armie he entered into Scotland, againÅ¿t King Alexander the Å¿econd, becauÅ¿e he had receiued, Å¿upported, and maintained diuers of his Clergie,He carrieth an Armie into Scotland. and others: who (adhering to the Pope, and magnifying his vÅ¿urped authoritie within this kingdome) had forÅ¿aken the King; and (as Rebells, and Out-lawes) fled vnto him for Å¿uccour.The Scots Å¿ubmit themÅ¿elues. But the ScotiÅ¿h King (perceiuing that Fire and Sword gaped greedily to deuoure both him and his Countrie) Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe (with great humilitie and reuerence) to king Iohn; and without further trouble, hee was reconciled to his Grace and Fauour.

The French king, hoping and endeuoring to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe of the Popes gift (which was not his to giue) and gladding his owne heart that now he had gotten Å¿ome colour to warre in England vppon king Iohn; The French King prepareth for England. prouided a great Armie to inuade this Realme. But by the wiÅ¿edome, valour, and circumÅ¿pection of the king, and by Gods aÅ¿siÅ¿tance,Three hundred of his Ships are taken. three hundred of his Ships (being loaden with Corne, Victualls, and other requiÅ¿its for the warre) were Å¿urpriÅ¿ed, and by meanes thereof king Philip was at that time robbed of his vaine hope.

King Iohn fainteth.The Pope (notwithÅ¿tanding) ceaÅ¿ed not, but euer and anon hee accurÅ¿ed the king againe, and againe: inÅ¿omuch that he feared, leÅ¿t vtter ruine and his ouerthrow did attend him. Wherfore (Å¿uddenly,He asketh pardon, and reÅ¿igneth his kingdom to the Pope. without the conÅ¿ent of his Nobles, or aduice of his Councell of EÅ¿tate) vpon his knees, before Pandulphus the Legat, hee confeÅ¿Å¿ed his diÅ¿obedience to the Pope; craued Pardon; and (by a publique InÅ¿trument in writing vnder his hand and Å¿eale) hee reÅ¿igned his Crowne and his kingdom, to the Pope: which Pandulphus kept the Å¿pace of foure daies to the Popes vÅ¿e.The Pope regranteth. And then he gaue the Kingdome and the Crowne againe to King Iohn, and to his heires; reÅ¿eruing a Tenure thereof to the Church of Rome, with an yeerely tribute of one thouÅ¿and marks.

This baÅ¿e Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion and Å¿ubiection of his,The King is deÅ¿piÅ¿ed and forÅ¿aken. Å¿o alienated from him the deere affection of diuers of his Nobles, and men beÅ¿t skilled in Chiualrie, that they reuolted from his Å¿eruice, and fled vnto his enemie the French King; whoÅ¿e head was building of CaÅ¿tles in the aire, and who made new and large preparations and prouiÅ¿ions, to make Lewes his Å¿onne the Å¿ole King and Monarch of this Kingdome. And when all things were in a readineÅ¿Å¿e,Prince Lewes of France inuadeth. the young Prince with a Å¿trong Armie came into England, and was oftentimes encountred with Å¿harpe blowes, but yet he did much harme. And the Pope (being by his Legats informed in what caÅ¿e King Iohn and his Realme Å¿tood) required the French King, and Prince Lewes his Å¿onne, and all others who adhered to their part, of what eÅ¿tate or condition Å¿oeuer they were, forthwith to deÅ¿iÅ¿t and ceaÅ¿e from all hoÅ¿tilitie and warre; becauÅ¿e both King Iohn and his kingdome, were reconciled to his fauour, and to the Church, and the Crowne of his Realme was holden of the See of Rome: Contention between the Pope and the French King. So that (by conÅ¿cience, and by the lawes of God and of Men) he ought to be protected and defended by him, and by his authoritie and power. But the French refuÅ¿ed to obey; affirming, That no king (without the free conÅ¿ent of his Nobles, Prelats, & common people) could giue vnto any other his kingdom, nor the protection of his Subiects, which were committed to him by God; and conÅ¿equently,The Pope curÅ¿eth. that this kingdome was not holden of the Church of Rome, nor ought to be defended or protected by her. This anÅ¿were Å¿o Å¿tartled the Pope (whoÅ¿e will may not willingly meet with the leaÅ¿t reÅ¿iÅ¿tance) that incontinently he Å¿ent Guallo the Cardinall of St. Martins, into this Realme: who accurÅ¿ed Philip the French king, and Prince Lewes his Å¿onne, and Å¿uch of the EngliÅ¿h Nobilitie as took part with them, and all their Complices and adherents.

The wiÅ¿er Å¿ort among them little reÅ¿pected what was done by the Å¿aid Cardinall: but the common people,The effects of the Å¿aid curÅ¿. and the ordinarie degree of Souldiers (whoÅ¿e deuotions more depended vpon feare, then vpon their knowledge) were Å¿o amazed and daunted with thoÅ¿e Å¿harp and Å¿udden curÅ¿es, that (leauing their Leaders, and the Field) they returned home to their houÅ¿es, and to their Ships.Robbery, Å¿tealth, and oppreÅ¿Å¿ion. And the poore Natiues of this Realme (knowing that diuers great Lords were vnder the cenÅ¿ure of this curÅ¿e) entered into their houÅ¿es, fields, and grounds, robbing and Å¿poyling, and bearing and driuing away, whatÅ¿oeuer they could find and take: they being Å¿o far off from doubting or diÅ¿puting with their owne conÅ¿ciences, whether therein they did well or no,PopiÅ¿h blindneÅ¿Å¿e. that they Å¿uppoÅ¿ed their Å¿o doing tended immediatly to the glorie of Almighty God, and that their
Å¿tealths and Robberies were meritorious and pleaÅ¿ing in his Å¿ight.

The reuolted Lords are diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed.By theÅ¿e means, thoÅ¿e Lords and Nobles were much perplexed and pinched with great diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, and were likely to be Å¿tarued to death; becauÅ¿e they wanted all neceÅ¿Å¿aries belonging vnto life, and knew not how to relieue their owne wants. Neither durÅ¿t anie other (by reaÅ¿on of thoÅ¿e CurÅ¿es, and of their TreaÅ¿ons) to relieue them:They Å¿ubmit them elues. So that at length (when all friends, and when all other remedies did faile) NeceÅ¿Å¿itie (which is the moÅ¿t imperious Commander of all thoÅ¿e, ouer whome Å¿he tyrannizeth) enforced them to proÅ¿trate themÅ¿elues at the Kings feet; to confeÅ¿Å¿e their vndutifull reuolt; and to craue his pardon.

They are pardoned and receiued into fauor.The King (who by nature was gracious, and full of pitie; and being more willing to forgiue than to puniÅ¿h Å¿uch, as in the higheÅ¿t meaÅ¿ure had offended him, albeit he had, by their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance giuen to his enemies, beene oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with infinite miÅ¿eries, and had found more fidelitie and Å¿eruice in Å¿trangers borne, than in thoÅ¿e his owne Å¿ubjects) in milde and in gentle Å¿ort accepted of their Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, pardoned their tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ions, and reÅ¿tored them to their Honors, and to their Lands.

Peace.And by theÅ¿e meanes this Realme was disburthened of the French Nation; and a quiet peace began to Å¿alute the King and his people: who now found Å¿ome leyÅ¿ure to looke vp, and to refreÅ¿h themÅ¿elues; as FiÅ¿hes doe in a faire calme, after they haue beene tumbled and toÅ¿Å¿ed in the Waters by an vnquiet Storme.

1212. The Councell of Lateran.The Pope intending to make theÅ¿e his proceedings with King Iohn in England, a preÅ¿ident vnto other Princes) aÅ¿Å¿embled a generall Councell at Lateran: wherein hee publiÅ¿hed them all at large, together with the Å¿aid kings Grant of his Kingdome to the Pope,Princes excommunicated, and their Prouinces and Kingdomes interdicted. and his Å¿aid regrant, and the Tenure thereof to be of the Church of Rome. And in the Å¿ame Councell, Otho the Emperour, Peter king of Arragon, and Raymond Earle of TholouÅ¿e, and diuers other Princes, were excommunicated: and others were interdicted, together with their Kingdomes and their Prouinces (for HereÅ¿ie, as it was pretended.A PopiÅ¿h Policie.) But the certaine Å¿cope of this craftie and cunning packing tended to none other end, than onely to make temporall Princes Å¿ubiect to the Popes correction; and conÅ¿equently to enrich himÅ¿elfe and his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors,Auricular ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion. TranÅ¿ubÅ¿tantiation. Damnation. with their Å¿poyle. In the Å¿ame Councell alÅ¿o, Auricular ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and TranÅ¿ubÅ¿tantiation were eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed and decreed: and therein it was enacted, That Å¿uch as Å¿pake euill of the Pope Å¿hould be damned in Hell; and that no
man Å¿hould be Emperour,Emperour. vntill he had Å¿worne his Homage to the Pope, and had receiued his Crowne from him.

And thus all theÅ¿e troubles (hauing had from the fourth yeare of King Iohns Raigne as long a continuance as the Troian Warres) were at laÅ¿t ended.Peace after tenne yeares warre. But the Clergie would in no Å¿ort bee heartily reconciled to the King. For Å¿uch was their Å¿ecret grudge and Å¿pleene towards him, that (vnder the colour of much Å¿eruice and dutie) as hee lay in the Abbey of Swansteede, not farre from Lincolne) hee was poyÅ¿oned by a Monke of the Order of Saint Bernard: who, to make his match Å¿ure,King Iohn is poyÅ¿oned. and to auoid jealouÅ¿ie and Å¿uÅ¿pition, firÅ¿t dranke vnto the King, and poyÅ¿oned himÅ¿elfe for companie. And thus died King Iohn, when he had raigned aboue Å¿eu â¢ nteene yeares; and lyeth buried at WincheÅ¿ter.

In the Å¿euenth yeare of his Raigne hee tranÅ¿ported a puiÅ¿Å¿ant armie of valiant men of armes, and common Å¿ouldiors,1205. into Ireland: Ireland. and with great reÅ¿olution and courage he reduced that Nation to their former obedience; from which (with inÅ¿olent obÅ¿tinacie) they had reuolted.

This King was verie wiÅ¿e, politike, and wonderfull valiant:1209. not to be Å¿ubdued but by Death;A deÅ¿cripti â¢ n of King Iohn nor wearied with anie Trauaile; nor would be diÅ¿couraged with more than ordinarie Dangers. Hee fought manie Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull Battailes both at home and abroad; yet was hee not alwayes fortunate. For by meanes of the Popes quarrellings, Philip of France wonne from him the greateÅ¿t part, yea almoÅ¿t his whole Duchie of Normandie, and vexed him exceedingly at home in his owne Kingdome. Hee was liberally bountifull and benigne to all Strangers; but Å¿paring in his gifts to his owne Å¿ubiects. And Å¿ome reaÅ¿on hee had to be the more cloÅ¿e-handed towards them, becauÅ¿e the moÅ¿t of them (better louing France than their owne Countrey, and caring more for the French King than for him, who was their Soueraigne Lord and MaÅ¿ter) gaue him little Å¿tomack and courage to aduance them; as otherwiÅ¿e (no doubt) hee would haue longed and deÅ¿ired to haue done.

Hee left behinde him foure Å¿onnes; viz. Henrie who Å¿ucceeded
him; Richard, who was elected King of the Romans; William of Valentia; and Guido DiÅ¿nay: and three daughters; viz. IÅ¿abell, married to Fredericke the Emperour; the Å¿econd, to William MarÅ¿hall Earle of WorceÅ¿ter; and the third, to the Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE THIRD.
div.p:
AFTER the death of King Iohn,
Henrie his Å¿onne (being of the age of nine yeares) was crowned King: and the Protection of him,A Protector. and of this Realme, was committed to the Earle of GloceÅ¿ter: who hauing married one of the Kings aunts, and being well learned, politicke, and wiÅ¿e; temperate, and valiant; adminiÅ¿tred the Lawes and IuÅ¿tice vprightly to the people.

So deepe an impreÅ¿Å¿ion had confidence made in the hearts of Philip of France, and of Prince Lewis his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne,The French King againe inuadeth England. that the Kings Minoritie, Traiterous friends, and their owne good fortune, would make them the Soueraigne Lords of this kingdome; that no former Commandements, or CurÅ¿es from the Pope, preuailed, to make them vtterly to abandon and to forÅ¿ake this kingdome. For their Hopes fed them with this conceit, that their new repaire hither, and the daily diÅ¿turbance and trouble, which by their meanes Å¿hould vnjoynt the Peace, and the good Gouernment of this Commonweale, would and (in the end) Å¿hould Å¿hake it with a continuall feauer; and make it hopeleÅ¿Å¿e of all recouerie or reliefe, Å¿auing onely by their meanes. And vpon this Proiect they landed freÅ¿h forces within this Land.

But the new Protector was not idle in his charge. For his Preparations were expedited with great celeritie and judgement: and (with Å¿uch forces as he had leuied) he manfully oppoÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t all Encounters of the French, The Welchmen take part with the French. and of the Welch, which obÅ¿tinately adhered to the French part.

But the beÅ¿t Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e by Warres (in a diÅ¿tempered and in a mutinous EÅ¿tate) giues little cauÅ¿e of boaÅ¿ting to eyther part. For the Å¿laughter of manie friends and kinsfolke (affoording the Victorie) cannot chuÅ¿e but bring with it a Å¿orrowfull remembrance of their vntimely end; and beget manie wiÅ¿hes, that (their vndutifull Errors hauing beene reformed) they were aliue againe.

The Pope curÅ¿eth again Honorius the Pope being truly informed, how obÅ¿tinately the French and the Welch Nations (being aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted with Å¿ome EngliÅ¿h) daily warred and Å¿poyled within this Realme: not onely confirmed the authoritie of Guallo the Legate; but by him he thundred more Å¿harpe and terrible CurÅ¿es againÅ¿t them all, than formerly hee or his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors had done. Whereunto hee added new Excommunications, Depriuations, and other bitter CenÅ¿ures of the Church of Rome.

His curÅ¿es are not cared for.Hereupon Prince Lewis, with his confederates, Å¿eemed to be peacefull for a while; and made an outward Å¿h â¢ w, as if hee onely waited for a fit oportunitie to depart. Yet in the meane time, king Philip his father (with great care and coÅ¿t) prepared new Forces for his aide, and Å¿hipped them for this Realme. But Hugh de Burgh (being a man prouident,Hugh de Bergh preuaileth on the Å¿ea. and truly valiant, and being chiefe MaÅ¿ter of the fiue Ports) hauing fitted a Å¿trong Fleete of good Shippes, and furniÅ¿hed them to the proofe with choice Mariners and expert men of Warre, encountred them brauely vpon the Sea: and with Å¿uch hardie blowes Å¿o fiercely did aÅ¿Å¿ayle them, that (beeing altogether vnable to reÅ¿iÅ¿t him) they Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elues, and all their Shippes, vnto his mercie.

The French are abÅ¿olued, and doe returne.This noble Exploit (being thus attended by Victorie) forthwith drew Prince Lewis to a milde entreatie of Peace: So that (being abÅ¿olued by Guallo, and receiuing good Å¿ummes of money to further his returne) he Å¿urrendred all Å¿uch Forts, CaÅ¿tles, and Townes as hee had taken, and with his companies Å¿ayled into France; leauing his EngliÅ¿h friends (who had Å¿upported his EÅ¿tate and part in all theÅ¿e Warres) to the cenÅ¿ure of the Lawes, and to end their miÅ¿erable dayes with Å¿undrie executions and Å¿trange deaths.

The Common-weale being now Å¿uffered to breath,A Parliament. and hauing found Å¿ome leiÅ¿ure to prouide fitting medicines to cure Å¿uch maladies as diÅ¿tempered her eÅ¿tate, required that a Parliament might be Å¿ommoned, which was graunted:King Edwards lawes restored. and in it the ancient Lawes of King Edward were reduced and reÅ¿tored to their former vigor and Å¿trength. And the Grand Charter (in thoÅ¿e dayes called Magna Charta, compriÅ¿ing Å¿undry laws,Magna Charta. which were both eaÅ¿efull and commodious to the common people) was ratified and confirmed. And whereas the WardÅ¿hips of the heires of Å¿uch of the Kings tenants as died, WarÅ¿hips & marriages. Ann. 902. Ann. 1056. Å¿eized of any lands by them holden in Knights Å¿eruice, was graunted to King Edgar during their minorities; and their marriages were afterwards granted to King Edward the ConfeÅ¿Å¿or. ThoÅ¿e lawes (which a long time had lien aÅ¿leepe) were now reuiued and awaked; and were reÅ¿tored to their former vÅ¿e. In the Å¿ame Parliament alÅ¿o, a voluntarie Taxe was frankely giuen to the King:A voluntarie Taxe. partly to diÅ¿charge Å¿uch debts as former warres had occaÅ¿ioned, and partly to leuie new forces, to be conducted by Richard the kings brother, for the recouering of Poyters and of GaÅ¿coyne; which of late yeers (moÅ¿t iniuriouÅ¿ly, and with too much violence) had been vÅ¿urped and taken from King Henries predeceÅ¿Å¿ors, by the French King.
