that time the vertuous and milde king Richard, king of the Romans, and brother to king Henrie (in regard of his neere alliance with Gilbert Clare Earle of Glocester) had (with all his power and beÅ¿t endeuours) mediated a peace betwixt the Barons and the King: now was he Å¿o exaÅ¿perated and rowÅ¿ed from his peacefull humor, that he became a profeÅ¿Å¿ed enemie both to the Barons, and alÅ¿o to the Citie of London. And King Henrie hauing intelligence, that Sir Peter Mountfort had rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong Armie at Northampton on the Barons behalfe;The King obtaineth a victorie. and being reÅ¿olued to make Å¿ome tryall of his fortunes, in regard of the apparant iniuries and wrongs which daily were practiÅ¿ed to his diÅ¿grace: leuied a Å¿trong Armie, and marched thither; and by maine aÅ¿Å¿aults he tooke the Towne, Å¿urprized Sir Peter Mountfort, and Symon the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne of the Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter, and manie others; and Å¿ent them all to Å¿undrie PriÅ¿ons, to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of as he Å¿hould pleaÅ¿e.

And on the other Å¿ide, the Barons (who being exceeding Å¿trong, and nothing at all diÅ¿couraged with this pranke of vncertaine fortune; but preferring the dutie of worthie Å¿ubiects to their Soueraigne before their hopes, which expected fortunate Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e) wrote their Letters to the King;The Barons Letter to the King. and with all humilitie and Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿iue proteÅ¿tations confirmed their fidelities, and aÅ¿Å¿ured him, That they intended nothing but the performance of their Oaths, by Å¿upporting thoÅ¿e Ordinances and thoÅ¿e Lawes which in Parliament had beene eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed at Oxford, for his HighneÅ¿Å¿e good, and for the welfare and profit of the Commonweale.

And thus Furie (triumphing in bloud) was contented at length to hearken vnto ReaÅ¿on: and they who could Å¿carcely Å¿et their feete vpon the ground, by reaÅ¿on of the multitude of dead carkaÅ¿Å¿es, which as thicke as Å¿tones lay before them; 20000 men are Å¿laine. were now pleaÅ¿ed to take breath, and to conferre vpon conditions of Peace. And in the end it was agreed, That the King Å¿hould (by new Articles,A new concluÅ¿ion for Peace. and by the renewing of his Oath) confirme the authoritie graunted to the Twelue Peeres; and all the Å¿aid Ordinances and Lawes: with this Caution notwithÅ¿tanding, That two Lords of the Spiritualtie, and two Lords of the Temporaltie, Å¿hould take a Å¿trait examination and view of them: and if in their judgements it were needfull, that anie of them Å¿hould be reformed, full power to them was giuen, to alter and to change what they thought fit. And if they diÅ¿Å¿ented in their opinions, it was then further ordered, that the Duke of Britaine (as Vmpier) Å¿hould haue power to arbitrate and to end the doubt.The two Kings are Å¿et at libertie. H â¢ Å¿tages giuen, and the Prince was one. This being on both parts conÅ¿ented to and concluded, the two Kings left both their eldeÅ¿t Å¿onnes for hoÅ¿tages with the Barons: who Å¿ent them to the CaÅ¿tle of Douer; where they remained about nine moneths.

Then did the King with all conuenient expedition Å¿ummon his High Court of Parliament: In which, Å¿o Å¿trongly was the continuance of the Å¿aid Lawes and Ordinances made at Oxford, vrged,A Parliament. that they were then againe ratified and confirmed: and the king (though much againÅ¿t his will) tooke an Oath to maintaine them and the authoritie of the Twelue Peeres,The former Lawes and Ordinances are againe confirmed. vntill (according to the Å¿aid former referment) they Å¿hould be reformed, if anie thing in them were found to be amiÅ¿Å¿e. And all Å¿uch as in thoÅ¿e Warres, or otherwiÅ¿e, had in anie Å¿ort maintained them, receiued their pardon from the king. And hereupon the two yong Princes were enlarged.The HoÅ¿tages are enlarged. But not long after, Å¿o great a variance touching thoÅ¿e Ordinances grew betwixt the two Earles of Leicester and of GloceÅ¿ter (the two Generals of the Barons Faction) that nothing but mortall Warre had decided their controuerÅ¿ie,DiÅ¿cord betweene the Earles of LeiceÅ¿ter and of GloceÅ¿ter. if the King had not interpoÅ¿ed his authoritie and mediation to make them friends.

A faire oportunitie well watched and taken.But the young Prince Edward (taking much aduantage by reaÅ¿on of this jarre) departed Å¿ecretly from the Kings Court, conÅ¿orted to his companie the Earles of GloceÅ¿ter and Warreyne, Sir Roger Mortymer, and manie other renowned men for the Warre. And all theÅ¿e rayÅ¿ed a new Armie in Wales. The Prince rayÅ¿eth an Armie. ANNO 48. 1263. The Barons doe the like. And the Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter conceiuing that his Å¿urpriÅ¿all and ruine was conÅ¿pired (to preuent his owne danger and misfortune) did the like. And not long after the two Armies met, neere to EuerÅ¿ham in WorceÅ¿terÅ¿hire, and fought together Å¿o maliciouÅ¿ly, and with Å¿uch bloudie reÅ¿olutions, that in Å¿hort time manie thouÅ¿ands among them were Å¿laine. For Death (taking part with both) Å¿pared neyther; but Å¿triuing to make her gaine by their loÅ¿Å¿e,The battaile of EuerÅ¿ham. inÅ¿ulted proudly in the Armie, and bragged moÅ¿t, when Å¿he did moÅ¿t harme. But in the end the Barons were diÅ¿comfited;The Barons are ouerthrowne. and Symon Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter, with his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, and Sir Hugh le Spencer, and manie others of great account, were Å¿laine, and the reÅ¿t fled. The common Å¿ouldiors that preuailed, deÅ¿pightfully mangled the dead carkaÅ¿Å¿e of the Earle; cutting off both hands and feete, and Å¿ending them into diuers Shires to their friends, as Trophies of their Victorie. And others among them (being more inhumane and barbarous) cut off his head, and his priuie members, and placed them on eyther Å¿ide of his noÅ¿e.

This ouerthrow did vtterly defeat the Barons, and depriued them of all their hopes: and it Å¿o reuiued the melancholie King, that now he began againe to be Å¿enÅ¿ible of his owne Å¿trength, and reÅ¿olued (with all Å¿peede poÅ¿Å¿ible) to breake thoÅ¿e chaynes with which Å¿o lately hee was Å¿o Å¿trongly bound. And for the effecting thereof,A Parliament. hee aÅ¿Å¿embled his High Court of Parliament: In which, no man dared to Å¿peake otherwiÅ¿e than as the King Å¿pake. So that thoÅ¿e former Ordinances and Lawes, which were made at Oxford in the Madde Parliament,The former Decrees are all made void and the authoritie of the Twelue Peers, and all Patents, CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, and InÅ¿truments whatÅ¿oeuer (which tended to the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing or ratifying of thoÅ¿e affaires) were (by the Kings expreÅ¿Å¿e commaundement) brought forth, and were publikely damned, cancelled, and made void. And thus King Henrie regained his former libertie and power, to Å¿ay and to doe in all things as he pleaÅ¿ed.

The King reÅ¿olueth to burne the citie of London.When this Parliament was ended, the King (perhaps by the inÅ¿tigation of his brother Richard, King of the Romans; who was cruelly wronged by the baÅ¿er Å¿ort of the inhabitants of London, without anie cauÅ¿e by him giuen, as before it is mentioned) reÅ¿olued vtterly to waÅ¿t and to conÅ¿ume with fire his Citie of London: becauÅ¿e
(as hee alledged) the Rulers and the Inhabitants thereof had alwaies deÅ¿piÅ¿ed him, and taken part againÅ¿t him with the Barons in their Warres. Whereupon Å¿uch of the Nobilitie (and others as were neere in fauour, and next about the perÅ¿on of the King) beÅ¿ought him inÅ¿tantly to abÅ¿taine from Å¿o foule a deede; which would not onely much weaken his EÅ¿tate and Kingdome, but alÅ¿o make him infamous through the World, and vnto all Å¿ucceeding Ages. Their Å¿uite was earneÅ¿t, and their reaÅ¿ons to perÅ¿uade were vnanÅ¿werable: yet the King proteÅ¿ted,No interceÅ¿Å¿ion can preuaile. That his determination Å¿hould be vnchangeable; and that his IuÅ¿tice vpon Å¿uch rebellious Caitiues Å¿hould be a preÅ¿ident to terrifie all peruerÅ¿e and obÅ¿tinate Traitors and Rebels in future times. And this his reÅ¿olution juÅ¿tly occaÅ¿ioned the Citizens of London to quake at the indignation of their angrie King: Å¿o that they (perceiuing that his rage and furie could not be mitigated) cauÅ¿ed an InÅ¿trument in writing to be made, and ratified it with their common Seale,The Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion of the Londoners. by which they confeÅ¿Å¿ed their Rebellion, humbly craued pardon, and without anie reÅ¿traint, or exception, wholly Å¿ubmitted their Lands, their Goods, and their Liues, together with the whole Citie, to the kings Grace and Mercie.

This InÅ¿trument they Å¿ent vnto WindÅ¿our by diuers of the chiefeÅ¿t and richeÅ¿t inhabitants of the Citie,The citizens committed to priÅ¿on, and giuen away by the King. who were prepared with all humilitie to haue preÅ¿ented it vpon their knees. But Å¿o fierce was the Kings wroth towards them, and Å¿o implacable was his anger, that he reputed none of thoÅ¿e to be his friends, who interpoÅ¿ed themÅ¿elues as Mediators in their behalfes: Neither would hee vouchÅ¿afe to admit anie one of them to come into his preÅ¿ence; but cauÅ¿ed them forthwith to be caÅ¿t into priÅ¿on: and fiue of the chiefeÅ¿t of them, together with all their Lands and their Goods, hee gaue vnto the Prince; and all the others he gaue to other of his attendants, who burthened them with heauie Å¿eruitude and much miÅ¿erie, and tooke from them what they pleaÅ¿ed, leauing to them the leaÅ¿t part of their owne.

Thus when the King had a little auenged himÅ¿elfe,The Prince procureth the Kings pardon and fauor. and time had cooled the heat of his paÅ¿Å¿ionate humour; he hearkened to the importunate interceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Prince, and receiued the Citie and all the inhabitants thereof into fauor, and onely tooke of them a fine of one thouÅ¿and marks; and reÅ¿tored them to all their Liberties and CuÅ¿tomes, which for their tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion were Å¿eized into his hands.

The King alÅ¿o, vpon the Princes entreatie,The fiue Ports are pardoned. pardoned the inhabitants of the fiue Ports: who finding IuÅ¿tice to be faÅ¿t aÅ¿leepe, whileÅ¿t the Barons warres outragiouÅ¿ly diÅ¿turbed the whole EÅ¿tate
and Kingdome; robbed, rifled, and Å¿poyled on the Seas both their owne neighbours and Countrey-men, and alÅ¿o all Nations whom they met, without any difference or reÅ¿pect.

And leÅ¿t the King Å¿hould be too much troubled with the frequent complaints of Å¿uch as had beene wronged by them, or his Courts of IuÅ¿tice peÅ¿tred with the multitude of Å¿uch Å¿utors; the King commanded that none of the offenders Å¿hould be impleaded elÅ¿where, but onely in the Courts of thoÅ¿e Ports: by meanes wherof there were but few that complained, becauÅ¿e none of them had any hope to haue recompence or redreÅ¿Å¿e there. And now, though thoÅ¿e inteÅ¿tine troubles and ciuill warres (which like an outragious fire diÅ¿perÅ¿ed in the heart, and middeÅ¿t of a well compacted Citie, endangered the whole eÅ¿tate of this Kingdome and Common-weale) were thus appeaÅ¿ed:The Earle of GloceÅ¿ter being vnrewarded, thinketh on miÅ¿chiefe. and although Gilbert Clare Earle of Glocester by his reuolt from the Barons, and by his adhering to the Prince and to his complices, had greatly furthered the good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, which had made the King to enioy a bleÅ¿Å¿ed peace; yet was the Å¿aid Earle Å¿o little truÅ¿ted, that he neither found fauour nor reward; but the little reÅ¿pect which was had of him, and his cold entertainment at the Court, made him deÅ¿perate of all good fortunes, and inflamed his heart to work reuenge.

The raÅ¿cality of London do flock vnto him.This furie carried him headlong vnto the Citie of London, where no Å¿ooner was his diÅ¿contented humour made known, but the raÅ¿call and the baÅ¿er Å¿ort (forgetting the great calamitie which that famous Citie did endure, and the great fauours which Å¿o lately they had receiued from the King) flocked in troupes about him,They do miÅ¿chiefe. and boldly committed many grieuous outrages within the Citie. And then they went vnto the Kings Palace at Westminster, which they rifled, Å¿poiled, and ranÅ¿acked without meane or meaÅ¿ure. This rude beginning prognoÅ¿ticated the Å¿udden acceÅ¿Å¿e of another ciuill warre: which might haue bred as much danger as any of the former had done;The Prince procureth a large pardon. but the Prince (againe) interpoÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe an earneÅ¿t mediator betwixt the King and all the Å¿aid offenders, and procured a large and a free pardon for the Earle.

Thus this dangerous fire was Å¿oone quenched, and good preuention in due time did wiÅ¿ely cut off all occaÅ¿ions of future warre: and at the Å¿ame time, and by the like meanes, the King pardoned many decaied and out-lawed Gentlemen, who (in the heat of thoÅ¿e broiles) had committed many robberies and Å¿poiles in diuers places of this kingdome.

The Earle of Glocesters requeÅ¿t.And not long after, the Earle of Glocester (deÅ¿pairing of all inward grace and fauour from the king, and being deÅ¿irous, as it Å¿eemed,
by deedes of Chiualrie to make himÅ¿elfe famous among the enemies of ChriÅ¿t) requeÅ¿ted that he might be Å¿ent with an Armie to make warre in the Holy-land. This motion (though it tended to much expence and great charge) yet it pleaÅ¿ed the King exceedingly; becauÅ¿e he knew that the Earles buÅ¿ie head and turbulent Å¿pirit would Å¿till be plotting and deuiÅ¿ing of new broiles,An Armie raiÅ¿ed to be conducted into the Holy land by the Earle of Glocester. and hurlyburlies at home: wherfore he cauÅ¿ed a faire Armie to be raiÅ¿ed, and furniÅ¿hed it with all neceÅ¿Å¿aries fit and requiÅ¿it for Å¿o long, and for Å¿o dangerous a iourney.

But when all things were in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, the Earle fained many excuÅ¿es which tended to ouer-much delay, which cauÅ¿ed him to be leÅ¿Å¿e regarded by the King, and to bee in great diÅ¿like with all others.

But Prince Edward (being full of youth and courage,The Earle is diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed worthily from that charge. and longing greedily to hoiÅ¿t his Sailes in the Sea of Honour, and by aduentrous deeds of Knight-hood, to equall his name with thoÅ¿e who were accounted moÅ¿t valiant in the world) by his earneÅ¿t Å¿uite and trauell, obtained the conducting of that Armie,The Prince vndertaketh it, and doth perform it. Their happie Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e. and tranÅ¿ported it into the Holy-land, where his Å¿word wrought wonders: and his Armie bred Å¿uch terror and admiration among the Turkes, that they would Å¿eldome or neuer aduenture themÅ¿elues againÅ¿t the ChriÅ¿tians in that quarter where the Prince Å¿erued. And to Å¿aue themÅ¿elues from his furie vpon his comming thither, they raiÅ¿ed their Å¿iege from the Citie of Acon, The Å¿iege of Acon raiÅ¿ed. which (for a long time) they had continued with more then a hundred thouÅ¿and men. And Å¿eeing that his death could not be haÅ¿tened by force and violence in the open field,The Prince was villanouÅ¿ly wounded. they attempted it by poyÅ¿onings and other Å¿ecret villanies, which tooke no effect. But at length a dogged Sarazen grieuouÅ¿ly wounded him with an enuenomed Knife, yet (after much paine and great danger) hee eÅ¿caped death. But in his abÅ¿ence his father King Henrie died, and was buried at Westminster, The King dieth. when he had raigned more then fiftie and Å¿ix yeers; whereof the Prince was quickly informed, and therfore (by great iournies) hee Å¿afely returned (with great honour) into ENGLAND.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING EDVVARD THE FIRST.
div.p: WHEN Edward, Å¿urnamed LongÅ¿hankes, was informed of his fathers death, he made quick preparations for his returne from the Holie Land;The new King returneth from the Holie Land. and by great journeyes trauailed vntill he came into England: where (with the generall applauÅ¿e, both of his Nobles and common People) hee was crowned King, when he was of the age of fiue and thirtie yeares.

Wee haue heard how, when,The French kings practiÅ¿e againÅ¿t King Edward. and where Symon de Mountford Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter, Henrie his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, and Å¿undrie other Barons were Å¿laine in the laÅ¿t Battaile betweene them and the laÅ¿t King. And it is true, that after his ouerthrow, the Ladie Elianor his daughter, with manie others of his allies and kinsfolkes, were Å¿entenced to Exile; and departed into France: where they were courteouÅ¿ly receiued by the French king Philip the third, Å¿urnamed the Hardie; whoÅ¿e kind entertaining of them proceeded not Å¿o much from his owne bountie and naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to Liberalitie, as it did from an opinion which hee conceiued, That in Å¿o doing hee Å¿hould gaine the loue and good liking of manie EngliÅ¿h Lords: who (being diÅ¿contented with the laÅ¿t Kings Gouernment) were not
well pleaÅ¿ed with his Å¿onne, who had croÅ¿Å¿ed them in moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e affaires. And moreouer, he knew the noble valour and courage of King Edward to be Å¿o eminent, that it was now high time to craue counÅ¿ell of WiÅ¿dome and of Policie, how and by what meanes he might preuent him from making himÅ¿elfe more great. And becauÅ¿e ReaÅ¿on and common Experience taught him, That hee, whoÅ¿e owne houÅ¿e is on fire, will rather imploy his endeuours to quench that flame, than to Å¿et his enemies houÅ¿e on fire alÅ¿o: hee therefore practiÅ¿ed Å¿ecretly with Lluellen (the moÅ¿t valiant,Lluellen of Wales Å¿ueth to the French King to haue in marriage Elianor the exiled daughter of the late Earle of LeiceÅ¿ter. and greateÅ¿t in dignitie among the Welchmen) that he, with thoÅ¿e inhabitants, would rebell, if at anie time anie Warres were but likely to be attempted againÅ¿t the French Nation by King Edward. And this his plot was much furthered by the exile of the aforeÅ¿aid Ladie Elianor: who being (by reaÅ¿on of her misfortunes) in the diÅ¿poÅ¿ing and power of the French King, was (with great importunitie) deÅ¿ired in marriage by the Å¿aid Lluellen: to whome (vpon thoÅ¿e concluÅ¿ions and agreements eÅ¿pecially) Å¿hee was Å¿ent with honourable attendance and rich gifts.She is Å¿ent towards Wales. But king Edward (being Å¿ecretly informed both of the Å¿aid purpoÅ¿e, and of her paÅ¿Å¿age towards Wales) wiÅ¿ely preuented his owne danger, and intercepted her on the Sea,She is taken at Sea. and detained her as his priÅ¿oner. By meanes whereof, Lluellen (whoÅ¿e beÅ¿t Rhetoricke to perÅ¿uade, was by open Warre and Rebellion) entred into the field with manie thouÅ¿ands;Lluellen rebelleth. who were more readie to robbe and to Å¿teale, than to reclayme themÅ¿elues, and to be mindfull of their dutie to their Prince.

The King rayÅ¿eth an Armie.The King likewiÅ¿e on his part (purpoÅ¿ing to make his firÅ¿t voyage terrible to the Welchmen, for examples Å¿ake to that fickle Nation) leuied Å¿o Å¿trong an Armie, that (by all conjectures) the Welchmen were altogether vnable to reÅ¿iÅ¿t him. And it Å¿eemed they thought Å¿o too: For their chiefeÅ¿t Captaine and Leader (partly for the loue which he bare to his longed-for Ladie, and partly to preuent thoÅ¿e fatall dangers which knocked at his dore) vnexpectedly Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe to the Kings Grace,Lluellen voluntarily Å¿ubmitteth himÅ¿elfe. and yeelded himÅ¿elfe to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of wholly and onely at the Kings pleaÅ¿ure; and vowed and proteÅ¿ted with manie great and Å¿olemne Oathes, That his obedience Å¿hould be conÅ¿tant,Lluellen voweth and Å¿weareth loyaltie. and his Å¿word alwaies readie to Å¿erue the King, both againÅ¿t France and againÅ¿t all others in future time, if he might be made happie with the Kings fauour, and haue the enjoyment of his Ladie.

Lluellen is pardoned fauored, and wiued.The King, whoÅ¿e heart was euer enclined to mercie, and more deÅ¿ired by affabilitie to winne an enemie, than to conquer him by blowes; and Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that his loue to his MiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e would be a
Å¿tronger bond to Å¿trengthen his allegeance, than anie other thing; freely granted him his pardon, his fauour, and his wife. And thus thoÅ¿e Warres (which menaced the death of manie thouÅ¿ands) were quietly ended, without the effuÅ¿ion of anie bloud.

But within few yeares after, Lluellen, Lluellen rebelleth. by the wicked perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions and enticement of his brother Dauid (a man more contentious than prouident, and leÅ¿Å¿e valiant than mutinous; and yet one whome the King did extraordinarily loue and fauour) rebelled againÅ¿t the King; and fought with Sir Roger Mortymer manie Å¿harpe and aduantagious battailes.Lluellen and his brother are taken and beheaded. But at length (Gods judgements haÅ¿tening Traytors to a Å¿hamefull end) both of them were taken; and their heads (as Trophies of the victorie) were Å¿ent vn â¢â¢ the King: who cauÅ¿ed them to be Å¿et vpon the Tower of London, for a terror vnto others; and there they remained long after.

But (notwithÅ¿tanding all this) yet the naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Welchmen Å¿o Å¿trongly preuailed, and Å¿o blind they were, and vnable to foreÅ¿ee their owne ruine,The Welchmen rebell againe and againe. that within few moneths after they rebelled twice; and by manie Å¿laughters and Å¿trange executions they were Å¿ubdued, and compelled to obey. And becauÅ¿e their Warres were rather maintained and cheriÅ¿hed by Å¿hiftings and by Å¿tartings into the huge and vaÅ¿t Woods (which made thoÅ¿e Rebels more diÅ¿ordered,They are Å¿ubdued. and confident to Å¿aue themÅ¿elues when greateÅ¿t danger did approach) the King cauÅ¿ed thoÅ¿e Woods to be hewen downe,Their woods are burned. and to be conÅ¿umed with fire: By meanes whereof, they were reduced to a more ciuill kinde of life;They become more ciuill. and began to practiÅ¿e diuers commendable Occupations, Arts, and Sciences, and tooke Å¿ome pleaÅ¿ure (from thenceforth) to liue like honeÅ¿t men.

In the eighteenth yeare of King Edwards Raigne,The King of Scots breaketh his necke Alexander the King of Scots (not hauing anie iÅ¿Å¿ue of his bodie) fell with his horÅ¿e, and vnfortunately brake his necke. He had three Å¿iÅ¿ters: the eldeÅ¿t of which was married vnto Iohn Baylyol, Lord of Galloway; the Å¿econd vnto Robert le Bruze, Lord of Valley-Androw; and the third was married into England to Iohn HaÅ¿tings, Lord of Abergauenny. Contention about the Crowne of Scotland. Betwixt theÅ¿e three (each of them being backed with the beÅ¿t Å¿upport of their moÅ¿t able friends) Å¿harpe bickerings and ciuill warres occaÅ¿ioned the deaths of manie worthie and valiant men, together with the ruine and deÅ¿truction of Å¿ome of their HouÅ¿es and beÅ¿t Fortunes:The title is referred to the cenÅ¿ure of King Edward, as to the Å¿oueraign Lord thereof. and the Commonweale of that kingdome receiued manie deÅ¿perate wounds and Å¿trange miÅ¿aduentures, becauÅ¿e each of them (in the right of his wife) attempted and hoped to be a king. Whereupon king Edward (with great expedition) went into Scotland as their Soueraigne Lord, and endeuoured to compoÅ¿e this Å¿trife. But
Å¿uch was their mutuall deÅ¿ire to raigne, that no perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions preuailed to make anie one of them to yeeld. But in the end, more Å¿ounder aduice tooke place: Å¿o that they all (by a publike writing vnder their hands and Å¿eales) conÅ¿ented to referre themÅ¿elues and their Titles to the cenÅ¿ure and judgement of King Edward. Scotland is Å¿urrendred to king Edward And by the Å¿ame InÅ¿trument they freely Å¿urrendered all Scotland, and that Crowne, into the Kings hands; to the end, that thereby they might enable him abÅ¿olutely to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uch a one of them in that Kingdome, as (in his judgement) ought to haue the Å¿ame. Hee alÅ¿o receiued from them in writing their Å¿euerall demands, and each mans proofes,A wiÅ¿e and a diÅ¿creet King reaÅ¿ons and arguments to maintaine his Clayme. And thereupon King Edward elected and made choice of twentie of the moÅ¿t diÅ¿creet, wiÅ¿e, and worthie men of his kingdome of England, and of twentie more of the kingdome of Scotland: and by their aduice and counÅ¿ell he informed himÅ¿elfe truly of that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; and at length pronounced his Sentence for Iohn Baylyol, Iohn Bailiol is made King of the Scots. He doth homage for it to the King. who had married the eldeÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e three Å¿iÅ¿ters: who receiued from him that Crowne and Countrey, and for it performed and did his homage to King Edward.

The King, although he were earneÅ¿tly employed in theÅ¿e and in other affaires at home; yet was he more troubled with greater buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es abroad,The French King wrongeth King Edward. by reaÅ¿on that the French King daily wronged him in GaÅ¿coyne, Guyan, and elÅ¿ewhere. And to maintaine thoÅ¿e warres, the King (by the aduice and counÅ¿ell of William Marchyan his chiefeÅ¿t TreaÅ¿urer) Å¿eized into his hands the Plate, Iewels, and TreaÅ¿ure of the Churches and of the religious HouÅ¿es within this kingdome,Eu â¢ ll counÅ¿ell. and compelled the Clergie to giue vnto him the one halfe of one yeares value of all their EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Dignities and Promotions.The King Å¿t â¢â¢ ppeth the Church. He is hated by Churchmen. This vnaccuÅ¿tomed Sacriledge made the King hatefull in Churchmens eyes. But yet he Å¿eemed in Å¿ome Å¿ort to content them with faire promiÅ¿es of ReÅ¿titution, when his TreaÅ¿ures Å¿hould by other meanes be encreaÅ¿ed. But they little relying vpon that promiÅ¿e, and (by common experience in other things) being reÅ¿olued, that the Kings Coffers would not be emptied to fill theirs (and yet feeding themÅ¿elues with a vaine hope, that Å¿ome other recompence might be made them) became humble Å¿utors to the King,The Clergies â¢ ute denyed. That he would be pleaÅ¿ed to reuoke and to annihilate the Statute, which in the fourth yeare of his Raigne was made againÅ¿t Mortmayne; Mortmayne. which prohibited the giuing and the conueying of anie Lands and Tenements to anie Corporation whatÅ¿oeuer, without the Kings leaue. But as he neuer meant to gratifie them in anie Å¿ort whatÅ¿oeuer: Å¿o he made them anÅ¿wer, That it lay not in him, without the conÅ¿ent
of a Parliament, to reuoke and to fruÅ¿trate anie Law. The Clergie (to their great griefe and Å¿orrow) perceiued, that their TreaÅ¿ure was Å¿wept away, together with all hope of reÅ¿titution or amends: and though it vexed them inwardly, yet durÅ¿t they not to expreÅ¿Å¿e anie outward tokens of diÅ¿like.

Thus when the King had augmented his Å¿tore by the Clergies plentie: he (by the directions of his Å¿aid TreaÅ¿urer) impoÅ¿ed a Taxe or SubÅ¿idie vpon euerie Sacke of Woolls,A new Tax. and vpon all Fells and Hydes which were to be tranÅ¿ported out of this kingdome; and alÅ¿o required the tenth part of euerie mans moueable goods and Å¿ubÅ¿tance to maintaine his Warres: which being granted, hee cauÅ¿ed it to be leuied by manie payments within the Å¿p â¢â¢ e of three yeares. He alÅ¿o compelled the Clergie to bring into his Coffers all Å¿uch Å¿ummes of mony as they had promiÅ¿ed to pay vnto the Pope, towards the maintenance of the ChriÅ¿tians Warre with the Turks in the Holie Land. He alÅ¿o tooke vp one hundred thouÅ¿and Quarters of the beÅ¿t Wheat, and Å¿ent it to his Armies in GaÅ¿coyne and in Guyan: where they fought with much courage and valour, but with doubtfull Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿ometimes gaining what was loÅ¿t, and Å¿ometimes looÅ¿ing what they had wonne.

In the fiue and twentieth yeare of King Edwards Raigne, 25. 1296. Iohn Baylyol inuadeth England. Iohn Baylyol the King of Scots (partly by the Å¿ecret procurement of the French King, and partly by the lewd aduice and counÅ¿ell of factious and wicked perÅ¿ons) Å¿ent a Defiance (with a proud renunciation of his Fealtie and Homage) to the King; and with an Armie of braine-Å¿icke Rebels entred into the Northerne parts of this kingdome: where (with fire and Å¿word) they oppreÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿uch as could make no reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and (without pitie and compaÅ¿Å¿ion) Å¿lew Å¿uch as were armed in the defence of their Countrey, and to Å¿aue themÅ¿elues.The King with an army marcheth againÅ¿t the Scots. Whereupon King Edward recounting his manifold fauors and great loue to the Å¿aid reuolted King, and the high Honour wherewith (not manie yeares before) he had graced him; and being reÅ¿olued to correct his vnthankfulneÅ¿Å¿e with Å¿harpe reuenge, leuied a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie, and marched (in full Å¿trength) towards the Northerne parts: and found his fortune to be Å¿o fauourable,Barwike wonne. The Scots are ouerthrowne. 25000 Scots are Å¿laine. that with much eaÅ¿e hee wonne the Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle of Barwike, with the Å¿laughter of fiue and twentie thouÅ¿and Scots. He alÅ¿o wonne the well-defended CaÅ¿tle of Donn-Barre: and (piercing into the Å¿ides of Scotland) hee tooke Edenburrough, and all other places of the beÅ¿t defence. And the King of Scots perceiuing the dangerous eÅ¿tate wherein hee Å¿tood, and repoÅ¿ing his laÅ¿t hopes in the Kings Grace; by the aduice of all his Nobles repaired in perÅ¿on to the
Kings preÅ¿ence,The King of Scots yeeldeth himÅ¿elf, and Å¿urrendreth his Kingdome. He is Å¿ent to the Tower of London. humbly Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe, craued pardon, and Å¿olemnely Å¿urrendred his whole Kingdome into King Edwards hands: Who forthwith Å¿ent the Å¿aid ScottiÅ¿h King with a Å¿trong Guard to the Tower of London; but gaue him large allowance both of Libertie and of Attendance, and of his Diet. And then he committed the Gouernment of that Kingdome vnto Iohn Warrayne, Earle of SuÅ¿Å¿ex and of Surrey; and made Sir Hugh CreÅ¿singham his High TreaÅ¿urer, and William EarnÅ¿ley his chiefe IuÅ¿tice of that Kingdome.The King placeth a Gouernour ouer Scotland. And hauing confined Å¿ome of the Rebellious Peeres of Scotland within the Marches of England; hee returned triumphantly, and with great honour.

And then King Edward vÅ¿ing great expedition and much policie for the refreÅ¿hing and for the renewing of his Armie;King Edward Å¿ayleth into Flanders and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿teth the Earle thereof. tranÅ¿ported it into the Territories of Guy, then Earle of Flanders: againÅ¿t whome, Robert Earle of Arthois (by the procurement, and with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the French King) made Å¿harpe warre. And the French King intending to haÅ¿ten King Edwards returne into England, to Å¿aue himÅ¿elfe and his owne Countrey; animated the Scots to rebell againe: And they (becauÅ¿e they were factious, and readie to doe vnto France all Å¿eruice vpon all commaunds,The Scots rebell. though with the hazard of their liues, and of their lands) without anie feare, or fore-caÅ¿t of their future miÅ¿eries, did put themÅ¿elues in Armes.

But King Edward purpoÅ¿ing to greete the French King and his Forces with a Souldiors welcome; appointed Henrie Percie Earle of Northumberland, and manie other Lords and Gentlemen of the beÅ¿t ranke,The Scots are Å¿ubdued. for the repreÅ¿Å¿ing of that Rebellion: who Å¿o manfully banged the Scots, that they enforced them to flye out of the field, and purÅ¿ued them with a mercileÅ¿Å¿e Å¿laughter, and reduced the reÅ¿t to their former dutie and obedience.

The French King dared not to fight with King Edward.The French King perceiuing, that his practiÅ¿e with the Scots wanted his hoped Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e; was not deÅ¿irous to trie his Å¿trength with King Edward in the open field: but repoÅ¿ing more confidence in his wit than in his valour, hee propoÅ¿ed verie honourable conditions of amitie and loue; which by King Edward were accepted: and then a generall Peace was proclaymed betwixt them all. And thus thoÅ¿e Warres (by King Edwards meanes and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance) receiued a Å¿hort end;A Peace is concluded. which made a Å¿hew of long continuance, with the expence of much bloud.

London is reÅ¿tored to her liberties.After the Kings returne into England, hee reÅ¿tored to the Citizens of London their Liberties; which (for manie vndutifull miÅ¿demeanors) had remained forfeited in his hands for the Å¿pace of
twelue yeares.The Scots rebell againe. And forthwith hee ledde all his Forces into Scotland; where a new Rebellion madly raged, and could not be Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed without much Å¿trength. And being more willing, that the execution of IuÅ¿tice vpon few (for examples Å¿ake) Å¿hould rather reclayme the multitude, than that the Sword Å¿hould waÅ¿tfully conÅ¿ume them; he required the deliuerie of their Leaders,A mercifull King. and offered his free pardon to the reÅ¿t.

But their froward diÅ¿poÅ¿itions (preparing them to much more miÅ¿erie than as yet they had endured) animated them obÅ¿tinately to arme themÅ¿elues, and in warlike faÅ¿hion to bid Battaile to the King: InÅ¿omuch, that his HighneÅ¿Å¿e finding his fauours to bee neglected, and perceiuing that all extremitie was to be vÅ¿ed;The battaile of Fanrike. The Scots are ouerthrowne. 28. EngliÅ¿hmen Å¿laine. 32000. Scots are Å¿laine. Å¿et vpon them with Å¿uch furie and violence, that with the loÅ¿Å¿e of eight and twentie of his followers, and with the Å¿laughter of two and thirtie thouÅ¿and of the Scots, hee enforced the reÅ¿t to yeeld: and taking a new Oath for their Fealtie and Homage, he appeaÅ¿ed that Countrey; and (to the great joy of all his people) he returned againe into England. Where (vpon the earneÅ¿t entreatie and requeÅ¿t of Pope Boniface the eight) hee enlarged Iohn Baylyol: Who trauailed into France, Iohn Baylyol Å¿et at libertie to take a view of his LordÅ¿hips there; which (according to his owne name) were called Baylyols Lands.

King Edward had no Å¿ooner finiÅ¿hed theÅ¿e Troubles;The Scots doe rebell againe. but the Scots were in Armes againe: So that the third time hee entred with a great Power into that Countrey; where none were Å¿o daring, or Å¿o hardie, as to endure his preÅ¿ence.The King leadeth an Armie into Scotland. But the greater number of the Earles, Barons, and chiefeÅ¿t Gentlemen of that kingdome had withdrawne themÅ¿elues into the Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle of Estryuelyne; which was by them Å¿o Å¿trengthened, that in their judgements it was impregnable. This CaÅ¿tle was long beÅ¿ieged by the King,EÅ¿tryueline is beÅ¿ieged, in which the Nobles are. but to little purpoÅ¿e: and hee much doubted, leaÅ¿t his continuance in that Å¿eruice would affoord him but little honor in the end. Wherefore (to make a tryall how farre his Inuention would take place) he cauÅ¿ed two paire of Gallowes to be Å¿et vp in the CaÅ¿tles view;The Kings Policie. and with the Å¿ound of a Trumpet did proclayme his free Pardon, if the beÅ¿ieged did yeeld themÅ¿elues within three daies: but denounced death vnto them all, by hanging, without reÅ¿pect of Honor,A Proclamation. or of PerÅ¿on, if obÅ¿tinately they enforced him to continue a longer Siege. And hereupon the beÅ¿ieged, although they were Å¿o Å¿trongly immured, that they might boldly haue truÅ¿ted vpon their Å¿trong defence; yet becauÅ¿e they diÅ¿truÅ¿ted to be relieued,EÅ¿tryuelyne is yeelded. they repoÅ¿ed their confidence in the Kings word, and Å¿ubmitted both the CaÅ¿tle
and themÅ¿elues to his grace and mercie,The Scots do Å¿wear their obedience to K. Edward. whereof they had good proofe. For (taking new oaths for the performance of their obedience, and dutie in future times) he Å¿et them free and at libertie: and the like oaths he tooke of all IuÅ¿tices, Mayors, and other Officers of Townes, Cities, CaÅ¿tles, and Forts; and hauing diÅ¿poÅ¿ed all things in a comely and in a peaceable order, for the good gouernement of that Kingdome,The ScottiÅ¿h chairn. hee returned into England, and brought with him (for a memoriall of his great victorie) a Chaire of Å¿tone, in which the Kings of Scotland by common cuÅ¿tom receiued their EnÅ¿tallment and their Crowne: which Chaire remaineth in the Kings Chappell at Westminster, among the faire Monuments of our famous Kings of this Realme.

AÅ¿Å¿oone as King Edward was returned from his iourney, he cauÅ¿ed a general enquirie (which was termed Troile BaÅ¿ton) to be made throughout his Kingdome,Troy-baÅ¿ton of the miÅ¿demeanours and oppreÅ¿Å¿ions of his Officers of all Å¿orts;A memorable deed done by a worthie King. Å¿o that the number of the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ors was Å¿uch, and Å¿o great were their offences, and their fines Å¿o heauie, that with their money the King filled his emptie coffers to the brimme, diÅ¿charged his old Å¿cores, which were very great by reaÅ¿on of his warres in Wales, Scotland, the Low Countries, GaÅ¿coyne, Guyan, and elÅ¿ewhere, and then he diÅ¿placed thoÅ¿e corrupted Officers, and placed better in their Å¿teads.The Prince is committed to priÅ¿on, and Pierce GaueÅ¿ton is baniÅ¿ht Cornwall and Wales giuen to the Prince. 29. 1300. Peace betwixt England and Scotland. The Scots doe Å¿weare obedience. The Popes claime to be high Lord of Scotland, and his command to King Edward.

About the Å¿ame time Doctor Langton then BiÅ¿hop of CheÅ¿ter, complained grieuouÅ¿ly to the King vpon Edward the yong Prince, who (by the lewd aduice and inÅ¿tigation of Pierce GaueÅ¿ton his looÅ¿e and graceleÅ¿Å¿e companion) brake forcibly into his Parke, and made hauocke of his game; for which the Prince was committed to priÅ¿on, and Gaueston was baniÅ¿hed the land, and required not to return on paine of death. And the next yeere after Edmund Earle of Cornwall, Å¿onne to Richard King of the Romans, died without iÅ¿Å¿ue; Å¿o that that Earldome reuerted to the Crowne, which (together with the Principalitie of Wales) the King gaue vnto Prince Edward, his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne and heire apparant to his Crowne.

In the three and thirtieth yeer of King Edwards raigne, a generall peace was proclaimed betweene England and Scotland, and Robert le BruÅ¿e, and many other knights, Lords, and Earles of that Country came into England, and voluntarily Å¿wore their fealtie and their homage to the king: yet before one yeare was fully expired, the Å¿aid Lord BruÅ¿e and many others Å¿ecretly procured from the Pope an inÅ¿trument in writing, by which the Pope made claime to the kingdome of Scotland, as holden of his Church of Rome; and the king was thereby peremptorily required to Å¿urceaÅ¿e from all demands
of Tenure, and of Soueraintie ouer it.The Kings meÅ¿Å¿age to the Pope. But the king (by the aduice of his Nobles) Å¿ignified by his EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Pope, That the Signiory and LordÅ¿hip of the Å¿aid kingdome of Scotland did only belong to the kings of England, and not vnto the See of Rome, nor vnto any other: and therefore he prayed him to reuoke his Å¿aid InÅ¿trument and vniuÅ¿t claime; for that both hee and his Nobles were reÅ¿olued to maintain his right and lawfull inheritance therein, with the vtmoÅ¿t expence of their goods, lands, and liues. But whilÅ¿t thoÅ¿e things were thus handling,Robert le BruÅ¿e doth vÅ¿urp in Scotland. The King in his owne perÅ¿on the fourth time Å¿ubdueth the Scots. The vÅ¿urper flieth into Norway. The King dieth. Robert le BruÅ¿e (by the Popes conÅ¿ent) cauÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf to be crowned king of that Realm: which occaÅ¿ioned king Edward the fourth time to enter into Scotland with a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie; where he Å¿o largely extended his valor, and with the Å¿word Å¿o fiercely deuoured the Inhabitants which ioynd with their vÅ¿urping king, that they were compelled (with extraordinarie tokens of Å¿ubiection and humilitie) to yeeld themÅ¿elues to the kings mercie. And Robert le BruÅ¿e (finding no meanes to make good his falÅ¿e title to that Crown) Å¿ecretly withdrew himÅ¿elfe, and fled into Norway, where he remained vntill king Edwards death; which happened Å¿oone after, when hee had raigned victoriouÅ¿ly almoÅ¿t thirty fiue yeeres.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING EDVVARD THE SECOND.
div.p: AFTER the Kings death, his Å¿onne Edward Å¿ucceeded, and was crowned King.

His tall and comely PerÅ¿onage,An euill King. graced with outward MajeÅ¿tie, Å¿eemed to promiÅ¿e manie bleÅ¿Å¿ings to enÅ¿ue: But his Maners (being groÅ¿Å¿ely corrupted by lewd and graceleÅ¿Å¿e companions) were Å¿o laÅ¿ciuious, and vnbefitting the condition of a King, that he became burthenÅ¿ome to his Nobilitie; and (almoÅ¿t) a skorne to his inferior Å¿ubjects. For hee neglected the Å¿ocietie and the counÅ¿ell of Å¿uch as were wiÅ¿e and graue, and conÅ¿orted himÅ¿elfe with his owne Minions: by meanes whereof, he put in practiÅ¿e euerie loathed thing, wherein hee could either take pleaÅ¿ure, or expreÅ¿Å¿e his follie. So that his euill Gouernment made his Kingdome to be vnfortunate, and himÅ¿elfe a preÅ¿ident of wretchedneÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿ucceeding Ages: as in the diÅ¿courÅ¿e of his HiÅ¿torie it will more particularly appeare.

No Å¿ooner was his head adorned with his Imperiall Crowne,Pierce GaueÅ¿ton. but his heart longed for Pierce GaueÅ¿ton; the wicked corrupter of his youth, and the profeÅ¿Å¿ed enemie of all honeÅ¿tie and vertue. For albeit that he was exiled by the laÅ¿t King;The King breakes his Oath to recall GaueÅ¿ton who tooke an Oath of this his SucceÅ¿Å¿or, neuer to permit him (vnpuniÅ¿hed) to come backe againe into England: yet the remembrance of his villanies (conÅ¿orting
with the Kings bad nature and euill diÅ¿poÅ¿ition) was a quicke meÅ¿Å¿enger for his returne.Pierce GaueÅ¿ton is all in all. And his arriuall Å¿o aboundantly repleniÅ¿hed the Kings conceits with extraordinarie joy, that nothing elÅ¿e (in compariÅ¿on of it) gaue him anie contentment: Neither could anie man (beÅ¿ides him) expect for anie gracefull entertainement from the King.

The Nobles tell the King of his Oath.The Noble men (who perfectly knew how wickedly this GaueÅ¿ton was enclined) perceiuing that the King doted on him, and that his affections towards him were vnlimited: being perplexed with inward griefe, and fearing the Ruine which (through his inÅ¿olencie) threatened the Å¿ubuerÅ¿ion of the whole Realme; emboldened themÅ¿elues to put the King in minde of his oath. But as his conÅ¿cience troubled him not for the breach thereof: So their diÅ¿liking encreaÅ¿ed his deÅ¿ires towards GaueÅ¿ton, and to make him great. For Gaueston alone, and none but Gaueston, was likely to doe all in all: and (frowne hee that frowne would) the King cared not who was diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed; hee was reÅ¿olued, that GaueÅ¿ton Å¿hould be great. And therefore hee firÅ¿t Lorded him with the Baronie of Wallingford: GaueÅ¿ton is aduanced. and Å¿oone after, he created him Earle of Cornwall; and made him the Å¿ole and onely Commander ouer his Iewels and his TreaÅ¿ure. In which Office, Å¿o abÅ¿olute was his power, and Å¿o cunning was his craftie head, to prouide in the time of his proÅ¿peritie for aduerÅ¿e fortune which might enÅ¿ue; that Å¿ecretly he conueyed beyond the Sea a faire Table and TreÅ¿Å¿els,He conueyes the Kings Iewels out of the Realme. all made of beaten gold, and manie rich and precious Ornaments and Iewels, to the great hurt and prejudice of the King and of this Realme.

Hee alÅ¿o tooke much pleaÅ¿ure to feede the Kings fancies with great varietie of new delights;The King liueth looÅ¿ely and lewdly. and by his example, hee enured him to Banquet, Drinke, and to CarowÅ¿e beyond meaÅ¿ure: And his diÅ¿honeÅ¿t perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions and enticements made him careleÅ¿Å¿e of the Bed and of the Å¿ocietie and fellowÅ¿hip of IÅ¿abell his Religious and vertuous Queene, the daughter of the French King Philip the faire, and Å¿iÅ¿ter to his SucceÅ¿Å¿or Charles the fourth; and trayned him to the adulterous conÅ¿ortÅ¿hip of wanton Curtizans and Å¿hameleÅ¿Å¿e Whores.

The Queene in vaine Å¿eeketh to reclaime the King.The Queene (who Å¿orrowed hereat beyond meaÅ¿ure) repoÅ¿ed all means for redreÅ¿Å¿e of thoÅ¿e her vnÅ¿ufferable wrongs in her prayers vnto God, and in her modeÅ¿t wooings for her Kings loue. But all her endeuours proued nothing at all: For the beames of her excellent vertues could not pierce the thicke clouds of his vanities; neither could her teares or her groanes mollifie his hard heart, which Å¿urfetted vpon too much plentie of loathÅ¿ome Å¿innes.

The common people gaue large libertie to their Tongues,The people talke of the Kings euill life. to Å¿peake and to talke reproachfully, and to the Kings diÅ¿grace. Hee knew it well; he heard it; and cared not for it: but was reÅ¿olued to perÅ¿euere in thoÅ¿e vngodly courÅ¿es, which by Pierce GaueÅ¿ton were contriued and propoÅ¿ed vnto him.

The Noblemen, and Å¿uch as by reaÅ¿on of their Offices and Places were of the Kings Councell; did (in their particulars) aduenture manie times Å¿ecretly to informe him of the lewdneÅ¿Å¿e of Pierce GaueÅ¿ton; and that both Å¿trangers, and alÅ¿o his owne people, did Å¿trangely Å¿peake of him and of his Gouernment: which was altogether eclipÅ¿ed by the foule interpoÅ¿ition of his vices betwixt himÅ¿elfe and it. But their labour was quite loÅ¿t,The King cares not for good counÅ¿ell. and their fidelitie was requited with vnthankfull frownes; rather teÅ¿tifying his determination to continue Å¿ubject (though he were a King) to his follies, than in anie Å¿ort to amend anie thing which was amiÅ¿Å¿e.

When nothing could preuaile, either to reforme the King,A petition for GaueÅ¿tons baniÅ¿hment. or to make him careleÅ¿Å¿e of Pierce GaueÅ¿ton; the Lords and Barons of this Kingdome began Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to conÅ¿ult and to take another courÅ¿e. For they preferred their generall Petition to the King: wherein they plainely diÅ¿couered the fouleneÅ¿Å¿e of his faults, and the Å¿orrow of his beÅ¿t affected Å¿ubjects, for that his MajeÅ¿tie (more than was fitting or comely) was guided and gouerned by Pierce GaueÅ¿ton: and earneÅ¿tly entreated him to be pleaÅ¿ed (for the preuenting of Å¿uch miÅ¿chiefes as were otherwiÅ¿e likely to enÅ¿ue) to baniÅ¿h that lewd Companion both from his Court and Kingdome.

The King perceiuing that his Nobles were reÅ¿olued to vrge his conÅ¿ent vnto Pierce GaueÅ¿tons Exile, agreed (though vnwillingly) thereunto: yea, in Å¿uch a diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed humor graunted he their requeÅ¿t, that thereby they might well vnderÅ¿tand,GaueÅ¿ton is baniÅ¿hed into Ireland. The King Å¿ends comfortable meÅ¿Å¿ages vnto GaueÅ¿ton. GaueÅ¿ton is made Gouernour of Ireland. The King Å¿ends him Iewels and Money. that his heart Å¿ubÅ¿cribed not to their deÅ¿ires. But away he was Å¿ent into Ireland: Where he was no Å¿ooner arriued, but by meÅ¿Å¿engers Å¿ent to him by the King, he was required to be jocund and chearefull in his baniÅ¿hment; for that his abÅ¿ence Å¿hould in the end be recompenced with greater honours and more gracefull fauors than hee had formerly receiued: And for a pledge thereof, the King appointed him to be the chiefe Gouernour and higheÅ¿t Commander in that Countrey; and Å¿ent him Å¿uch Å¿tore of Plate, Iewels, and Coyne, both of Siluer and of Gold, that he might well thinke, that his baniÅ¿hment was but an honorable EmbaÅ¿Å¿ade, and an occaÅ¿ion thereby preÅ¿ented by good fortune to the King, to make him the more potent and more rich.

The Nobles doe Å¿ue for his returne.And beÅ¿ides all this, the Kings diÅ¿contented paÅ¿Å¿ions Å¿o Å¿wayed in him, and GaueÅ¿tons abÅ¿ence Å¿o much perplexed him; that his Nobles (being in hope of future amendment of all things which had beene done amiÅ¿Å¿e,GaueÅ¿ton is recalled. and to pleaÅ¿e the King) freely, and of their owne accords, moued the King for his returne. But when he came back againe,GaueÅ¿ton is wicked and inÅ¿olent. Å¿o Å¿trongly and Å¿o Å¿trangely was hee Å¿upported by the publike fauors and vnremoueable loue of the King; that with greater inÅ¿olencie and pride than before hee practiÅ¿ed manie more notorious villanies than euer he had done.GaueÅ¿ton is baniÅ¿hed againe. He is recalled. So that (by meanes of the inceÅ¿Å¿ant importunitie of the Nobles) hee was againe baniÅ¿hed into Flanders: where hee remained not long, but the king called him backe againe.

ThoÅ¿e his Exiles (thus procured by the Lords and Barons of this kingdome, and their conÅ¿ents to call him home againe) might haue reclaymed him from his foule and groÅ¿Å¿e errors, if wiÅ¿dome and vertue had in anie Å¿ort beene entertained by him.GaueÅ¿ton boaÅ¿teth of his wicked courÅ¿es. But in Å¿tead of changing his bad nature into good qualities; hee tooke an extraordinarie delight to glorie in his owne Å¿inne; and to boaÅ¿t, how he miÅ¿-led the king. He alÅ¿o skornefully deÅ¿piÅ¿ed the greateÅ¿t Nobles of this Land,He skornes the Nobles. and abuÅ¿ed them at their faces: and by vntrue informations (which priuately and behind their backs he gaue vnto the king) he cauÅ¿ed them to be frowned on; and did all things in Å¿uch a diÅ¿ordered faÅ¿hion, without controlment, that the Barons with one conÅ¿ent (being hopeleÅ¿Å¿e of redreÅ¿Å¿e,The Barons Å¿trike off GaueÅ¿tons head. and being vnable anie longer to Å¿upport Å¿uch a deÅ¿piÅ¿ed burthen) beÅ¿ieged him, being in a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle; which they wonne: and to redeeme the kings honour,The King is impatient for GaueÅ¿tons death. and to procure their owne liberties, and the welfare of the Commonweale; they cauÅ¿ed his head to be Å¿mitten off. But Å¿o highly was the king diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed thereat, that alwaies from thenceforth he endeauoured nothing more, than by crueltie and by tyrannie to reuenge his death.

The King fauoreth the two Spencers.And then (to anger his Nobilitie) he entertained into his neareÅ¿t familiaritie and counÅ¿ailes the two Spencers, Sir Hugh the father, and Sir Hugh the Å¿onne; men as graceleÅ¿Å¿e, and as odious to the Lords and common people,The Spencers are as bad as was GaueÅ¿ton as the other was. Their aduice enclined the king to proÅ¿ecute his lewd and wanton courÅ¿e of life among laÅ¿ciuious and wanton Whores and Concubines, and to Å¿et at naught the Å¿weet companie of his modeÅ¿t and vertuous Queene: which made him a skorne to forraine Princes, and batefull in the Å¿ight of all honeÅ¿t men.The fruits of euill gouernment. Yet the king, in deÅ¿pight of his greateÅ¿t Lords, Å¿upported the two Spencers in all things which they would take in hand.

But his euill gouernment, both of himÅ¿elfe and of his kingdome,The King and his Nobles are at variance. reuiued new diÅ¿cords betweene the king and his Barons: and by meanes thereof, the affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es of the Commonweale were ill managed; and Å¿uch as lay in wait to aduance their EÅ¿tates by reaÅ¿on of this diÅ¿Å¿ention, had now gotten fit oportunitie to put in practiÅ¿e what they pleaÅ¿ed. Among which, Robert le Bruce (returning from Norway into Scotland) was joyfully receiued there,Robert le BruÅ¿e being recrowned, inuadeth England. 7. 1313. The Battaile of EÅ¿treuelyne and was the Å¿econd time crowned king of that kingdome: And then he leuied a Å¿trong Armie, with which he entred into the Marches of England foure or fiue dayes journey; and with fire and Å¿word miÅ¿erably waÅ¿ted and deÅ¿olated thoÅ¿e Countries, vntill hee was encountred by the king, and compelled to retyre.

But king Edward fighting a Battaile with the ScotiÅ¿h power within the borders of their owne Countrey, receiued the ouerthrow: and hauing Å¿eene the Å¿laughter of manie thouÅ¿ands in his Armie (among which, were Gilbert de Clare Earle of GloceÅ¿ter, The King receiueth a great ouerthrow. and two and fortie other Lords, and more than threeÅ¿core knights and Baronets, beÅ¿ides two and twentie men of Name, who were taken priÅ¿oners) hee was compelled (for his owne Å¿afetie) Å¿hamefully to flye, and with diÅ¿honourable Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e to returne againe into England. The King flyeth. Where he was (eftÅ¿oones) perplexed and put to much trouble by the vntrue and deÅ¿perate attempt of one Iohn Poydras a Tanners Å¿onne dwelling in Exeter: Iohn Poydras diÅ¿couered and executed who boldly affirmed himÅ¿elfe to be the truly begotten Å¿onne of the laÅ¿t king, and Å¿aid, That he was changed in his Cradle by his NurÅ¿e for a Carters child; and offered diuers colourable proofes for the Å¿ame: and among the reÅ¿t, he Å¿trongly inÅ¿tanced vpon the vnworthie and baÅ¿e conditions of the king; Å¿orting to none Å¿o fitly, as vnto one of obÅ¿cure and of common birth.

This his clayme, and bold aÅ¿Å¿ertions, quickly abuÅ¿ed the eares and the hearts of the vulgar, and drew manie of them (for want of wiÅ¿dome and obedience) to flocke vnto him, as to their king. But at length he was apprehended; and hauing confeÅ¿Å¿ed his TreaÅ¿on and his folly, and being arraigned, conuicted, and condemned, hee was executed according to his deÅ¿erts.

The King is ouerthrown the Å¿econd time by the Scots. A miÅ¿erably diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed people.The King (intending to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e the Scots, and to correct them for their inÅ¿olencie and folly) encountred them with his whole Armie, but receiued a notorious ouerthrow; and (being Å¿cornfully checked and diÅ¿graced by his bold and Å¿awcie enemies) hee returned home again with great ignominie and Å¿hame, leauing his poore Å¿ubiects in the North, Å¿o miÅ¿erably diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed and vnrelieued, as euer any people were forÅ¿aken by an vnworthie and a careleÅ¿Å¿e King.

The vÅ¿e of this History.Of theÅ¿e diÅ¿graces, and of theÅ¿e troubles, we make this profitable vÅ¿e: That as the heroicall vertues of excellent Princes are crowned with many bleÅ¿Å¿ings from aboue; Å¿o for the iniquitie and hainous tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ions of wicked and vngodly Kings, both themÅ¿elues and their people likewiÅ¿e, are Å¿euerely puniÅ¿hed by God, before whom Princes muÅ¿t fall as well as the common Å¿ubiects, except their true and heartie repentance (being ioyned with the amendment of their liues) doe (in Å¿eaÅ¿on) procure his mercie and his fauour.

The Nobles endeuour reformation.The Peeres and the Nobles of this Kingdome (perceiuing that the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the Common-weale did daily encreaÅ¿e and growe more dangerous) determined (like good PhyÅ¿itians) narrowly to Å¿earch out the cauÅ¿es of theÅ¿e maladies, and to finde Å¿ome remedie to cure them before it were too late.They complain on the two Spencers. The miÅ¿erable examples of all kinds of wickedneÅ¿Å¿e which preÅ¿ented themÅ¿elues vnto their view, emboldned them to informe the King, That the two Spencers and their miÅ¿guiding of the State (by whom only, and by none other the King was counÅ¿ailed and directed) were the immediat occaÅ¿ioners of all thoÅ¿e miÅ¿chiefes and calamities, which miÅ¿erably afflicted and tormented the whole Kingdome. They plainly tolde him, That Å¿uch was their intereÅ¿t in the Kings perÅ¿on, and in his gouernment of his people, that they were bound (in honour, and for conÅ¿cience Å¿ake) to informe his HighneÅ¿Å¿e of all Å¿uch miÅ¿demeanors
committed by any of his Å¿ubiects as tended to the Å¿ubuerÅ¿ion of the State, and the diÅ¿turbing of the common peace therof: and then they became importunat Å¿utors to his MaieÅ¿tie, That he would be pleaÅ¿ed to put from him the two Spencers, who corrupted him with monÅ¿trous vices, and made him altogether careleÅ¿Å¿e of thoÅ¿e duties which by Almightie God were required at his hands. They told him likewiÅ¿e, That as Å¿ubiection belonged to the people; Å¿o the King was bound to protect them, and that (vnconÅ¿cionably and moÅ¿t diÅ¿honorably) he had left his Commons in the North, to the rage and rigor of the Scots, The reÅ¿olution of the Nobles touching the two Spencers. and to all extremities of hunger and of other wants: and that if he pleaÅ¿ed not (vpon their humble entreaty and requeÅ¿t) to caÅ¿Å¿ier thoÅ¿e two graceleÅ¿Å¿e CounÅ¿ailors, of their places and from his Å¿eruice; they then muÅ¿t and would preÅ¿ume to doe it, though it were with the hazard and perill of their owne liues.

The king could not chooÅ¿e but hearken to this grieuous and true report. For as it was founded and grounded vpon conÅ¿cience, and on duetie; Å¿o was it maintained with a conÅ¿tant reÅ¿olution to reforme that which was amiÅ¿Å¿e. He bit his lip thereat, and his countenance proclaimed his diÅ¿contentment.The King frowneth on his Nobles. Inwardly he meditated and deuiÅ¿ed how he might Å¿urpriÅ¿e thoÅ¿e Noble-men, who (moÅ¿t of all) Å¿tomacked the two Spencers, whom Å¿o immoderatly hee did loue, yet inwardly his tongue gaue the Barons a pleaÅ¿ing anÅ¿were; Å¿o that hee forthwith Å¿ommoned his high Court of Parliament:A ParlameÌt. and pretending a reformation of all things that were conceiued to be amiÅ¿Å¿e, he gladded the hearts of his Nobles and Commons exceedingly. But the Lords and Barons (although they reioiced much that the time would Å¿hortly come,The Nobles do Å¿tand vpon their guard. in which theÅ¿e matters Å¿hould be Å¿ubÅ¿tantially debated on) yet were they iealous, and Å¿uÅ¿pected leÅ¿t the king intended their Å¿urpriÅ¿al in that Å¿olemn meeting: wherfore the greater numbers of them repaired vnto London, beeing Å¿trongly garded with a braue Armie of Å¿ufficient and gallant men, which were all cloathed in a like Liuerie; whereat the king was highly diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed: but moÅ¿t of all it grieued him, that hee knew the Barons would haue their owne wil by taking and Å¿eparating from him the two Spencers (who were more deer to him then his Queen and children,How the king loued the two Spencers. The two Spencers are baniÅ¿hed for euer. and all his friends beÅ¿ide) and in the end (among many other things) it was (by the whole Parliament) enacted, That they Å¿hould bee exiled during their liues, and neuer bee licenÅ¿ed by the king to returne againe into England.

This being thus concluded, the Barons (who longed to Å¿ee the two Spencers vnder Å¿aile) cauÅ¿ed certaine Ships to bee prepared, in
which they were embarked and Å¿ent away. So that now all men were well pleaÅ¿ed except the King; whome their abÅ¿ence vexed at the heart:The King hateth his Barons. and in all things he endeuoured plainely to expreÅ¿Å¿e his hatred and his anger towards the Barons, who had enforced him to conÅ¿ent vnto their baniÅ¿hment. And to expreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ame more fully; he was informed, that the younger Spencer had Å¿trengthened himÅ¿elfe with a few good Shippes;The younger Spencer becomes a Pyrate. and that he lay (as a Grand Pyrate) coaÅ¿ting vpon the Narrow Seas, robbing, ranÅ¿acking, and Å¿poyling the Marchants, and all Nations who paÅ¿Å¿ed by them; but eÅ¿pecially, and chiefely, Å¿uch as were of this Kingdome. And although great Å¿ute was made vnto the King, that a conuenient Fleet might be prepared for his Å¿urprizall; and that hee might be produced vnto judgement,The grieued Lords complain, but the King laughs. and receiue Å¿uch puniÅ¿hment as the Lawes of this Kingdome appointed for the cutting off of Å¿uch a notorious Theefe: yet the King Å¿myled, and was inwardly glad to heare this newes, and turned a deafe eare to their requeÅ¿t; and was Å¿o farre off from prouiding to fetch him in, that (pardoning all his offences,The Spencers are recalled, and honored. and to deÅ¿pight his Barons) hee recalled them both from their BaniÅ¿hment, and honoured them with more Dignities, Offices, and Authoritie, than euer he had done before.

ANNO 13.This thing being thus Å¿trangely performed by the King, and the daily vnÅ¿ufferable injuries and inÅ¿olencie of the two Spencers (who skorned and derided the Nobles, as being vnable to controll them,The Spencers doe skorne and deride the Nobles. or to doe them anie harme) were Å¿ufficient warnings to the Barons to looke vnto themÅ¿elues, and to prouide for their owne Å¿afetie, before it were too late. Wherefore, Å¿eeing that neither entreatie nor Law could right their wrongs; they rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong Armie,The Barons doe rayÅ¿e a Å¿trong armie. and boldly marched into the field: And the King, with the two Spencers, and Å¿ome others of the Nobles, did the like. And after manie Å¿harpe Bickerings and Encounters both their Armies met,The King doth the like. and fought on either part with Å¿uch obÅ¿tinate deÅ¿ire to reuenge, that he was Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be the moÅ¿t valiant man among them, who could and did drench his Å¿word deepeÅ¿t in the moÅ¿t bloud.A cruell Battaile. The Noblemen now forgat, that vndutifully they fought againÅ¿t their Soueraigne Lord: and the King would not by anie meanes know, that his Tyrannie had compelled them to take Armes. Kindred, Alliance, Countrey, Religion, Neighbourhood, nor anie other reÅ¿pect now preuailed to winne fauour: but furie made them truÅ¿t to their weapons, and death Å¿tickled the controuerÅ¿ie betwixt them.The Barons are ouerthrowne. In the end, when manie of the Barons, and thouÅ¿ands of their adherents were Å¿laine; they fled, and were purÅ¿ued
by the King, who (obtaining the victorie) neuer ceaÅ¿ed the purÅ¿uit vntill he had taken the Earles of LancaÅ¿ter, Hereford, and manie other Lords, of which hee cauÅ¿ed two and twentie to looÅ¿e their heads in Å¿undrie places of this Realme,Twentie and two Lords beheaded. to the great aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment of the reÅ¿t, and to the terror of the vulgar Å¿ort.

The Scots (being Å¿ecretly informed that King Edward was reÅ¿olued to inuade their Countrey, ANNO 15. The Scots do inuade Ireland. The Scots are ouerthrown. and to reuenge thoÅ¿e indignities and thoÅ¿e wrongs, which by the incurÅ¿ions and inuaÅ¿ions of Robert le BruÅ¿e their vÅ¿urping King, he had receiued) endeuoured to diuert his purpoÅ¿e another way; Å¿o that they entred into Ireland with a copious Armie. But the king (who was not ignorant of their determination) made Å¿uch prouiÅ¿ion againÅ¿t their landing there, that the greater number of thoÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿ailants were Å¿laine, and the reÅ¿t (being vtterly ouerthrowne) were compelled to flie vnto their Ships, and Å¿hamefully to returne into their owne Countrey.The King entereth into Scotland with an Armie.

The king was now perÅ¿waded that Å¿carcely any Å¿trength could withÅ¿tand Å¿o great a power as hee had leuied, and that the Scots Å¿hould now be called to a Å¿trict account for all their inroades, incurÅ¿ions, inuaÅ¿ions, murthers, robberies, and Å¿poyles. And for the effecting thereof, he conducted his Armie into Scotland, where the Nobles and the other inhabitants of that land (being armed well, and being in number many thouÅ¿ands) for many daies by continuall preparations, made a Å¿hew to giue battaile to king Edward, when
as (indeede) they meant nothing leÅ¿Å¿e.The Scots do retyre into the Woods & Mountaines. For when King Edward approached neere vnto them, they craftily, yet Å¿toutly and Å¿trongly, retyred manie myles, and at length withdrew themÅ¿elues into the Woods, ForeÅ¿ts, and Mountaines: where they Å¿oone cloyed, wearied, and waÅ¿ted the EngliÅ¿h forces;The EngliÅ¿h Armie is tyred out. partly with the vneaÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of thoÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ages, and partly with Å¿uch Stormes, TempeÅ¿ts, Raine, Hayle, Snow, FroÅ¿ts, and other diÅ¿tempered weather, as vÅ¿ually in thoÅ¿e places were too bitter and too Å¿harpe.

The Kings Armie is afflicted.And beÅ¿ides all this, the want of victuals and other neceÅ¿Å¿aries Å¿o grieuouÅ¿ly afflicted the Kings Armie with mortalitie and death, that (not hauing performed anie thing worthie a Kings care and trauaile) he began to retyre: which when the Scots perceiued, they purÅ¿ued and hunted him with much crueltie and violence: So that (finding his forces to be broken,The King is purÅ¿ued, and flyeth. and his Armie Å¿cattered) the Scots gaue a bold onÅ¿et vpon the King himÅ¿elfe, and enforced him to Å¿aue his life by an ignominious flight, and to leaue behinde him his TreaÅ¿ure,The King loÅ¿eth his TreaÅ¿ure and prouiÅ¿ions. Ordinance, and all his beÅ¿t prouiÅ¿ions, whereat they made great jolitie and mirth.

This laÅ¿t diÅ¿aÅ¿ter and this laÅ¿t danger (which King Edward by a Å¿hamefull flight eÅ¿caped) was principally occaÅ¿ioned by Sir Andrew Harkley; Sir Andrew Harkley Earle of Carlile beheaded. whome the King had created Earle of Carlyle, for his great Å¿eruice in his behalfe againÅ¿t his Barons in their late ouerthrow: for hee (hauing Å¿ecretly receiued from the Scots a great Å¿umme of money for a bribe) practiÅ¿ed to betray the King: for which offence he loÅ¿t his head.

The Queene flyeth into France, and carrieth the prince with her.The Queene (knowing that the two Spencers enuied her deepely at the heart, and that by their perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions the King refuÅ¿ed to keepe her companie, and Å¿olaced himÅ¿elfe too too wantonly with lewd and laÅ¿ciuious Å¿trumpets; and pitying the late Å¿laughter and bloudie executions of verie manie of the Nobilitie, and perceiuing that the affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of the Commonweale were made Å¿lauiÅ¿h and Å¿eruile to all misfortunes) taking with her the young Prince Edward her Å¿onne, fled into France to her brother King Charles: She is kindly entertained by her brother the King. by whome Å¿hee was receiued louingly, and was recomforted by earneÅ¿t promiÅ¿es and oaths, That by his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, and at his coÅ¿ts, her wrongs, and this whole Kingdomes ruines, Å¿hould be repaired. And not long after, the Barons (by their letters) offered their beÅ¿t Å¿eruice to her and to the Prince her Å¿onne;The Barons doe offer her their Å¿eruice. and did proteÅ¿t, That if Å¿hee could returne Å¿trengthened onely with the helpe of one thouÅ¿and valiant men at armes, they would thereto adde Å¿o great a Å¿trength as Å¿hould Å¿uffice to make the two Spencers feele the Å¿mart of their vnÅ¿ufferable follies.

This proffer exceedingly rejoyced the Queene,The Spencers do bribe the French King with the Kings Money and Iewels. The French King checketh the Queene his Å¿iÅ¿ter. The Pope and his Cardinals are bribed. Sir Robert Earle of Arthois a friend to the Queen The Queene and Prince flye into the Empire. They are kindly entertained by the Earle of Henault. The Queene and Prince doe land in England. ANNO 19. 1325. The Nobles & Commons doe repaire to the Queene and Prince. The BiÅ¿hop of Exeter beheaded by the Londoners. The King goeth toward Wales. The Londoners take the Tower. and daily fedde her conceits with freÅ¿h hopes of fortunate Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e at the laÅ¿t. But the two Spencers (greatly fearing the euent of her returne, if the French King Å¿hould take her part, and making the Kings Coyne and his TreaÅ¿ure their beÅ¿t Aduocates to plead their caÅ¿e) Å¿o corrupted King Charles and his Councell of EÅ¿tate with vnvaluable preÅ¿ents of Gold, of Siluer, and of rich Iewels, that not onely all aide and Å¿uccour was denyed to her by her owne brother; but in verie Å¿harpe and in quicke manner Å¿hee was by him reproued and blamed, as being fooliÅ¿hly afraid of her owne Å¿hadow: and as hauing vnwiÅ¿ely and vndutifully forÅ¿aken the companie of her Lord and kinde husband. The Pope likewiÅ¿e, and manie of his chiefeÅ¿t Cardinals (being by like rewards engaged by the two Spencers) required the French King (vpon the penaltie of CurÅ¿ing) to Å¿end the Queene and the young Prince her Å¿onne to King Edward. And doubtleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hee had vnnaturally beene betrayed by her owne brother, if Å¿ecretly and Å¿peedily her Å¿elfe and her young Å¿onne had not been conueyed into the Empire by Sir Robert of Arthois, her neere and kinde couÅ¿in and friend: where they were with vnexpected and extraordinarie joy receiued and welcommed by the Earle of Henault, and by Sir Iohn of Henault, Lord Beaumont his brother; who (being accompanied with three hundred Knights and Å¿elected men of Armes) went with her and with her Å¿onne into England.

Vpon the firÅ¿t intelligence giuen of their landing, the Lords and Barons, with gladded hearts and luÅ¿tie troupes of reÅ¿olued Gallants (who were Å¿oundly and at all points armed) repaired euerie day to the Queene and Prince, and hourely their forces were encreaÅ¿ed. So that the King hauing notice of theÅ¿e new troubles, left the Gouernment of the Citie of London to his chiefeÅ¿t TreaÅ¿urer Walter Stapleton then BiÅ¿hop of Exeter (who was an inward friend to the two Spencers, and a profeÅ¿Å¿ed enemie to the Queene, and hated generally by the inhabitants of that Citie) and the King haÅ¿ted vnto the Marches of Wales for the preÅ¿ent leuying of an Armie. But hee was no Å¿ooner on his journey, but the Londoners (skorning the Gouernment of their prowd and inÅ¿olent Commander) apprehended him; and without anie lawfull proceedings, or judiciall Sentence, cauÅ¿ed his head to be Å¿mitten off at the Standard in Cheape: and then they Å¿uddenly, and with great violence, ruÅ¿hed into the Tower of London; where they Å¿lew all Å¿uch as they found there: and kept both it and that Citie to the vÅ¿e of the Queene and of the young Prince her Å¿onne.

The King changeth his purpoÅ¿e. The King fortifieth BriÅ¿toll. The Queene winneth BriÅ¿toll. The King is beÅ¿ieged in the CaÅ¿tle. EÅ¿t ineuitabile Fatum. A Å¿trange matter. The King and Sir Hugh Spencer the younger are taken. The CaÅ¿tle of BriÅ¿toll yeeldeth. Sir Hugh Spencer the father, and the Earle of Arundell are beheaded. The Queene and Prince doe march toward London. The younger Spencer is publikely derided. He is cruelly executed.As Å¿oone as King Edward was reÅ¿olued and informed of this Reuolt; hee deÅ¿iÅ¿ted from his intended purpoÅ¿e, and poÅ¿ted vnto BriÅ¿tow, and fortified it in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t manner that hee was able; and committed the defence thereof to the Earle of Arundell, and to Sir Hugh Spencer the father: and himÅ¿elfe (with Sir Hugh the Å¿onne) entred into the CaÅ¿tle there, and were determined to defend it with all their Å¿trength. But within few dayes after, the Å¿aid Citie was beÅ¿ieged, aÅ¿Å¿aulted, and wonne by the Queene and by the Barons: who (committing the two Earles, and diuers others of the chiefeÅ¿t note, vnto Å¿afe keeping) beÅ¿ieged the CaÅ¿tle in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that the King and his Minion (diÅ¿truÅ¿ting the euent) Å¿tole away Å¿ecretly in the night, and put themÅ¿elues into a little FiÅ¿her-boat. Yet Å¿uch was the will and pleaÅ¿ure of GOD (to make them to know him by their future miÅ¿eries) that euerie day, for a weeke and more, the Å¿ame Boat (by reaÅ¿on of a contrarie winde) was driuen backe, neare to the Å¿aid CaÅ¿tle: Which being at length perceiued and obÅ¿erued by the Lord Beaumont, hee chaÅ¿ed the FiÅ¿her-boat with a Å¿mall veÅ¿Å¿ell, and boarded her, and found in her the King and Sir Hugh Spencer the Å¿onne, whome they Å¿o much deÅ¿ired, and brought them to the Queene; who preÅ¿ented them before the CaÅ¿tles view: and vpon the Å¿ight of them, the beÅ¿ieged yeelded the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of their Fort into the Queenes hands. Then were the heads of Sir Hugh Spencer the father, Earle of WincheÅ¿ter, and of Iohn Earle of Arundell (whoÅ¿e daughter was married to the younger Spencer) Å¿mitten off. And the King being committed vnto honorable and Å¿afe keeping; the Queene, with the young Prince her Å¿onne, beeing accompanied with the Barons and a Å¿trong Armie, marched towards London; carrying with them Sir Hugh Spencer the Å¿onne as a Å¿laue: before whom, certaine vnworthie and baÅ¿e Fidlers (vpon Pypes which they had made of Reedes) skornfully played, skipped, and Å¿ung, in euerie Towne which they paÅ¿Å¿ed through. And being come to the Citie of London, hee was faÅ¿t bound vpon the top of an high Ladder; and (his priuie members and his heart being Å¿euered from his bodie and burned) his head was forthwith cut off and Å¿et vpon London Bridge.

A iuÅ¿t reward for their wickedneÅ¿Å¿e.Thus GODS judgements purÅ¿ued thoÅ¿e two vngodly and ambitious caitiues: by whoÅ¿e lewd aduice and euill counÅ¿ell the King forÅ¿ooke the bed and companie of the Queene his wife; liued wickedly; made hauocke of his Nobilitie; neglected his common People; permitted his Enemies (to his diÅ¿grace) to triumph and to inÅ¿ult ouer him; and gouerned more like a Tyrant than a King.

And thus thoÅ¿e times of Trouble being now againe bleÅ¿Å¿ed with a happie Peace,Sir Iohn of Henault and his companie are feaÅ¿ted and rewarded. the Queene bountifully feaÅ¿ted and rewarded Sir Iohn of Henault, Lord Beaumont, and all his aÅ¿Å¿ociates: who taking leaue, departed; and were receiued into their Countrey with much joy and great honour.

And then the Queene and the young Prince (to reforme Å¿uch things as were amiÅ¿Å¿e,A Parliament. and to Å¿ettle a better courÅ¿e of Gouernment within this Land) aÅ¿Å¿embled an High Court of Parliament at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter. In which, the King, by a generall conÅ¿ent, was depoÅ¿ed:The King is depoÅ¿ed. Prince Edward crowned King. and (being verie honourably reÅ¿pected and attended) he was committed to the CaÅ¿tle of Killingworth; and Prince Edward was crowned King. And not long after, the King being remoued to the CaÅ¿tle of Corff, was wickedly aÅ¿Å¿ayled by his Keepers: who through a Horne which they did put into his fundament, pierced his guts with a burning Spit, and murdered him;The old King is murdered. when hee had raigned almoÅ¿t nineteene yeres.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING EDVVARD THE THIRD.
div.p: EDVVARD the third, being of the age of fifteene yeares; and crowned King, whileÅ¿t his depoÅ¿ed father liued: was chiefely directed in his younger yeares by the aduice and counÅ¿ell of Queene IÅ¿abell his mother, and of his vncle Edmund of WoodÅ¿tock Earle of Kent, and of Sir Roger Mortymer: Sir Roger Mortymer wickedly procured the murder of the old King. which knight (to intereÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe more eÅ¿pecially in the Queenes loue) traiterouÅ¿ly conÅ¿pired and procured the murder of the laÅ¿t king, by the monÅ¿trous villanie and barbarous crueltie before mentioned.

In the Å¿econd yeare of this kings Raigne, Robert le BruÅ¿e (the buÅ¿ie vÅ¿urping king of the Scots) denounced Warres againÅ¿t him and his kingdome: which occaÅ¿ioned the leuying of a Å¿trong Armie,King Edward inuadeth Scotland. which conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of foure and fiftie thouÅ¿and men; with which, the king himÅ¿elfe (being accompanied with Sir Iohn of Henault, Lord Beaumont, and fiue hundred Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen Å¿trangers his aÅ¿Å¿ociates) marched into Scotland: The Scots flye into the Woods and Mountaines. Where he hunted and chaÅ¿ed his enemies from MariÅ¿h to MariÅ¿h, from Wood to Wood, from Hill to Hill, and from Mountaine to Mountaine, for the Å¿pace of one moneth and more: yet (by reaÅ¿on of the Scots cowardiÅ¿e, which made them to skulke and runne from place to place, tyring
out the EngliÅ¿h Armie.The King returneth. The King marrieth Philip daughter to the Earle of Henault. A Parliament. PerÅ¿ons attainted. A diÅ¿honorable peace with Scotland. Their tenure is releaÅ¿ed. By reaÅ¿on of king Peters death; the Prince his Å¿ouldiours (being hopeleÅ¿Å¿e to receiue their promiÅ¿ed pay, and large rewards) and being oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with many wants, daily petitioned the Prince to Å¿upply their need. But before the Prince of Wales could enable his forces for a Å¿trong defence: the inhabitants of thoÅ¿e Countries for the moÅ¿t part reuolted from him, and dayly yeelded their Townes, Cities, Forts, and CaÅ¿tles, into the hands of the French king. King Charles of France (forgetting what he had Å¿worne, ANNO. 43 The French Name. and pleaÅ¿ing himÅ¿elfe thus quietlie to be made the Lord of all thoÅ¿e Countries which were aÅ¿Å¿igned to king Edward) conceiued Å¿trong hope, not only to defeat him vtterly of all theÅ¿e Countries, but alÅ¿o to vex him at home in his owne kingdome. div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING RICHARD THE SECOND.
div.p: RICHARD the Å¿econd (being the Son and heire of the Blacke Prince,ANNO. 1. 1377. and aged eleuen yeares, and Å¿omewhat more) was crowned king of England in the yeare of our Lord God, one thouÅ¿and three hundred and Å¿euentie Å¿euen.

In the whole courÅ¿e of his euill Gouernment,King Richards euill manners and bad Gouernment. he neglected his Nobilitie, and taxed his Subjects, to enable himÅ¿elfe to giue prodigally vnto his ill deÅ¿eruing Fauorites. So that they fell by their own weight; and he himÅ¿elfe (in the end) was enforced to endure the extremitie of his hard fortune. For being firÅ¿t diÅ¿graced by his CouÅ¿in, Henrie of Bullingbrooke Duke of Lancaster, and Å¿onne and heire to his Vncle Iohn of Gaunt; hee was at length by him (with the general conÅ¿ent of a whole Parliament) depoÅ¿ed from his Crowne, commited to PriÅ¿on, and afterwardes
wickedly murdered, as in this diÅ¿courÅ¿e of his diÅ¿ordered Gouernment, more amply it Å¿hall appeare.

The Frenchmen burne diuers townes in England.In the firÅ¿t yeare of king Richards Raigne, Charles the French king (preÅ¿uming much on his Minoritie, and being aided by the Spaniards) landed in the SouthweÅ¿t, and in the South-eaÅ¿t parts of this kingdome, and ranÅ¿acked, and burnt the Townes of Plymouth, Dartmouth, PortÅ¿mouth, Rye, and Å¿ome other Townes and Villages, coaÅ¿ting vpon the Sea, and would haue done more miÅ¿chiefe, if by the kings Vncle Edmund of Langly Earle of Cambridge, and by the Earles of Buckingham, and of Salisburie, they had not beene fought with, and beaten to their Å¿hips.

Alexander RamÅ¿eyes deÅ¿perate attempt: and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e.At the Å¿ame time alÅ¿o (by the inÅ¿tigation of the French king) one Alexander RamÅ¿ey, an approued ScottiÅ¿hman at armes, with fortie of his Company, in the depth of the night, Å¿uddenly and deÅ¿perately Å¿called the wals of the CaÅ¿tle of Barwicke: and (finding the Captaine, and all his Å¿ouldiers Å¿ecurely Å¿leeping) he tooke it without blowes; and intended alÅ¿o to haue Å¿urpriÅ¿ed the Towne. But the inhabitants, (hearing an extraordinarie noyÅ¿e and tumult in the CaÅ¿tle, and indeuouring to preuent a feared miÅ¿chiefe) hewed away the Å¿tayes of the Draw-bridge, on the Townes Å¿ide: Å¿o that when the Scots did let fall the Draw-bridge, the chaines brake, and the Bridge fell into the CaÅ¿tle Ditch. This neceÅ¿Å¿itie enforced them (as well as they were able) to fortifie the CaÅ¿tle, which on the kings behalfe, was Å¿oone beÅ¿ieged, and aÅ¿Å¿aulted by tenne thouÅ¿and men: who after many feates of Armes performed brauely by the aÅ¿Å¿ailants, and after much valor, with high courage, Å¿hewed by that Å¿mall number of valiant Scots, wonne the CaÅ¿tle, and receiued not one of them to mercie, but onely their Captaine Alexander RamÅ¿ey.

The Frenchmen land in England.And not long after, the Frenchmen landed againe in England, and did much harme at Douer, WynchelÅ¿ay, HaÅ¿tings, and at GraueÅ¿end; and returned with their booties into France: But to preuent like future miÅ¿chiefes, and to reuenge thoÅ¿e injuries done to the King and his Realme by the French King: ANNO. 3. A ParliameÌt. This Taxe cauÅ¿ed much trouble. An Armie Å¿ent into France. A Parliament was aÅ¿Å¿embled at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter. In which, a SubÅ¿idie of foure pence, for euery man, and for euery woman within this Kingdome (being aboue foureteene yeares of age) was granted to the King. The leuying whereof procured much heart-burning, which (not long after) brake forth, and endangered the whole State of the Common-weale. Yet with that monie great prouiÅ¿ion was made, and an armie of eight thouÅ¿and
men was Å¿ent into France, vnder the command of Thomas of WoodÅ¿tock the Kings Vncle: who paÅ¿Å¿ing ouer the faire and great Riuers of Soame, OyÅ¿e, and Marne, Å¿poiled, and burnt all the Countries, and ranÅ¿omed the inhabitants, vntill he came into Brittaine; where he was receiued by the Duke Iohn Mountford with all friendly entertainment, and much joy.

This lewd and damnable doctrine Å¿o infatuated and infected the RuÅ¿ticks from Shire to Shire, that (at length) it was Å¿pread in the Citie of London, where the meaneÅ¿t, and the baÅ¿eÅ¿t Å¿ort (being a multitude, who egerly enuyed the proÅ¿peritie of the more worthie inhabitants, and greedily coueted to be enriched with their Å¿ubÅ¿tance) were in great hope (by Rebellious mutening) to make vtter hauoke and Å¿poyle of all things at their pleaÅ¿ure. Of this rude and raskall rout,Watt Tyler, Iohn Wall, Iack Straw and Iack Shepheard, Captaines in this Rebellion Wat Tylar (who by his profeÅ¿Å¿ion was a Taylor) was made Captaine, to command the reÅ¿t: and the Å¿aid Iohn Wall, Iack Straw, Iack Shepard, and Å¿ome others, were made chiefe directors, and their leaders. they marched towards London, beating downe the houÅ¿es, and rifling all the moueables of all Å¿uch as were profeÅ¿Å¿ors of the Law;How they paÅ¿Å¿ed towards London. and compelling all Knights and Gentlemen either to flye before their comming, or to be partakers in this vprore.
