But (to preuent that miÅ¿chiefe) a free entrance was giuen them into the Citie: where the greateÅ¿t men made them the beÅ¿t cheere, and fed them with their chiefeÅ¿t dainties; and by liberall gifts (in Å¿ome Å¿ort) pacified their furie and their rage.

Then they entred into the Sauoy (which then belonged to Iohn of Gaunt Duke of LancaÅ¿ter the Kings Vncle) which houÅ¿e they rifled,The Sauoy burned. burnt, and wickedly murdered all his Officers whom they found there.The Innes of Court rifled. They alÅ¿o robbed all the Innes of Court; burnt their Law-bookes; and Å¿acrilegiouÅ¿ly they Å¿tole in all Churches, and in all Religious HouÅ¿es;They commit Å¿acriledg. accounting their monÅ¿trous thefts to bee no Å¿inne.

They alÅ¿o releaÅ¿ed out of all PriÅ¿ons all manner of offenders whatÅ¿oeuer.PriÅ¿oners enlarged. Wat Tylars crueltie to his old maÅ¿ter. Among Å¿undrie other outrages which they then committed, Their chiefeÅ¿t Ring-leader Wat Tylar Å¿ent for his old MaÅ¿ter, named Richard Lion, a worthie and graue Citizen, from whom (during the time of his Å¿eruice) he had receiued for a foule offence Å¿ome Å¿mal correction: and (for a reuenge) without other iudgment, according to his graceleÅ¿Å¿e command,All Å¿trangers are rifled. his head was Å¿triken off, and borne vpon a Launce before him in the Å¿treets. And at length (their numbers being encreaÅ¿ed to threeÅ¿core thouÅ¿and) they came to Saint Katherines, neere to the Kings lodging; where they remained that night. The next morning they Å¿ent againe to the King:The King goeth to Mile-end-Greene to Å¿peake with the Rebels. Wat Tylor entreth into the Tower. He robbeth the Kings Mother. INprimis, That hee would not permit the Å¿aid Duke of Hartford (who was Å¿o much wronged for his good aduice and counÅ¿ell touching the Kings Gouernment) to fight the Combate againÅ¿t the falÅ¿ely accuÅ¿ing Thomas Mowbray Duke of Norfolke, and yet baniÅ¿hed him vniuÅ¿tly for Å¿ix yeares.

div.p:
ALTHOVGH the Crowne of England, ANNO. 1. 1399. in right (if Richard the depoÅ¿ed king Å¿hould die without iÅ¿Å¿ue) was by Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion to deÅ¿cend vnto Edmund Mortimer Earle of March (the Son and heire of Edmund Mortimer, by Philip his wife, who was the daughter and heire of Lionel Duke of Clarence, the third Å¿onne of Edward the third: Yet his CouÅ¿in Henrie of Bullinbrooke Duke of Hartford, and Å¿onne and heire vnto Iohn of Gaunt the yonger brother of the Å¿aid Lionel, was elected and crowned king. And forthwith hee created his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne Henrie, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, and Earle of Chester: and Å¿ummoned his High Court of Parliament, in which an order was preÅ¿cribed and Å¿et downe, for the Å¿afe keeping, and for the honourable attendance, and maintaining of Richard the late king. But his depoÅ¿ing, impriÅ¿onment, and all the former proceedings which were had againÅ¿t him,Iohn BiÅ¿hop of Carleyl condemneth the former proceedings againÅ¿t King Richard. were in the Å¿ame AÅ¿Å¿embly publikely condemned and reprooued by Iohn BiÅ¿hop of Carlile, as hatefull vnto God, trayterous towardes the wronged king, and infamous among good men. For he auerred boldly, That if he were not a good king, yet more iniurie was done vnto him then ordinarily is done to Murderers, and to Theeues: becauÅ¿e they are not (as he was) condemned, before they had made their
anÅ¿were to the obiected crime, before Iudges which were indifferent,The BiÅ¿hop of Carleyl is attached. and pronounced their iudgement vpon good proofe. But aÅ¿Å¿oone as hee had ended his Å¿peech: he was attached by the Earle MarÅ¿hal; and committed to Å¿trait PriÅ¿on in the Abbey of Saint Albons. And then (among manie other things in the Å¿ame Parlament done) the Crowne of England was entailed to King Henrie, The Crowne is Entayled. and to his heires for euer.

TreaÅ¿on plotted, to be acted at Oxford.AÅ¿Å¿oone as this Parliament was ended, Å¿uch of the greateÅ¿t Lords, as made the faireÅ¿t Å¿hew of publike applauÅ¿e and ioy, for the High dignitie which King Henrie did poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e; conÅ¿pired by TreaÅ¿on to take away his life, at a Å¿olemne IuÅ¿ts to be holden in the Citie of Oxford: whereunto the King was inuited; and promiÅ¿ed to bee preÅ¿ent, becauÅ¿e hee conceiued, that the Å¿ame Triumph was Å¿o appointed for his honour, and for his delight.

This Treacherie was cunningly plotted and contriued by the ConÅ¿pirators: who by Indentures vnder their handes and Å¿eales, had bound themÅ¿elues each vnto other, both for Å¿ecrecie, and alÅ¿o for the reÅ¿olute effecting and performing thereof; all which they Å¿olemnly confirmed by their Oathes.

The confederates.The Confederates in this TreaÅ¿on, were the Kings CouÅ¿in German, Edward Plantagenet Duke of Aumarle, Å¿onne and heire apparant to Edmund of Langley Duke of Yorke: Thomas Holland Duke of Surrie; and Iohn Holland his brother, Duke of Exeter, both which were halfe brothers to King Richard; Iohn Montague Earle of Salisburie; Hugh Spencer Earle of GloceÅ¿ter; Sir Thomas Blunt; and one Magdalen, who was Å¿ometimes a Chamber-wayter to the depoÅ¿ed King, and both in Å¿tature, and in countenance, and in his behauiour, was not much vnlike him.

All theÅ¿e ConÅ¿pirators (the Duke of Aumarle onely excepted) met at Oxford, at the appointed time, being Å¿trongly guarded, and honourably attended,The TreaÅ¿on was Å¿trangely diÅ¿couered. by luÅ¿tie Archers, and other valiant men. But the abÅ¿ence of the Å¿aid Duke, was (by his AÅ¿Å¿ociates) wondred at: for which their was good cauÅ¿e. For as hee Å¿ate at Table with the Duke his Father, one Labell of a part of the Å¿aid Indentures appeared at his boÅ¿ome: by which, the olde Duke drew forth the whole writing. And hauing read the Å¿ame; hee cauÅ¿ed his HorÅ¿e to bee made readie, becauÅ¿e hee intended (with all poaÅ¿ting Å¿peed) to make this newes knowne vnto the King. But his guiltie,The Duke of Aumarle confeÅ¿Å¿eth all to the King. and perplexed Sonne (perceiuing that his Father would reueale this Å¿ecret) and knowing that, now, the leaÅ¿t delay might extraordinarily haÅ¿ten his danger: being brauely mounted (with all celeritie) he out-rode his Father, and came to WindÅ¿or CaÅ¿tle to the
King (who was preparing for his Å¿aid iournie) and without anie tedious diÅ¿courÅ¿e, or lingring ceremonies,He is pardoned. hee reuealed to his MaieÅ¿tie the whole conÅ¿pired TreaÅ¿on; and freely obtained his owne pardon.

It now behoued the King to change his courÅ¿e: and Å¿o hee did. For preÅ¿ently he rode to the Tower of London: The King raiÅ¿eth an armie. where he tooke a preÅ¿ent and a perfit view of all Å¿uch thinges, as were behoofefull, and neceÅ¿Å¿arie to an Armie.

And then he leuied a Å¿trong power: purpoÅ¿ing to defend himÅ¿elfe, and to Å¿urpriÅ¿e thoÅ¿e grand Traytours, if he might. But when the ConÅ¿pirators were informed, that all their Plot and TreaÅ¿on was reuealed:Magdalen was King Richards counterfeit. They cauÅ¿ed the Å¿aid Magdalen to bee attired in Royall Robes; and to faine, and affirme himÅ¿elfe, to bee King Richard. And with him, and all their Troupes (which were verie warlike and Å¿trong) they marched towardes London: reÅ¿oluing to oppoÅ¿e themÅ¿elues in the field againÅ¿t the king.

But king Henrie (knowing that thoÅ¿e Lords, both in bloud, and for their power,The King marcheth towards the Traytors. were more then ordinarily great) was not ignorant, that his beÅ¿t meanes to repreÅ¿Å¿e, and vanquiÅ¿h them, conÅ¿iÅ¿ted in the quickeÅ¿t expedition and diÅ¿patch, which hee could make. The newes of the kings approach being voiced among the companies, which were conducted by the conÅ¿piratours; Å¿o perplexed,The Traiterous Lords are left by their companions. and Å¿o amazed them, that verie cowardly they ranne away, and left thoÅ¿e Lords comfortleÅ¿Å¿e, and deÅ¿titute of all aide. So that the moÅ¿t of them were apprehended; and not long after were put to death, in Å¿undrie places of this kingdome:The Lords fl â¢ e and are taken and executed. and the reÅ¿t (being Å¿urcharged, and ouer-burdned with feare, and Å¿orrow) not long after dyed.

He deÅ¿isteth when he heareth of King Richards death.
A French Armie.
An EngliÅ¿h Armie. But when hee certainly knew, that the poore, diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed, and afflicted King, was dead, and that it was too late to doe him anie good: hee diÅ¿Å¿olued his Armie; and proceeded no further in that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. Yet to reuenge thoÅ¿e wrongs; hee was verie hopefull to Å¿urpriÅ¿e manie Townes, Cities, and CaÅ¿tles in Aquitaine, and in Guyan. But the EngliÅ¿h Armie (landing in thoÅ¿e Countries before the French King was in a readineÅ¿Å¿e: and being boldly commanded and conducted by the Lord Percie, Earle of WorceÅ¿ter, vnto Sir Thomas Knowles the King of Englands Lieutenant there:The French King giueth ouer his enterpriÅ¿e. and they hauing taken the fealtie, and the homage, of the Lords of thoÅ¿e Prouinces, for their obedience, and alleageance vnto King Henrie: cauÅ¿ed the French King to change his mind, and diÅ¿honourably to diÅ¿band all Å¿uch companies as hee had leuied. Yet for all this, King Henrie (Å¿till diÅ¿truÅ¿ting the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e of his vÅ¿urped title, and endeuouring to Å¿upport it with a more Å¿ure foundation, entreated the French King Charles the Å¿ixt, to giue in marriage his daughter IÅ¿abel (Å¿ometime King Richards wife) vnto his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne Henrie, Marriages with France are Å¿eldome fortunate. Prince of Wales. But her father (obÅ¿eruing that marriages betwixt England and France were but Å¿eldome fortunate) denied the kings requeÅ¿t, whereupon, Å¿he was conueied into France with Princely attendance, and great honour. The aforeÅ¿aid TreaÅ¿on conÅ¿pired againÅ¿t the king by the aforeÅ¿aid Lords; and the late preparations of the French King, firÅ¿t to haue inuaded the Kingdome of England, and Å¿econdly, to haue wrought wonders in Aquitaine, and in Guyan: and the frequent Å¿peeches which euerie where were vttered touching the manner of the Kings attaining to the Crowne; animated the Welchmen, and the Scots, to Å¿hew themÅ¿elues troubleÅ¿ome neighbours vnto the King.

Owen Glendor rebelleth.For in Wales, Owen Glendor (a bold Squire) with manie hundreds of his lawleÅ¿Å¿e and vnciuill companions, entred into Armes, and did much harme in the Marches which bordered neere vnto them. Wherein (becauÅ¿e the King was too too Å¿lacke and negligent) hee was entreated and vrged by his Lords,The King would not redeeme him. but eÅ¿pecially by the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Earles kinÅ¿men the Percies. The Scots alÅ¿o inuaded the Northerne parts of this Kingdome:The Scots inuade. but King Henrie, with a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie, entred into their Countrie; and reuenged his wrongs euerie where, with fire, and Å¿word, at his owne pleaÅ¿ure.The king curbeth them. But as Å¿oone as hee was gone, the angrie Scots (being in number twentie thouÅ¿and at the leaÅ¿t) entred with barbarous crueltie into England vpon the Northumbers,
The Scots againe doe inuade.
Henrie HotÅ¿purre ouerthroweth them.
His great PriÅ¿oners. but were gallantly encountred by Sir Henrie Hot-Å¿purre, the Å¿onne and heire apparant of Henrie Percie Earle of that Prouince: who (with tenne thouÅ¿and luÅ¿tie and braue men) gaue the Scots Å¿uch a bloudie ouerthrow, that he Å¿lew of them more then tenne thouÅ¿and in the field, and tooke aboue fiue hundred PriÅ¿oners; among whome Mordake Earle of Fyffe, Archibald Earle DouglaÅ¿Å¿e, Thomas Earle of Murrey, and Robert Earle of Angus, were the chiefe.

The next yeare following, ANNO. 1. The Frenchmen, Å¿poyled by a Å¿torme at Sea. the French King Å¿ent for Wales (to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t Owen Glendor in his rebellious enterpriÅ¿es) twelue hundered Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen of good accompt, that they might be leaders, and directors, to thoÅ¿e diÅ¿ordered Traytors. The King marrieth the Dutches of Britaine.
The King makes great friends abroad.
ANNO. 3. The King requireth the Percies to deliuer to him their ScotiÅ¿h PriÅ¿oners. They refuÅ¿e it The Percies reÅ¿olue to Å¿et Edmond Mortimer at libertieâª and to reÅ¿tore him to the Crown. The Percies (hauing receiued this anÅ¿were, ANNO. 4. list.head: Articles againÅ¿t King HENRIE.
list.item:
1. INprimis, That when hee came into England from his BaniÅ¿hment, he tooke an oath, only to challenge, and to recouer his inheritance, and his wiues; and not to intermedle
with the King, nor with the Crowne. By reaÅ¿on of which oath diuers loyall and good Subiects to King Richard, reÅ¿orted vnto him, not hauing anie treaÅ¿onable intent. But when he perceiued that his Å¿trength was Å¿o much encreaÅ¿ed, that he might doe what hee pleaÅ¿ed; hee wickedly brake his oath, and without anie title, or right, procured himÅ¿elfe to be made, and to be crowned King.

2 Item, that not only, as an Archtraitor, hee had impriÅ¿oned his naturall, and vndoubted Lord and MaÅ¿ter, King Richard, but had cauÅ¿ed him wickedly, and traiterouÅ¿ly to be murdered: that with greater Å¿ecuritie, hee might enioy his Crowne, and his Kingdome.

3 Item, that, euer Å¿ince the death of King Richard, hee had vniuÅ¿tly kept the Kingdome, and the Crowne, from his CouÅ¿in Edmund Mortimer Earle of March, who was the Å¿onne and heire of Philip, the daughter and heire of Lionel Duke of Clarence, elder brother to Iohn of Gaunt father to the vÅ¿urping King.

4 Item, that when no want or need compelled him, hee had impoÅ¿ed diuers SubÅ¿idies, and taxes, vpon the people, to their great griefe, and diÅ¿contentment: of which they willingly would, but dared not to complaine.

5 Item, that no iuÅ¿tice could be expected at his hand: becauÅ¿e (contrarie to the oath which hee tooke when hee was crowned) he had by letters, written, and Å¿ent into Å¿undrie Shires, procured certaine BurgeÅ¿hips for the Parliament, all which hee beÅ¿towed vpon Å¿uch as would not faile to Å¿erue his turne, when opportunitie did Å¿erue.

6 And laÅ¿tly, that whereas in honour and for affinities Å¿ake, hee ought to haue ranÅ¿omed, and redeemed his Å¿aid CouÅ¿in the Earle of March, from his Å¿trait and loathÅ¿ome impriÅ¿onment (and the rather for that hee was earnestly Å¿olicited Å¿o to doe) he not only denied the Å¿aid request, but falÅ¿ly, and vntruly publiÅ¿hed and proclaimed, that the Earle himÅ¿elfe was of his owne accord become a voluntarie PriÅ¿oner, to
the end, that Traitors and Rebels ioyning with him, might haue Å¿omwhat wherewith they might colour Å¿uch TreaÅ¿ons as they would conÅ¿pire againÅ¿t him.

div.p: For all which cauÅ¿es, and manie others more,The Percies doe defie the King. they vtterly defied him as a Traytor, and as a VÅ¿urper; and (as an enemie) they vowed his deÅ¿truction, and the reÅ¿toring of the Å¿aid Earle to his Right.

The King perceiuing, that nothing but Å¿trong blowes could end this Å¿trife: and being perÅ¿uaded,The King rayÅ¿eth an Armie. that if hee became victorious in this Rebellion, he Å¿hould bereaue all his enemies of all hope to preuaile in the like attempts; had leuied a Å¿trong Armie: with which hee marched couragiouÅ¿ly againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e Lords; hoping to meet with them, before they Å¿hould joyne their forces with the Welchmen: and Å¿o great was his care,The battaile of Shrewsburie. that he failed not therein of his purpoÅ¿e. Yet notwithÅ¿tanding, the Lords and their Armie Å¿toutly performed their taske; and fought with Å¿uch admired courage and reÅ¿olution, that they perÅ¿uaded themÅ¿elues of good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, vntill the King and the martiall Prince his Å¿onne (determining by honourable death rather to be Å¿ubdued, 3. 1401. The Percies are ouerthrowne. than to become the laughing Å¿tocks of aduerÅ¿e and froward fortune) redoubled their Å¿trength and valour, and by their particular examples each to the other, they Å¿o renewed the fight, that Sir Henrie HotÅ¿purre, and Å¿ome others of the principall Leaders of thoÅ¿e companies, and manie thouÅ¿ands more, were Å¿laine; and his vncle, the Earle of WorceÅ¿ter, was taken priÅ¿oner in the field, and the reÅ¿t fled. And Å¿o the King, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ixteene hundred of his Å¿ouldiours,
The King himÅ¿elfe Å¿lew 36.
Douglas is releaÅ¿ed by the King without ranÅ¿ome. hauing Å¿laine more than Å¿ix thouÅ¿and of his enemies (of which, thirtie and Å¿ix fell by his own Å¿word) obtained a famous victorie. And becauÅ¿e the Earle Douglas, in a Å¿ingle combate with the King himÅ¿elfe, performed the part of an approued and of a worthie knight, the King granted him his libertie, without ranÅ¿ome.

The next day following, the King and all his armie (with great deuotion and reuerence) gaue thankes vnto Almightie GOD for their good and honourable Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e:
Thanksgiuing vnto God.
The Earle of Worcester is beheaded. and then he cauÅ¿ed the Earle of WorceÅ¿ter to be beheaded; and manie others, being ring-leaders in that Rebellion, to be drawne, hanged, and quartered, and did Å¿et their heads vpon London Bridge.

The Prince marcheth into Wales. Owen Glendor forÅ¿aken by his companions. He is famiÅ¿hed to death.And the King intending forthwith to purÅ¿ue and proÅ¿ecute his good fortunes, for the Å¿urer Å¿etling of his eÅ¿tate in future time; Å¿ent the Prince of Wales, and his whole armie, into Wales. But when hee came thither, his chiefeÅ¿t enemie Owen Glendor was vtterly forÅ¿aken by his whole companies, and Å¿hrowded himÅ¿elfe in the Woods; and being compaÅ¿Å¿ed round about by the Princes forces (who eagerly hunted to apprehend him) hee was miÅ¿erably famiÅ¿hed to death; and manie of his aÅ¿Å¿ociates being taken, were put to death: and then the Prince returned joyfully to the King.

The Earle of Northumberlands voluntarie Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion.Now, whileÅ¿t the Prince was thus buÅ¿ied in Wales, Henrie Percie Earle of Northumberland, came (of his owne accord) and Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe to the Kings mercie; proteÅ¿ting and Å¿wearing with manie oathes, That he was neuer made acquainted, nor intermedled in thoÅ¿e TreaÅ¿ons. A Chalenge Å¿ent by the Duke of Orleans to king Henrie.When all theÅ¿e Troubles had found an end, Lewis Duke of Orleance, brother to the French King (being prowd and vainglorious) Å¿ent a Chalenge to King Henrie; requiring him, with one hundred choÅ¿en men at armes of his Kingdome, in Å¿ome indifferent and conuenient place, to fight with him, and with the like number of Frenchmen, for honours Å¿ake. But the King (with great diÅ¿cretion and wiÅ¿dome) made him this anÅ¿were,King Henries diÅ¿creet anÅ¿were. That his former actions, in warlike employments, could clearely acquite him from the infamous name and title of a Coward: And that Kings ought not to be Å¿o careleÅ¿Å¿e of their Countries and of their people (whome GOD had committed vnto their charge and gouernment) as to fight for anie cauÅ¿e, except it were for the furtherance or for the maintenance of true Religion; or in defence of their Rights; or to defend their Kingdomes from forraine enemies; or to reuenge their wrongs; and for Å¿uch like important cauÅ¿es: And alÅ¿o, that a Soueraigne and an annointed King (by the Lawes of Armes, and of Honor) was not bound to anÅ¿were anie Chalenge in the field, except it were made vpon good cauÅ¿e, by his Equall in Dignitie and in Office. And yet hee further added this, That hee would at all times be verie readie to repulÅ¿e and to repreÅ¿Å¿e anie violence or wrong, which the Duke Å¿hould dare, raÅ¿hly or vnaduiÅ¿edly, at anie time to attempt againÅ¿t him, or anie of his people.

The Duke,A raÅ¿h attempt had a diÅ¿gracefull end. being ouer-paÅ¿Å¿ionate when he receiued this diÅ¿creet and mild anÅ¿were, with all expedition beÅ¿ieged the Towne of Vergie in Guian, and remained there for the Å¿pace of three moneths, and Å¿omewhat more. In which time hee offered manie Å¿harpe aÅ¿Å¿aults, and much violence, but receiued as manie Å¿tout repulÅ¿es as he could well endure. The Duke of Burgoine alÅ¿o (Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that the inÅ¿tabilitie of king Henries eÅ¿tate at home,The Duke of Burgoyne attempteth the regaining of Callice. could not permit him to leaue his Kingdome and to warre abroad) obtained leaue of the French King to attempt the regaining of Callice to the French. For which purpoÅ¿e he procured a puiÅ¿Å¿ â¢ nt Armie, in which he had Å¿ix thouÅ¿and valiant men at armes, fifteene hundred croÅ¿bowes, and twelue thouÅ¿and ordinarie Souldiers on foot. But when the French Kings Councell were informed, of the great preparations made in England by King Henrie to defeat them, and had maturely conÅ¿idered of the difficultie (yea almoÅ¿t of the impoÅ¿Å¿ibilitie) of this attempt: the Å¿aid Duke was commanded to deÅ¿iÅ¿t from his intended Å¿eruice:He is required to deÅ¿iÅ¿t. whereat hee was much grieued, and did coniecture, that the proud Duke of Orleans, and Å¿ome others, had diÅ¿couraged the King in that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e they were iealous, that by his valour hee would winne too much honour and renowne.

Experience teacheth vs, that as the higheÅ¿t Trees are Å¿ubiect moÅ¿t to bee hurted by a Å¿torme: ANNO. 6. A new Rebellion Å¿ecretly plotted but diÅ¿couered. Å¿o the greateÅ¿t EÅ¿tates are in greateÅ¿t danger to be Å¿haken by Enuie. An euident poofe therof appeared plainly in the whole courÅ¿e of this Kings Raigne. And though he had now eÅ¿caped the great dangers of two former TreaÅ¿ons, and Rebellions, and had beene victorious ouer the Scots, and the Welch Rebels, and had out-faced the French, who (if they had dared) would haue attempted high Atchieuements at Callice, and in Aquitaine, and in Guian: yet was he now againe in hazard to haue beene turmoiled with an other Ciuill Warre at home; which Å¿ecretly was plotted, and contriued, by Henrie Percie Earle of Northumberland, Richard Scrope ArchbiÅ¿hoppe of Yorke, Thomas Mowbray Earle MarÅ¿hall, and by the Lords, H â¢ Å¿tings, Faulconbridge, and Bardolf, and by diuers others.

But as (in Å¿uch like caÅ¿es) it often falleth out,The King Å¿odainely Å¿urpriÅ¿eth the Traitours. Å¿o this Traiterous ConÅ¿piracie was Å¿ecretly reuealed to the King: who came Å¿o vnexpectedly with an Armie into the North, that ere anie man reported

The King in danger to be taken on the Thames by French Pirates. The Lord of Camoys in trouble, cleareth himÅ¿elfe. ANNO. 9. A valiant Sheriffe.And now it chanced, that as king Henrie paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer the Riuer of Thames, from Kent into EÅ¿Å¿ex, vnder the conduct of the Lord of Camois, hee was almoÅ¿t taken by the French Pirats: for which cauÅ¿e the Å¿aid Lord was Å¿uÅ¿pected, and attached as a Traitour, and receiued his due triall, by his Peeres; but was clearely acquited of that offence, and receiued into fauour.

In the ninth yeare of this kings Raigne, the Earle of Nothumberland, and the Lord Bardolfe (animating the Scots to a new war) entred with them into Northumberland; and did much miÅ¿chiefe: whereupon king Henrie leuied a Å¿trong armie, and by great iournies) trauailed to encounter them. ANNO. 11 Thomas is made Duke of Clarenceâª Iohn Duke of Bedford. Humphrie Duke of GloceÅ¿ter. The King prepareth to Warre in the Holy land. The King falleth â¢ k â¢ . Whereat the king Å¿tarted vp,The Prince Å¿eized on the Crowne. The Kings Å¿peech to the Prince. and rayÅ¿ing himÅ¿elfe vpon his armes, he demanded who it was that had taken away his Crowne. div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE FIFTH.
div.p:
IT is well knowne, That King Henrie the fifth, whileÅ¿t he was but a Prince, aÅ¿Å¿ociated to himÅ¿elfe diuers vnthriftie and lewd companions;A wilde Prince, but a wiÅ¿e King. by whoÅ¿e inÅ¿tigation (among manie other vnworthie paÅ¿Å¿ages in his fathers dayes) hee Å¿mote the Lord chiefe IuÅ¿tice of England in the face: for which offence he was impriÅ¿oned and diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed of the PreÅ¿identÅ¿hip of the kings Councell; and (to his great griefe and diÅ¿grace) was Å¿ucceeded therein by Thomas, Duke of Clarence, his younger brother. But when hee was crowned king, hee diÅ¿poÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe into a new courÅ¿e, qualifying his behauiour with Å¿uch heroicall vertues, as might beÅ¿eeme both his PerÅ¿on and his Honour,He baniÅ¿heth his looÅ¿e companions. and baniÅ¿hed from his Court his looÅ¿e and baÅ¿e conÅ¿orts, after he had enabled them to liue by Å¿uch gifts as were proportionable to their callings. He alÅ¿o elected for his Councell, and into places of IuÅ¿tice and publike Gouernment, Å¿uch as were wiÅ¿e, diÅ¿creet,His good choice of good Gouernors. He reformeth the Clergie. He ruleth the Laitie. learned, and temperate; well able to rule themÅ¿elues, and to command others. He painefully laboured to reforme Pride, CouetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿uch other groÅ¿Å¿e abuÅ¿es as were crept into the Church among the Clergie: and enjoined them Å¿trictly to frequent Praier & Preaching, to HoÅ¿pitalitie, and to the Å¿incere Å¿eruing of Almightie GOD.
And (by the adminiÅ¿tration of his Lawes with moderate Å¿eueritie) hee made the Laitie tractable in the performance of their duties. And (to Å¿ettle his EÅ¿tate in peace and in tranquilitie at home; Å¿o that neyther the Scots nor the Welchmen Å¿hould moleÅ¿t him, when hee was buÅ¿ied in his Warres abroad) hee erected diuers CaÅ¿tles,He erecteth CaÅ¿tles in the frontiers of Scotland and of Wales. Bulwarkes, and other Fortifications vpon their frontiers; and Å¿o diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of them, that with manie thouÅ¿ands of able men, and skilfull Captaines to command them, he was Å¿till readie and powerfull, with great violence and force, to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e and qualifie Å¿uch rebellious InÅ¿urrections as they might make.

King Richards bodie remoued to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter.In the firÅ¿t yeare of his Raigne, with great pompe and Å¿olemnitie, hee brought the bodie of King Richard the Å¿econd from Langley vnto Westminster, and buried it by Queene Anne, his firÅ¿t wife.

div.head: A proud Speech of a Frenchman to King HENRIE.
div.p: REnowned and great Prince, the world is taught to know by good Experience, that Kings and Noble Captaines doe winne their chiefeÅ¿t Reputation for their valour and for their fortitude, by maÅ¿tring and Å¿ubduing of proud enemies and of valiant men by martiall violence, and with the Sword: and that it is, and euer hath beene, a notorious Badge of cowardly baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e in a Prince, to make them Å¿eruile by Famine, and by the Å¿carÅ¿itie of food; in which kind of crueltie there is neither found Manhood to praiÅ¿e him, nor Wit, which may in anie Å¿ort commend him. To the end therefore, that your HighneÅ¿Å¿e may make your Å¿elfe equally famous with the greateÅ¿t Princes for your generous diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, in taming of vs, the Souldierie of this Citie, by the Sword; Å¿uffer (I pray you) the multitude of our diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed and Å¿ick folkes, and the weaker Å¿ort of our men, women, and Children, Å¿afely and charitably to paÅ¿Å¿e through your Armie; and then (if you dare) aÅ¿Å¿ault our FortreÅ¿Å¿es and our Walls: and if, by your valour, you fortune to become our Lord, you may vÅ¿e vs at your pleaÅ¿ure, and make your Å¿elf truly and heroically famous among great Men, who doe Å¿corne all baÅ¿e attempts, and can relliÅ¿h nothing but vnÅ¿potted honor.

Sir Thomas Beauford, Å¿urnamed the baÅ¿tard of Clarence (who had the direction of the Archers which were left behinde) being informed (but all too late) that the Duke of Clarence was betrayed; and that the numbers of the Frenchmen, and their Power, did farre exceede the Lombards report; and that the EngliÅ¿h were diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed: with incredible Å¿peede marched forth to Å¿uccour them with his beÅ¿t helpes. The heauie newes of this vnexpected ouerthrow,The Earle of Mortaigne Å¿ucceedeth the Duke of Clarence. and eÅ¿pecially the death of the Duke of Clarence (occaÅ¿ioned by the aforeÅ¿aid Treacherie and TreaÅ¿on) much grieued the King his brother: Who purpoÅ¿ing to reuenge himÅ¿elfe, if hee might, vpon the Duke of AlanÅ¿on, and the late Dolphin, and his adherents; Å¿ent into Normandie the Earle of Mortaigne, brother to the late taken Earle of SomerÅ¿et, and gaue to him the Å¿ame Authoritie and Place which the Duke of Clarence formerly had. The King hauing leuied a gallant Armie,Iohn Duke of Bedford carrieth an army into France. which conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of foure thouÅ¿and men at Armes, and of foure and twentie thouÅ¿and Archers; Å¿ent, and with all Å¿peede, proÅ¿perouÅ¿ly landed them at his owne Towne of Callis, vnder the commaund of his worthie brother, Iohn Duke of Bedford: whome, himÅ¿elfe (in his owne perÅ¿on) followed.The King followeth. And vnderÅ¿tanding, that the Dolphin
with Å¿euen thouÅ¿and men, had beÅ¿ieged and much diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed the Citie of Chartieres, which was valiantly defended by the BaÅ¿tard of Thyan; hee marched Å¿wiftly vnto Paris, and from thence toward his Enemies: and in his journey he was met by his heartie and true friend, Philip Duke of Burgoine, He meeteth his friend Philip Duke of Burgoine. and Earle of Flanders; who brought vnto him foure thouÅ¿and men, and diligently attended him in that Negotiation and Seruice.

The Dolphin rayÅ¿ed his Å¿iege.The King was now informed, That the Dolphin (diÅ¿truÅ¿ting his owne Å¿trength) had rayÅ¿ed his Siege, and was retyred vnto Tours into Towrayne: Wherefore (to repreÅ¿Å¿e the rage and violence of Sir Iaques Harcourt, who waÅ¿ted the Countrey of Picardie) hee Å¿ent the Duke of Burgoine thither: And with other Forces hee cauÅ¿ed the young and couragious Iames, Iames the King of Scots winneth Direx. the King of the Scots, to lay Å¿iege vnto the Towne of Direx: which he performed accordingly; and dayly with Å¿uch violence and valour Å¿o aÅ¿Å¿aulted it for the Å¿pace of Å¿ixe weekes, that with mayne Å¿trength hee compelled it to be yeelded into his hands, to King Henries vÅ¿e.

P â¢ Henry is borne.About the Å¿ame time, Queene Katherine was deliuered of a Sonne at WindÅ¿our, who was named Henrie: Of whoÅ¿e birth, as Å¿oone as the King had notice, he Å¿aid vnto the Lord Fitz-Hugh his Chamberlaine:The Kings words. The King, who (for manie weekes together) had beÅ¿ieged the well-defended Towne of Meux in Bry; enforced it to bee yeelded into his hands: and thereupon all the Townes and FortreÅ¿Å¿es in the IÅ¿le of France, in Lanuoys, in Bry, and in Champaigne, did the like.The Dolphin entreth into the Duke of Burgoines countrey.

The King, by reaÅ¿on of his encreaÅ¿ing Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, waxing more weake and feeble, was carried vnto Boys in Vyncennes; where, within few dayes, he was Å¿ummoned by Death to depart into another world.

But before he died,The Kings Speech before he died. he called vnto him his two brothers, Iohn Duke of Bedford, and Humfrey Duke of GloceÅ¿ter: the former, hee made Lieutenant Generall of Normandie, and Regent of the kingdome of France; and the other, he made Protector of England, and of his Å¿onnes owne perÅ¿on. div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE SIXT.
div.p: KIng Henrie the fifth died when his Å¿onne Henrie was but nine months old: 1422. 1 A yong king, but well gouerned. Yet was hee Å¿o fortunate in his beginning, that his Youth and Gouernment were worthily Å¿upported by his three vncles; Humfrey Duke of GloceÅ¿ter, who (when the King was crowned) was made Protector both of his PerÅ¿on and alÅ¿o of his Realme: Iohn Duke of Bedford, who was eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed Regent of France: and Thomas Duke of Exeter, who graced all his actions with much wiÅ¿dome and great valour.

Needfull it was, that the new Protector and the Regent Å¿hould make the vtmoÅ¿t tryall of their Å¿ufficiencies to the World. For whereas, in the end of the Kings fathers dayes,France is vnwilling to remain EngliÅ¿h. the Nobilitie of France incorporated themÅ¿elues to the EngliÅ¿h Nation, and heartily enuied the Dolphin: King Charles about this time died: and the vnconÅ¿tant Frenchmen began to play an IriÅ¿h game. For, on a Å¿uddaine, manie of thoÅ¿e diÅ¿Å¿embling and fained friends renounced their duties and obedience to King Henrie, and (vtterly neglecting the performance of Oathes of Allegeance made vnto him) they reuolted, and not onely adhered to Charles their new King, but by all Å¿iniÅ¿ter practiÅ¿es and meanes they endeuoured to extirpe the EngliÅ¿h Nation among them, if they might.

The Regents Policies.The Protector at home (by the aduiÅ¿e and counÅ¿ell of the StatiÅ¿ts) plotted manie Proiects for the retayning of the Kings inheritance in Normandie and in France: and for that purpoÅ¿e he furniÅ¿hed the Regent with Å¿tore of Souldiours, Siluer, and of Gold.

The Regent alÅ¿o leuied a Å¿trong Armie in Normandie among his choyÅ¿eÅ¿t and chiefeÅ¿t friends: whome (by Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall arguments and Å¿ound reaÅ¿ons) hee perÅ¿uaded to perÅ¿euere and to continue loyall to his MaÅ¿ter; and not to be wearied with anie labour, or daunted with anie danger, becauÅ¿e a peacefull and a bleÅ¿Å¿ed concluÅ¿ion Å¿hould make them rich and fortunate, and winne to them the loue and fauour of their young King, as hee encreaÅ¿ed in wiÅ¿edome and in yeares.

And on the other Å¿ide, Charles (the new King) Å¿pared not anie paines; but did the like: inÅ¿omuch, that nothing but tyrannizing Warre, and the vnchriÅ¿tian effuÅ¿ion of much bloud, was thought vpon. And to begin thoÅ¿e Troubles, the French King Å¿ent the Lord Grandeuyle, Pont-Melance taken. with a Å¿elected companie, to Pont-Melance, which Å¿tandeth on the Riuer of Seyne; which hee Å¿urprized, and Å¿lew the moÅ¿t part of them, whom he found there, before anie notice of his approach gaue anie warning to the EngliÅ¿h garriÅ¿on to defend it.

The Earle of Salisburie a famous man. Thomas Montacute, the Earle of Salisburie, for his admired courage and expert managing of martiall actions, was (at that time) more fitly to be compared to a choiÅ¿e Roman, than to anie other who liued in his dayes. To this Earle, the Regent commended the regayning of that Towne: in the Å¿iege whereof, hee Å¿pent three moneths;Pont-Melance regained. but (at length) it was yeelded into his hands: and the Lord Grandeuyle (by a Å¿olemne Oath) promiÅ¿ed his faithfull and perpetuall Å¿eruice to King Henrie; but reuolted as Å¿oone as he was Å¿et at large.
Sens is taken.From thence, the Å¿aid Earle marched into Champaigne, beÅ¿ieged and tooke the Towne of Sens, and deuoured the Å¿urprized Å¿ouldiors with the Sword.

The PariÅ¿ians craue protection.The vnconÅ¿tant PariÅ¿ians (more coueting to make an outward Å¿hew of their fidelitie to the EngliÅ¿h, than to be true indeede) Å¿ent diuers of their greateÅ¿t and graueÅ¿t Citizens into England, to craue protection and defence againÅ¿t King Charles: Who were receiued, not onely with a chearefull welcome, heartie thankes, and bountifull entertainement; but alÅ¿o were promiÅ¿ed the fruition of much happineÅ¿Å¿e, if they perÅ¿iÅ¿ted loyall vnto King Henrie.

About that time, the Regent meeting at Amiens with the Dukes of Burgoine and of Britaine,
1423. 2 A League renewed. The Regent marrieth. renewed the League formerly concluded betweene them: And to make it the more firme and Å¿ure, hee married the Ladie Anne of Burgoine, Å¿iÅ¿ter vnto the Duke.

The triumphant Shewes and PaÅ¿times which were prepared to augment the honour of this Match,The PariÅ¿ians are vnfaithfull, and conÅ¿pire with the French king. perÅ¿uaded the PariÅ¿ians in his abÅ¿ence, that the Regent attended nothing but Iolitie and Mirth: Which conceit of theirs made them (trecherouÅ¿ly) to inuite their longed for King Charles to come vnto them, and to receiue that Citie into his hands.

This newes brought comfort to his Å¿oule:The trecherie diÅ¿couered. So that hee appointed the day, when his deÅ¿ire Å¿hould bee effected in that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. But, as it euer falleth out, where many are of counÅ¿ell, nothing can be Å¿ecret: Å¿o, Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e ConÅ¿pirators acquainted the Regent with euerie particular of this Plot: Who (with his Armie) poÅ¿ted vnto Paris, with greater expedition than may well be credited, and entred into the Citie gates before anie notice was giuen of his repaire thither. For this ConÅ¿piracie; manie of the chiefeÅ¿t confederates were executed publikely with Å¿undrie kinds of death. And from thenceforth he maÅ¿tred the PariÅ¿ians with EngliÅ¿h GarriÅ¿ons,The Regent curbeth the PariÅ¿ians. and repleniÅ¿hed their CaÅ¿tle, Towers, FortreÅ¿Å¿es, and Places of Defence and Strength, with Å¿uch EngliÅ¿h Souldiors, as Å¿olaced themÅ¿elues in being froward Commanders and imperious Rulers of the inhabitants of that Citie.

And likewiÅ¿e (by Å¿trong AÅ¿Å¿aults, and enforced CompoÅ¿itions) hee wonne the two CaÅ¿tles of Pacy and CourÅ¿ay, Pacy and CourÅ¿ay wonne by the EngliÅ¿h. which were not farre from it; both which hee Å¿trengthened in like manner.

WhileÅ¿t theÅ¿e things were thus acted, the Lord William Steward, ConÅ¿table of Scotland; the Earle of Ventadore, The Å¿iege of Crauant is rayÅ¿ed. and manie others, with a Å¿trong Armie, beÅ¿ieged the Å¿trong Towne of Crauant, within the Territories of Burgoigne. But the Earle of Salisburie, with an Armie of fifteene thouÅ¿and men, ruÅ¿hed fiercely vpon the beÅ¿iegers; and with the loÅ¿Å¿e of one and twentie hundred of his companies, and with the Å¿laughter of eight thouÅ¿and of his enemies, hee rayÅ¿ed the Siege, and gayned libertie to the Towne.

The Earle, vpon his returne to Paris, was Å¿ubÅ¿tituted vice-Regent of the Countries of France, Bry, & Champaigne: and Sir Iohn FaÅ¿tolfe (an approued Knight in Arms) was appointed to be Deputie in the Duchie of Normandie. Which worthie Captaines performed Å¿uch
noble deedes of Chiualrie, and obtayned Å¿uch vnexpected victories, as made them famous, their Followers rich, and their Countrey renowned in all Kingdomes.

In the meane time, whileÅ¿t the Protector prouidently endeuoring to preuent the encreaÅ¿ing Å¿trength of the Kings enemies in France, and to Å¿ecure the tranquilitie and peace of this Common-weale at home;The King of Scots ranÅ¿omed. for a Å¿mall ranÅ¿ome hee enlarged Iames the young and martiall King of Scots; who for manie yeares had beene a priÅ¿oner: And receiuing of him, in the Kings behalfe, his homage and his fealtie for Scotland; He doth homage for Scotland. hee gaue to him in marriage (by the conÅ¿ent of all the EngliÅ¿h Nobilitie) the Ladie Iane, daughter to the deceaÅ¿ed Earle of SomerÅ¿et, and couÅ¿in german to the King.

He is an excellent Prince, but vnfaithfull and vnthankefull.This gallant Prince, by meanes of his excellent Learning and Education in feats of Armes, vnder the laÅ¿t King Henrie, was better enabled to rule a Kingdome than any of his progenitors did before him. In Å¿o much, that making the beÅ¿t vÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e heroicall vertues with which he was adorned, he reduced that Realme into extraordinarie Ciuilitie; made his Å¿ouldiors expert in warlike diÅ¿cipline; and his Nation more learned than euer they had been before his dayes. Yet was he altogether vnfaithfull and vnthankfull to England, his neareÅ¿t and his deareÅ¿t friend.

ProuiÅ¿ion & an Armie Å¿ent into France.The Protector (who was wiÅ¿e and induÅ¿trious) neuer Å¿uffered the Regent in France to complaine of any want. For, as in former times, Å¿o now he Å¿ent vnto him an Armie of tenne thouÅ¿and men, with much TreaÅ¿ure. The Regent and his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants daily wonne Townes, Cities, CaÅ¿tles, and Forts, with prouident policie and true valour. But the French King, by groÅ¿Å¿e Flatterie, cunning DeuiÅ¿es, Å¿ecret Treacherie,Valour was encountred by trecherie. and couert Dealings (among others) poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elfe of the Å¿trong Townes of Crotoy, and Å¿ome others, which were Å¿uddainely regayned: for true Manhood was encountred with Subtletie, and approued Valour with Treacherie and Craft.

The Duke of Britaine and his brother doe reuolt.The Duke of Britaine fearing leaÅ¿t the Regent (growing Å¿trong) would at length be Lord of his Countrey, baÅ¿ely and perfidiouÅ¿ly reuolted to the French King. And Å¿o did his brother Arthur, Earle of Richmond; who by King Henrie the fifth was created Earle of Yurye in Normandie, Yury in Normandie beÅ¿ieged. and made Gouernor of that Towne. Whereupon the Regent beÅ¿ieged it; and with many Å¿ecret Mynes, violent Batteries, and fierce AÅ¿Å¿aults, made it Å¿o Å¿ubject to apparant dangers that the beÅ¿ieged concluded to yeeld it vp, if at an appointed day they were not relieued by the French King.The Regents reÅ¿olution. For the Regent being throughly reÅ¿olued to purchaÅ¿e his peace with a Å¿hort and with a Å¿harpe warre, determined to abide battel, what force Å¿oeuer
Å¿hould be Å¿ent to relieue the miÅ¿eries of that diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Towne. And to further his purpoÅ¿e in that behalfe, hee freely permitted meÅ¿Å¿engers to be Å¿ent vnto his enemies, to informe them of the concluÅ¿ion which he had made.

Within few dayes after, the Duke of AlanÅ¿on, with Å¿ixteene thouÅ¿and Frenchmen, approched neare to the EngliÅ¿h Campe;A cowardly French Armie. who did put themÅ¿elues into a readineÅ¿Å¿e to receiue him. But (according to the French faÅ¿hion) he made manie bragging Å¿hewes to performe much: but (on a Å¿uddain) he cowardly quited the place,Vernoyle beÅ¿ieged and wonne by a falÅ¿e report. not giuing any one blow; and pitched with his whole Å¿trength before the Towne of Vernoyle in the prouince of Perch: where he falÅ¿ely informed the inhabitants, That at Yurye hee had fought with the Regent, defeated his Armie, Å¿laine thouÅ¿ands,Policie. taken many priÅ¿oners, freed that Towne, and had compelled him (by Å¿wift riding) to prouide for the Å¿afetie of his owne life.

This falÅ¿e report Å¿oone made the Duke owner of that Towne,Yury wonne. and his Retreat made the Regent Lord of Yurye: and as Å¿oone as Å¿ound prouiÅ¿ions were made to Å¿trengthen it, the Regent with his whole Armie marched vnto Vernoyle; where (meeting with the French cowards, and with diuers Scots who did aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them) hee compelled them to engage their fortunes by a bloudie battaile in a pitched field. The fight was cruelly maintained for the Å¿pace of three houres. But in the end, the EngliÅ¿hmen, The battaile of Vernoyle. with the loÅ¿Å¿e of one and twentie hundred of their common Å¿ouldiors, wonne the honour of that day, and Å¿lew of their enemies fiue Earles, two Vicounts, one and twentie Barons, and more than Å¿euen thouÅ¿and other men; beÅ¿ides two thouÅ¿and and Å¿euen hundred Scots, who were Å¿ent thither by their King. But the Duke of AlanÅ¿on himÅ¿elfe, with many Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen of Name,The Frenchmen are ouerthrowne. were taken priÅ¿oners. And the Towne of Vernoyle (without AÅ¿Å¿ault or Batterie) was Å¿urrendred into the Regents hands:Vernoyle is regayned. who (hauing fortified it with a Å¿trong GarriÅ¿on, commanded by their worthie Captaine Sir Philip Hall) marched to the Citie of Roan; where hee was receiued with many triumphant Shewes. And from thence he came to Paris; where his kinde entertainment proclaymed his welcome and his honour.

This ouerthrow Å¿o weakened the French King, that none other Prouinces or Territories, but onely Burbon, Aluerne, Berry, The EngliÅ¿h doe preuaile. Poytou, Towrayne, part of Angeou and Languedoc, could giue vnto his Royall PerÅ¿on anie warrant of Å¿afetie and aÅ¿Å¿urance. Yet (leaÅ¿t he Å¿hould want the true honors belonging to a King) in the Citie of Poytiers hee eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed his High Court of Parliament, and his
Chancerie;The French King laboureth his owne eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment. with the publike vÅ¿e of his broad Scale: and of all other things needfull and requiÅ¿ite for the due adminiÅ¿tration of his Lawes, and the diÅ¿tribution of IuÅ¿tice.

The Earle of Salisburie winneth many Townes.The Regent taking the aduantage of his late victorie, Å¿ent into the Countrey of Mayne an Armie of tenne thouÅ¿and men: which (with great reÅ¿olution) were brauely conducted by the valorous and prudent Earle of Salisburie: who quickly wonne the Å¿trong Citie of Mauns, and the Townes of Saint SuÅ¿an, le Fort Saint Barnard, and manie others. 1425. 4The perfidious Earle of Richmond (whome King Charles had newly made High ConÅ¿table of France) intending to make himÅ¿elfe famous in the minoritie of his Gouernment, raiÅ¿ed an Armie of fortie thouÅ¿and men; which conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of Britons, French, and Scots: The Siege of Saint Iames. with which he beÅ¿ieged the Å¿trong Towne of Saint Iames in Beuyon; which was defended only by Å¿ix hundred EngliÅ¿hmen: who hauing reÅ¿olutely endured many Å¿harpe aÅ¿Å¿aults and hard bickerings,A miraculous ouerthrow. vpon a Å¿uddaine iÅ¿Å¿ued boldly out of the Towne, and proclaymed their approach with an hideous Å¿hout of Saint George, Salisburie; Saint George, Salisburie; and fell vpon the multitude of their enemies like a Å¿torme. This terrible crie, and the inconÅ¿olable feare and terror, which made them thinke that the Earle of Salisburie, with his Armie, had Å¿ecretly conueyed himÅ¿elfe into the Towne for their reÅ¿cue; Å¿o amazed and daunted the faint-hearted multitude, that (caÅ¿ting away their Armour, abandoning all Order, and entertaining nothing but DeÅ¿paire) they leapt headlong into the Riuer: In which, many of them were drowned; more were Å¿laine: Å¿ome were taken priÅ¿oners: and the reÅ¿t, who ranne away, left vnto this little handfull all their Tents, foureteene Peeces of Ordnance, fortie barrels of Powder, three hundred Pypes of Wine, two hundred Pypes of Bisket and of Flower, and two hundred Peeces of RaiÅ¿ins and Figges, fiue hundred Barrels of Herrings, much Armour, and manie other things.

A poore reuenge.The New ConÅ¿table intending to redeeme his honour with Å¿ome better fortune, recollected and furniÅ¿hed his Armie: with which hee marched into the Countrey of Angeou; where (without reÅ¿iÅ¿tance) hee burnt a few of the Å¿malleÅ¿t, pooreÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t vnworthie Villages of that Prouince.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING EDVVARD THE FIFTH.
div.p: IF our memories be pleaÅ¿ed to take a reuiew of the life and actions of the late deceaÅ¿ed King Edward the Fourth, Edward the Fourth deÅ¿cribed. wee may thereon make this pretie abbreuiate and Å¿hort collection: That hee was of a goodly perÅ¿onage, and of a kingly preÅ¿ence: That he was very Å¿trong, and paÅ¿Å¿ing valiant, not proud in proÅ¿peritie, nor deiected with aduerÅ¿e fortune: That hee was moderately pleaÅ¿ant and merie: That he was pleaÅ¿ing to his Nobles, familiar with his Å¿ouldiers, and amiable to his inferiour Å¿ubiects: That he was mercifull to offenders, and fauoured all Å¿uch as did well: That he was very wiÅ¿e, diÅ¿creet, prouident, and Å¿oundly aduiÅ¿ed in all his actions. He left behinde him two Å¿onnes; Edward, who being of the age of thirteene yeares, vnfortunately Å¿ucceeded him in this Kingdome; and Richard Duke of Yorke, who was two yeares younger; and fiue daughters, namely Elizabeth, who afterwards maried King Henry the Å¿euenth, and was mother to King Henry the eighth, and Cicilie, Bridget, and Katherine, whoÅ¿e fortunes Å¿eldome laughed, and Anne, who maried Thomas Lord Haward, who after was created Earle of Surrey.

Richard Duke of GloceÅ¿ter deÅ¿cribed.The Å¿aid noble King (when he died) left behinde him but one brother, namely Richard Duke of GloceÅ¿ter, who was (by common report) a monÅ¿ter in nature. For he had many teeth when he was borne. Hee was very haÅ¿tie and forward in great expeditions and weightie actions; yet wiÅ¿e, and well aduiÅ¿ed before hee would attempt to fight. He was ambitious beyond meaÅ¿ure, and his deÅ¿ires for Å¿oueraigntie had no bounds. What he contriued, were it good or bad, hee would by one meanes or by another aÅ¿Å¿uredly effect it. Hee made his conÅ¿cience in all things to Å¿erue his will, though his will could not bee obtained without the effuÅ¿ion of guiltleÅ¿Å¿e bloud. He would oftentimes make himÅ¿elfe poore by his lauiÅ¿h bountie to Å¿uch as wickedly Å¿erued his turne: and would againe quickly enrich himÅ¿elfe by pilling and by polling of ciuill and of honeÅ¿t men. Hee was Å¿o cunning a diÅ¿Å¿embler, that hee would accompanie moÅ¿t familiarly and ieÅ¿t pleaÅ¿antly with Å¿uch as hee inwardly hated in his heart. Hee Å¿pared no mans death, whoÅ¿e life
reÅ¿iÅ¿ted his vngodly purpoÅ¿es; nor puniÅ¿hed any man for any offence, if his wickedneÅ¿Å¿e might be applied to his Å¿eruice. This ambitious, this fierce, and this cruell man, in his brother King Edwards daies (as wiÅ¿e men did coniecture) directed his aime to make himÅ¿elfe a King.10. E. 4. For he with others murdered Prince Edward the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne of King Henry the Sixth:10. E. 4. and with his owne hand hee Å¿lew the Å¿ame King when he was a priÅ¿oner in the Tower; and was conÅ¿enting (as the world blabbed) to the death and deÅ¿truction of his elder brother, George Duke of Clarence, in the Å¿ame place.10. King Edwards death, and the minoritie of his two Å¿onnes,Richard aimeth to the Crowne. gaue him fit opportunitie to worke miÅ¿chiefe, which firÅ¿t of all he reÅ¿olued to proÅ¿ecute by the reuiuing of olde grudges betwixt the Queenes kindred and the Kings, although the laÅ¿t King in his death-bed had reconciled them, and made them all friends. To them hee diÅ¿couered the meane deÅ¿cent of the Queene, and of her kinsfolkes in reÅ¿pect of theirs, and told them plainly, that if thoÅ¿e VpÅ¿tarts remained Å¿o neere vnto the King in his youth, they would (through his fauour) be Å¿o powerfull when he came to his full age, that all their honours, their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, and their liues, would be in danger to be made Å¿ubiect to their willes. TheÅ¿e faire perÅ¿waÅ¿ions, and their owne ambitious humours,

And the Duke of GloceÅ¿ter knowing that if his feat were not wrought before that time, it could not eaÅ¿ily be effected after; and conÅ¿idering likewiÅ¿e, that if he with his confederates Å¿hould come armed againÅ¿t the King to meet him, and by open violence attempt to get the Kings perÅ¿on into their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, their Å¿aid enterpriÅ¿e would be cenÅ¿ured and adiudged to be a rebellious action, and no leÅ¿Å¿e then TreaÅ¿on. Wherefore he cunningly directed and Å¿ent his letters to the Queene, and called to her remembrance the heartie loue and friendÅ¿hip which the late King her deceaÅ¿ed huÅ¿band in his death-bed had ratified and confirmed betwixt the Lords of his owne bloud and alliance, and the kinsfolkes of the Queene. The Queene and her friends (who meant none ill) taking much comfort in this aduice,The Kings Å¿trength is Å¿ent away. becauÅ¿e Å¿he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed it Å¿prang from heartie loue, and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e the Duke of GloceÅ¿ter had at the Å¿ame time with all reÅ¿pectiue dutie and reuerence likewiÅ¿e written vnto the King, and louingly to the Earle Ryuers her brother, and vnto Richard Lord Grey her Å¿onne, cauÅ¿ed all Å¿uch Å¿trength of armed men as was prouided for the Kings conduction towards London, to bee diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed and Å¿ent away. Yet in friendly and in a iocund manner he came vnto the two Dukes, and asked them why they had Å¿o done. But Å¿uddenly they entred into a needleÅ¿Å¿e and cauÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e quarrell with the Å¿aid Earle,They are impriÅ¿oned. Å¿urpriÅ¿ed his perÅ¿on, and committed him to Å¿afe keeping. And then in good and quiet manner the two Dukes rode to Stony Stratford, and humbly preÅ¿ented their duties and their Å¿eruice to the King, who being altogether ignorant of that which Å¿o newly had hapned, receiued them with a cheerfull countenance and with much ioy. But preÅ¿ently they alÅ¿o Å¿eiÅ¿ed vpon Richard Lord Grey, the Kings halfebrother, and vpon Sir Thomas Vaughan, and Å¿ome others, all which they Å¿ent (vnder a Å¿trong Guard) to the CaÅ¿tle of Pomfret in the
North, where without any iudiciall Å¿entence or legall proceeding againÅ¿t them, they were beheaded vpon the Å¿ame day that the Lord HaÅ¿tings Lord Chamberlaine (who conÅ¿pired in that action with the two Dukes) did loÅ¿e his head.

The Kings Å¿eruants are remoued.The two Dukes alÅ¿o and the Lord Chamberlaine remoued from the King all his other Officers, and moÅ¿t of his meniall Å¿eruants, informing all men which attended the King, or expected the Å¿equell of this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, that the Å¿aid Earle, Lord, and Knight, with Å¿ome others, had reÅ¿olued to deÅ¿troy all the Lords of King Edwards bloud, and to rule both the King and Common-weale according to their owne will.

The Queene with her children take Sanctuarie.When the Queene (who at that time lay, with the Kings brother, the young Duke of Yorke, and with her fiue daughters, at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter) heard of theÅ¿e tumults, and what had hapned to her brother, Å¿onne, and friends, it repented her much that Å¿he had aduiÅ¿ed them (vpon the Duke of GloceÅ¿ters cunning letters) to diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿e and to diÅ¿charge their Å¿ouldiers and men of warre. And becauÅ¿e Å¿he had good cauÅ¿e to feare the euent thereof, Å¿hee with her children entred into the Sanctuarie there. The young King alÅ¿o mourned grecuouÅ¿ly to Å¿ee the wofull tragedie wherein his friends miÅ¿fortunes were Å¿o vnexpectedly acted. But the two Dukes recomforted him with the expreÅ¿Å¿ion of their humble duties and Å¿eruice, and with a thouÅ¿and proteÅ¿tations of their fidelitie and troth towards his HighneÅ¿Å¿e during their liues:The King is brought to London. and then they brought him with great honour neere to the Citie of London, where he was met by the Lord Maior, and fiue hundred graue Citizens more, in whoÅ¿e preÅ¿ence the Duke of GloceÅ¿ter vÅ¿ed Å¿uch humble dutie and reuerence to the King, and Å¿o diÅ¿creetly demeaned himÅ¿elfe towards him, that none of them Å¿uÅ¿pected that any thing was done but for the Kings preÅ¿eruation, and for his good: yea the Nobilitie and CounÅ¿ellors of EÅ¿tate were Å¿o inwardly perÅ¿waded to reÅ¿t in the Å¿ame beleefe, that (by their generall conÅ¿ent) they forthwith made him the Protector both of the Kings royall perÅ¿on,The Duke of GloceÅ¿ter is made Protector. and of his Kingdome.

When the Duke of GloceÅ¿ter had procured and obtained this high place which his heart infinitely deÅ¿ired, (the Å¿ame being an office of greateÅ¿t honour,He poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿eth himÅ¿elfe of the Kings brother the Duke of Yorke. of confidence, and of truÅ¿t) hee made no doubt but that his purpoÅ¿e would quickly (though wickedly) bee brought to paÅ¿Å¿e as himÅ¿elfe wiÅ¿hed, if he could alÅ¿o get the young Duke of Yorke into his hands. And to the end that his deÅ¿ires might not remaine fruitleÅ¿Å¿e, hee greeuouÅ¿ly complained to the Kings CounÅ¿ell of the froward obÅ¿tinacie of the Queene, who detained
the Å¿aid young Duke diÅ¿honourably in the Sanctuarie as an offender, and in priÅ¿on, cauÅ¿ing thereby the gouernment of the whole Kingdome, and the Nobles and officers thereof, to be exceedingly blamed and taxed, not only at home, but alÅ¿o in all other ChriÅ¿tian Prouinces and Kingdomes. He vrged alÅ¿o, that his Grand-maÅ¿ter the young King was infinitely wronged and diÅ¿heartened, for that he was not permitted to enioy the Å¿ocietie and the companie of his owne and only brother, whom aboue all other creatures in the world he reÅ¿pected and longed for.

The Lords hauing conÅ¿idered of the Dukes motion, reÅ¿olued that he had Å¿poken well, and that it was fitting it Å¿hould be hearkned vnto. And thereupon, they made eÅ¿peciall choice of the Cardinall ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke (vpon whoÅ¿e fidelitie and loue, the Queene did not a little relie) to goe to her, and to pray her (without further trouble) to Å¿end the yong Duke her Sonne to the king his brother: That he might be comforted with his Å¿ight, and bee made merrie and iocund with his companie. And withall they required him to tell her, that for many reaÅ¿ons the young Duke might not be detained there.

1. FirÅ¿t,ReaÅ¿ons why the young Duke ought not to be in the Sanctuarie. becauÅ¿e the whole eÅ¿tate of this Kingdome would be Å¿landered at home and among forraine Nations, if it Å¿hould permit Å¿o young a childe, by birth Å¿o noble, Å¿o neere vnto the King, and Å¿o innocent, to liue in priÅ¿on: (for euery Sanctuarie is a priÅ¿on.)

2. Secondly, becauÅ¿e none could claime the benefit of Å¿uch a place, but he whoÅ¿e conÅ¿cience did accuÅ¿e him of Å¿ome offence, for which he feared to be puniÅ¿hed by the law. But the conÅ¿cience of this young Duke cannot be Å¿o burdened, becauÅ¿e his infancie and his innocencie doe excuÅ¿e him of any Å¿uch fault, and therefore hee needed no protection there.

3. Thirdly, that none might enioy the priuilege of a Sanctuarie, but Å¿uch a one as is enabled by true diÅ¿cretion to demand it. But the young Duke (by reaÅ¿on of his infancie) hath not Å¿ufficient diÅ¿cretion to require it, and therefore hee is not capable of it, nor may enioy it.

4. And laÅ¿t of all, hee was required to aÅ¿Å¿ure her, that any perÅ¿on might be taken out of a Sanctuarie, if it bee for his good and welfare, and not to his hurt, or to puniÅ¿h him: and that therefore if the Queene did obÅ¿tinately refuÅ¿e to deliuer him, it was reÅ¿olued and determined, that hee Å¿hould be taken from thence, and from her without her leaue; and the rather, for that great Å¿uÅ¿pition and feare was iuÅ¿tly conceiued, that her frowardneÅ¿Å¿e or her iealouÅ¿ie would perÅ¿wade her to Å¿end him beyond the Sea, as
if hee Å¿hould bee more Å¿afe there then in his brother the Kings Court.

When this round meÅ¿Å¿age was done vnto the Queene, though it Å¿o nipped her at the heart, that willingly Å¿he would not let him goe, alleadging that none but his owne mother was more fit to tutor him, or to attend him, hee being Å¿o young, Å¿ickly, and very weake; and that each of thoÅ¿e two brethren was the others Å¿afetie Å¿o long as they were kept aÅ¿under, and that the life of the one was maintained in the bodie of the other, and that if one of them did well, the other was in no perill or danger, and that nothing was more hazardous then to keepe them both in one place together: yet when Å¿hee perceiued which way the game went, and that it was reÅ¿olued by the Protector, and by his friends, that arguments Å¿hould not preuaile, Å¿hee embraced the louely young Duke in her armes, Å¿he kiÅ¿Å¿ed him many times, Å¿he wept bitterly, and praying Almightie God to preÅ¿erue and to defend him from all iniurie and dangers, Å¿he deliuered him to the Arch-biÅ¿hop, telling him, that Å¿hee would require that poore and innocent childe at his hands. And thus vnwillingly and Å¿orrowfully Å¿he did let him goe.

A monÅ¿trous diÅ¿Å¿embler.When the harmeleÅ¿Å¿e infant was by the Arch biÅ¿hop deliuered into the Protectors hands, who with many other Lords attended the Queenes anÅ¿were in the Starre-chamber, he tooke him (before the whole aÅ¿Å¿emblie) in his armes, he hugged and embraced him, and kiÅ¿Å¿ed him once and twice, and againe and againe, proteÅ¿ting vpon his Å¿oule, that no worldly thing (his MaieÅ¿tie only excepted) was Å¿o deare vnto him as that young childe, when as indeede hee meant nothing more then the deÅ¿truction and ruine of them both. And hauing brought him to the King, who was infinitely ioied with his preÅ¿ence and companie, hee conueied them (within few daies after) with princely pompe and attendance thorow the Citie of London to the Tower,The King and his brother Å¿ent to the Tower. vnder the pretence of an eÅ¿peciall care and prouidence that they Å¿hould in Å¿afetie remaine there vntill the Common-weales troubles were thorowly quieted and appeaÅ¿ed, whereas in truth and in deede nothing was out of frame, nothing was ill ordered, but by himÅ¿elfe, and by Å¿ome other great Lords who wholly applied themÅ¿elues to his will.

A bloudie conÅ¿piracie.When the Protector had thus couped vp thoÅ¿e two young Princes, he then beganne more Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to determine how hee might Å¿peedily make himÅ¿elfe a King. And though for a while he Å¿taggered whether or no hee might make the Duke of Buckingham acquainted with his purpoÅ¿e, yet in regard that hee Å¿tood aÅ¿Å¿ured of his loue, and knew that his proiect could not be effected without
his priuitie and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, becauÅ¿e he was Å¿o mightie and Å¿o powerfull, therefore hee found a fit time and a Å¿ecret place to conferre with him about that buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e: and with Å¿mall perÅ¿waÅ¿ions, and by the offer of his daughter to the Dukes Å¿onne in mariage, with the gift of the whole Earldome of Hartford, whereunto the Duke pretended a rightfull title, but neuer could obtaine it from King Edward the Fourth, and by the diuiding and Å¿haring of the greater part of the Kings treaÅ¿ure among themÅ¿elues, hee wonne him not only to conÅ¿ent vnto his villanie, but alÅ¿o to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him in that plot.

The Lord HaÅ¿tings (whom the Protector for old acquaintance,The Lord Hastings could not be wonne. friendÅ¿hip, and loue, had newly Å¿ettled in the office of Chamberlaine to the young King) was euer faithfull and truÅ¿tie to King Edward the Fourth, and had vowed his heart to the Å¿eruice of his new maÅ¿ter, inÅ¿omuch that the Protector was not aÅ¿Å¿ured whether he might attempt to winne him to ioine with himÅ¿elfe and with the Duke of Buckingham in his conÅ¿piracie, or no. But in the end hee fearing leÅ¿t he could not doe that miÅ¿chiefe Å¿afely, except the Å¿aid Lord were either wonne or deÅ¿troied, hee reÅ¿olued vpon one of them. Wherefore firÅ¿t of all by liberall gifts, and by large promiÅ¿es of extraordinarie aduancement and preferment, hee wonne to his will one Catesbie, who was both wittie, and well learned in the Lawes of this Realme, and was the moÅ¿t inward of all others with the Å¿aid Lord HaÅ¿tings, from whom hee had receiued his beÅ¿t fortunes, and his chiefeÅ¿t meanes to gaine. Him the Protector imploied and inÅ¿tructed, that by darke Å¿peeches and by Å¿ome myÅ¿ticall propoÅ¿itions, hee Å¿hould afarre off feele and vndermine the inclination of the Å¿aid Lord his deareÅ¿t friend touching that matter. Which when he treacherouÅ¿ly and craftily had done, he informed the Protector that there was no poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie euer to winne him thereunto.

Hereupon the Protector reÅ¿oluing to cut him Å¿hort,A plot full of villanie. called a Grand CounÅ¿ell of the Lords at the Tower of London, propoÅ¿ing to them for their taske the conÅ¿ideration of all fitting preparations for the Å¿peedie Coronation of the King, when as indeed hee intended no Å¿uch thing.

The Lords being aÅ¿Å¿embled, and Å¿et downe in their places, and all of them long expecting the repaire of the Protector, who Å¿taied long, at length he came in, tooke his chaire, Å¿aluted them all kindly, excuÅ¿ed his long abÅ¿ence, merily ieÅ¿ted with Å¿ome of them, and was more then ordinarily pleaÅ¿ant with them all. But aÅ¿Å¿oone as he had propoÅ¿ed Å¿ome method to their preÅ¿ent conference he told
Doctor Morton, BiÅ¿hop of Elie, whom he loued not, that hee was informed that he had Å¿tore of Straberies in his Garden in Holborne, and intreated him to Å¿end for Å¿ome, which with all expedition he did, being much gladded that he found the Protector (as hee conceiued) Å¿o kinde towards him. But (behold) vnexpectedly and vpon a Å¿udden the Protector (faining Å¿ome neceÅ¿Å¿itie of a Å¿hort abÅ¿ence) roÅ¿e vp, and requeÅ¿ted the Lords to proceed in the matter which then they had in hand, and promiÅ¿ed to make a quicke returne, which within one houre after hee performed accordingly. But being placed in his chaire, the Lords perceiued that Å¿ome things were amiÅ¿Å¿e: for he bent his browes, bit his lippe, caÅ¿t his eies vpon the ground, wrung his fiÅ¿ts, looked fiercely, Å¿ighed deepely, and by euery vnpleaÅ¿ing geÅ¿ture he openly expreÅ¿Å¿ed the diÅ¿quieted paÅ¿Å¿ions of a troubled minde. The Lords (who looked on him Å¿adly, and were perplexed with Å¿udden perturbations) wondred much at this Å¿udden change, but knew not what it meant. And when a profound Å¿ilence had prepared them all to hearken what would be Å¿aid, the Protector by way of queÅ¿tioning propoÅ¿ed what they deÅ¿erued who wickedly had intended and practiÅ¿ed his deÅ¿truction, hee being Vncle and Protector to the King? The Lords (who were all free and abÅ¿olutely guiltleÅ¿Å¿e of any Å¿uch crime) Å¿ate Å¿till as men amazed, and not one of them Å¿pake a word. But at length the Lord HaÅ¿tings (who by reaÅ¿on of his great familiaritie with the Protector, imagined that hee was higheÅ¿t in his fauour) anÅ¿wered thus: My Lord, Å¿uch as haue Å¿o tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ed the Law, deÅ¿erue the Å¿euereÅ¿t puniÅ¿hments which by the Law may be inflicted vpon them, and all the Lords aÅ¿Å¿ented thereunto.A likely matter. Then quoth the Protector, that SorcereÅ¿Å¿e (meaning the Queene) and that Strumpet Shores wife, haue conÅ¿pired together by witchcraft to depriue me of my life: and that you may be right well aÅ¿Å¿ured that it is true, behold (I pray you) and Å¿ee how their villanie hath alreadie Å¿eiÅ¿ed vpon my bodie. For by it my left arme is alreadie waÅ¿ted and conÅ¿umed, and therewithall hee Å¿troke vp his Å¿leeue, and Å¿hewed his arme naked before them all. Thus dared hee to doe, albeit that all Å¿uch as were there preÅ¿ent were well aÅ¿Å¿ured that his arme had neuer beene otherwiÅ¿e from his mothers wombe. And moreouer, no man was Å¿o full of follie to beleeue that if the Queene had intended Å¿uch a miÅ¿chiefe,Shores wife was King Edwards Concubine. Å¿hee would haue conÅ¿orted with Shores wife aboue all other women, becauÅ¿e Å¿hee was the Concubine of King Edward her deceaÅ¿ed husband. And beÅ¿ides all this, they all knew that the Queene was religious, temperate, milde, charitable, and vertuous
in all her actions, hating to reuenge although meanes and opportunitie were offered vnto her to doe miÅ¿chiefe.

The Lord HaÅ¿tings (who after King Edwards death,The Lord HaÅ¿tings puniÅ¿hed for his whoredome. conuerÅ¿ed with Shores wife; vÅ¿ing her as his Concubine; and but the Å¿ame Morning leauing her in his owne bed) being deÅ¿irous (if he might) to appeaÅ¿e the Protectors rage towards her: And (in Å¿ome Å¿ort) being willing to excuÅ¿e her, Replied thus, My Lord, if the Queene and Å¿hee haue Å¿o done, and therewithall the Protectors indignation (waxing intemperate) interrupted him, thus: Thou Traitor (quoth hee) telleÅ¿t thou me of Iffs and Ands; I tell thee they haue done it, and as he Å¿pake thoÅ¿e words with a lowd voice, hee clapt his hand rudely vpon the Table board;Armed men. vpon the noyÅ¿e whereof, the whole Chamber was Å¿uddenly Å¿tuffed and filled with Armed men. And one of them (at his firÅ¿t entrance) Å¿trake with his Holbard at the Lord Stanleys head: who preuenting the violence, but not all the blow, to Å¿aue his life fell vnder the Table but did looÅ¿e much bloud. The Protector himÅ¿elfe arreÅ¿ted the Å¿aid Lord HaÅ¿tings, and accuÅ¿ed him (by generall tearmes) of high TreaÅ¿on:The Lord HaÅ¿tings beheaded. and forthwith without any other proceeding or Iudgement, cauÅ¿ed him to be carried out into the Greene, and his Head vpon a Logge to be chopped off.

And it is to be noted, that this Execution was thus done on him the Å¿ame day, and at the Å¿ame hower, that the Earle Ryuers, the Lord Richard Gray, Sir Thomas Vaughan, and their other friends, were executed without legall proceeding in the CaÅ¿tle of Pomfret: Murder puniÅ¿hed. which Execution was appointed by the Protector, by the Duke of Buckingham, and by the Å¿aid Lord HaÅ¿tings, who litle dreamed that he Å¿hould in the like maner haue died at the Å¿ame time.

This Execution being thus diÅ¿patched, the Protector cauÅ¿ed thoÅ¿e Armed to Å¿eiÅ¿e vpon the Cardinall ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke: and vpon the BiÅ¿hop of Elie, and vpon the Lord Stanley, and Å¿ome others, all which were Å¿euerally committed to Å¿euerall PriÅ¿ons in that place.

And preÅ¿ently the Protector and the Duke of Buckingham, A had Å¿hift. thruÅ¿ting themÅ¿elues into vile and vncomely harneÅ¿Å¿e, as if neceÅ¿Å¿itie had compelled them to Å¿hift themÅ¿elues into the firÅ¿t and worÅ¿t that came vnto their hands: They Å¿ent for diuers worthie Citizens of London and required them with all poÅ¿ting Å¿peed to repaire thither, which they did. And vnto them the Protector paÅ¿sionately related, that his death was conÅ¿pired, and that his life Å¿hould haue beene taken from him as he Å¿ate that morning in CounÅ¿ell with the Lords, by the Lord HaÅ¿tings, and by his wicked
complices, if by Å¿udden force and violence he had not preuented that miÅ¿chiefe: and Å¿o much they were required to tell their friends, that they might haue true notice of the cauÅ¿e of this Å¿udden broile and execution in the Tower. And within two houres after that the Lord HaÅ¿tings was depriued of his head, a Å¿olemne and a long Proclamation written with a faire hand in parchment, and being vnder the Great Seale of England, was brought into the Citie, and with great Å¿olemnitie proclaimed there by an Herald of Armes. But by all circumÅ¿tances it was coniectured by all wiÅ¿e men, that the Å¿ame was indited, written, and Å¿ealed Å¿ome daies before.

Doctor Shaas Sermon.Thus when the wicked Protector had impiouÅ¿ly cut off the heads of thoÅ¿e Lords, who would Å¿till haue kept him backe from doing of too much miÅ¿chiefe if they had liued, hee cauÅ¿ed Doctor Shaa (a man more learned then vertuous, and as wicked in practiÅ¿es as the Protector was, who did inÅ¿truct him) in a Sermon the Sunday following at Pauls CroÅ¿Å¿e, to blazon the honourable birth and parentage of the Protector, to relate his vertues, to commend his valour, to weaken the fame and honour of the deceaÅ¿ed King Edward by reaÅ¿on of his laÅ¿ciuious wantonneÅ¿Å¿e with Shores wife, and with many others, to baÅ¿tardize all his children, as being borne in adulterie, and out of lawfull mariage, for that King Edward was Å¿olemnly contracted (as he affirmed) vnto the Ladie Elizabeth Lucie (whom he begat with childe) before Å¿uch time as hee maried with the Ladie Elizabeth Grey; and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e hee was in the perÅ¿on of Richard the great Earle of Warwicke (before his Å¿aid mariage) affied vnto the Ladie Bona, Å¿iÅ¿ter to Carlot the wife of the French King.

He alÅ¿o accuÅ¿ed the Protectors owne mother of great incontinencie, when King Edward and George Duke of Clarence (his two elder brothers) were begotten. And thus he Å¿triued to make euery one crooked beÅ¿ides himÅ¿elfe, who was moÅ¿t crooked of all. And (in concluÅ¿ion) the Doctor applying his Å¿peech to the worthineÅ¿Å¿e and goodneÅ¿Å¿e of the Protector, he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed that the people could not chuÅ¿e but receiue him for their vndoubted Å¿oueraigne Lord and King, and therefore hee Å¿triued to prepare the multitude to haue Å¿houted out when the King came in, and to haue cried, King Richard, King Richard: but he failed of his purpoÅ¿e; for euery man was Å¿ilent, and more Å¿urpriÅ¿ed with wonder then with applauÅ¿e, to Å¿ee and to perceiue how cowardly, how vnnaturally, and how wickedly theÅ¿e affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es were carried, not to continue the Protector to be a Å¿ubiect any longer, but to be a King.

And the next day in the Guildhall of London the Duke of Buckingham by like arguments endeuoured to make the Protector the rightfull and vndoubted heire and inheritor of the Crowne.The Duke is now King Richard. And albeit that the TowneÅ¿men tooke no contentment in this meÅ¿Å¿age, nor did by their voices aÅ¿Å¿ent to that which to them was deliuered, yet (againÅ¿t their willes) the Duke of Buckingham procured them the next day to goe with him and with many other Lords to Baynards CaÅ¿tle to the Protector, where they offred to receiue him for their lawfull King, and praied him to vndergoe that burden. But oftentimes he refuÅ¿ed to grant them their requeÅ¿t. But at laÅ¿t he granted it. And thus he gained and wonne (by their perÅ¿waÅ¿ions) his hearts deÅ¿ire.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING RICHARD THE THIRD.
div.p: WHen King Richard had taken vpon him the gouernement of this Kingdome, and was crowned, inÅ¿tead of noble and prince like courteÅ¿ie,Cowardly diÅ¿Å¿imulation. be applied himÅ¿elfe to all baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿triuing thereby (but all in vaine) to winne the loue and fauour of his people. And not Å¿eeming to take any notice that the Lord Strange, Å¿on and heire apparant to the Lord Stanley, intended to raiÅ¿e an Armie in the North, becauÅ¿e his father had beene wronged, and was then impriÅ¿oned by the King, but pretending that he loued him when he might puniÅ¿h him, hee did not only Å¿et him at libertie, but alÅ¿o made him the Steward of his owne houÅ¿e.

He alÅ¿o enlarged the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Yorke, D. Morton committed. but committed Doctor Morton BiÅ¿hop of Elie as a priÅ¿oner to the Duke of Buckingham, who was afterwards a principall meanes of his confuÅ¿ion, and of
King Richards deÅ¿truction, as in the Å¿equell of this HiÅ¿torie more particularly it Å¿hall appeare.

Nobles created.The King, to make himÅ¿elfe Å¿trong, by conferring of great honours vpon others, created his onely childe Edward (who was of the age of ten yeares) Prince of Wales: and Iohn Howard (who was both valiant in the field, and wiÅ¿e in counÅ¿ell) was by him created Duke of Norfolke. And Sir Thomas Howard (his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne) was made Earle of Surrey. The Lord William Barkley was aduanced to the Earledome of Nottingham. And Francis Lord Louel (whom he entirely loued) was made ViÅ¿count Louel.

The French King deÅ¿piÅ¿eth King Richard.And when hee had (as hee imagined) Å¿o Å¿urely Å¿ettled his eÅ¿tate, that froward fortune could not change it, by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors he made offer to Lewys the French King to conclude a peace. But Lewys Å¿o much deteÅ¿ted his bloudie cruelties and his murders, that hee would not vouchÅ¿afe to Å¿ee the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors which hee Å¿ent, nor to heare the meÅ¿Å¿age which they brought.

This frumpe and Å¿ome others Å¿o pinched him at the heart, and the Deuill tooke Å¿uch an aduantage of him, by reaÅ¿on of his ambitious and wicked minde, that he Å¿uppoÅ¿ed he could neuer be reputed and truly honoured as a King, Å¿o long as his two harmeleÅ¿Å¿e and poore nephewes drew any breath, as though Å¿o horrible and Å¿o execrable and bloudie a murder could winne him loue and reputation among his diÅ¿contented people.The two yong Princes are murdered.

Thus whileÅ¿t his head forged this vile and villanous conceit, he made his progreÅ¿Å¿e towards the Citie of GloceÅ¿ter, as if hee only intended by his preÅ¿ence to honour that place from whence his former title of dignitie was deriued, Å¿trongly perÅ¿wading himÅ¿elfe, that if this vngodly and hainous fact were committed in his abÅ¿ence, no man would then repute him to bee guiltie of that miÅ¿chiefe.

Sir Robert Brackenburie.Wee muÅ¿t be informed here, that becauÅ¿e from a meane eÅ¿tate hee had raiÅ¿ed Sir Robert Brackenburie to the dignitie of Knighthood, and had made him Lieu-tenant of the Tower, hee coniectured that thoÅ¿e his fauours, and many more which hee might hope for, would haue incited him (for his Å¿ake) to haue committed any villanie whatÅ¿oeuer. But the loue which this vertuous and good Knight bare to vertue, and the great care which hee had to keepe a quiet and a guiltleÅ¿Å¿e conÅ¿cience, made him to refuÅ¿e to perpetrate that murder, which by the Kings letters hee was peremptorily enioined and commanded to performe.

Iames Terril.Whereat when the King had Å¿tormed, Å¿worne, and curÅ¿ed like a Fiend, hee called to his remembrance, that in the Tower there
lodged one Iames Terril, a man who was needie both in vertue, and of good meanes, to Å¿upport his haughtie and his ambitious minde, and who was likely (for rewards and promotions Å¿ake) to kill his owne father and his friend. To him the King by his letters diÅ¿cloÅ¿ed the earneÅ¿tneÅ¿Å¿e of his deÅ¿ires, and promiÅ¿ed larger recompence if the fact were done; then Å¿uch a helliÅ¿h Å¿eruice could deÅ¿erue.
