The olde Queens follie and couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e.The vnconÅ¿tant and the vnprouident Queene, whom couetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and ambition had made credulous, and willing to beleeue him, who in the field had formerly Å¿laine Sir Iohn Gray her firÅ¿t husband, vniuÅ¿tly had executed her brother and her Å¿onne, and who had not only baÅ¿tardized her two other Å¿onnes,K. Richard is poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of K. Edwards fiue daughters. but had wickedly and villanouÅ¿ly cauÅ¿ed them both to bee murdered in the Tower, accepted of thoÅ¿e his gifts and promiÅ¿es, and deliuered vnto him her fiue daughters.

And no Å¿ooner had hee gotten them into his cuÅ¿todie, but (to make his title to the Crowne more Å¿ure) he longed in his heart inceÅ¿tuouÅ¿ly to marie with his owne brothers daughter,His inceÅ¿tuous purpoÅ¿e. the Å¿aid Ladie Elizabeth. But the life of Queene Anne his wife, who was the daughter of Richard Earle of Warwicke, and the former wife of Prince Edward the Å¿onne and heire of King Henry the Sixth, and whom himÅ¿elfe and his brother the Duke of Clarence had murdered in King Edwards preÅ¿ence, was the onely impediment to that match.

The Queene Å¿uddenly died.It muÅ¿t now be diligently obÅ¿erued, that Å¿uddenly vncertaine Authors made report that Queene Anne (who was not Å¿icke) was dead: and moreouer, King Richard himÅ¿elfe forÅ¿ooke her companie and her bed, pretending much diÅ¿contentment and great diÅ¿like becauÅ¿e Å¿he was barren, and not likely to haue any more children to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion in the Crowne. The Queene (who Å¿hrewdly gheÅ¿Å¿ed at the wicked intention of her graceleÅ¿Å¿e huÅ¿band) much greeued and vexed her Å¿elfe thereat: and whether her priuate conceits that her death was conÅ¿pired, or whether any poiÅ¿on (as many did imagine) Å¿hortned her daies or no, it was vncertaine; but within few daies after Å¿he was Å¿uddenly found dead indeed.

He maketh loue to his owne Neece.The King Å¿o little regarded the death of his Å¿aid Queene, that preÅ¿ently he began to make loue to the Ladie Elizabeth his owne Neece, who being diÅ¿creet and modeÅ¿t, and hating his deteÅ¿ted villanies, and well conÅ¿idering what perill and danger her Å¿elfe and all her Å¿iÅ¿ters were in,She makes him hopefull. if the Tyrant Å¿hould raÅ¿hly be reiected, tempered her denials with tempting and alluring lookes, and prettily
fed his fancie with the muÅ¿icke of her Å¿weet tongue, and inÅ¿tantly requeÅ¿ted him, not to vrge his Å¿ute with too much loue, vntill he had defeated the Earle of Richmond of all his hopes, and had finiÅ¿hed his owne troubles, and that he would with carefull diligence make good prouiÅ¿ion to defend himÅ¿elfe. Thus liuing in hope of her liking, and pleaÅ¿ing himÅ¿elfe by yeelding to her requeÅ¿t, hee diÅ¿poÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe wholly in making all needfull preparations to reÅ¿iÅ¿t. But whileÅ¿t he was thus buÅ¿ied, hee was informed by Å¿uch Flatterers as neuer ceaÅ¿ed to abuÅ¿e him, that his Arch-enemie the Earle of Richmond and his coadiutors receiued Å¿uch Å¿mall comfort of the French King, that all their hopes were vaniÅ¿hed, and that they were Å¿o infinitely oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with many wants, that hee needed not to feare any oppoÅ¿ition which they could make.

This newes was by him Å¿o quickly credited,FalÅ¿e newes makes him Å¿ecure. that too much Å¿ecuritie made him careleÅ¿Å¿e to proceed; nay, he diÅ¿charged all his GarriÅ¿ons, which formerly (with great charge and trauaile) he had placed neere vnto the Sea-coaÅ¿ts: Å¿o that we may by the way make this profitable vÅ¿e thereof,A note. that Å¿uch is the Å¿trength of Gods iudgements and iuÅ¿tice, that wicked and vngodly men are euermore leaÅ¿t heedfull and vigilant for their own Å¿afetie and good, when puniÅ¿hments are neereÅ¿t at hand to correct them for their greeuous offences and tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ions againÅ¿t God. WhileÅ¿t theÅ¿e things were thus acting in England, the Earle of Richmond was informed that his Ladie and her Å¿iÅ¿ters were by their mother deliuered into King Richards hands, that his own Queen was Å¿uddenly found dead, and that the old Lecherer made loue and daliance to the Ladie Elizabeth, who was the anchor and the Å¿tay of all his hopes.Richmond Å¿aileth into England, being aided by the French King. Wherefore it is not to be wondred at, that now (with more then wonted importunitie) he Å¿ollicited the young French King and his CounÅ¿ell for preÅ¿ent aid. And (to Å¿ay the truth) Å¿o gratiouÅ¿ly was he fauoured by them all, that he obtained a quicke Å¿upplie of money, Å¿hips, armour, artillerie, and two thouÅ¿and men, to make triall if his fortune had determined that he Å¿hould weare a Crowne. With this little (but reÅ¿olued) companie hee arriued and landed at Milford Hauen in Waies, when he was leaÅ¿t thought on,He landeth. where hee Å¿aw no great appearance of Å¿uch Å¿uccours as he hoped for.

But when the WelÅ¿hmen were put in minde, that (being the Å¿onne of Owen Tuthar) hee was of their owne bloud,The WelÅ¿hmen do Å¿ticke vnto him. and would bee an eÅ¿peciall fauourer of them all, and that his mariage with the Ladie Elizabeth would Å¿ettle the whole eÅ¿tate of this Kingdome in perfect vnitie and in peace, they flocked vnto him, and thronged about him with reÅ¿olued mindes and willing hearts, vnder their skilfull
and hardie Captaines, among which Iohn Sauage, Arnold Butler, Richard Griffith, Iohn Morgan, and Rice A â¢ Thomas, were the chiefe. To him alÅ¿o repaired Sir George Stanley, More aid. who conducted the power and Å¿trength of the young Earle of Shrewesburie, (he being then in ward) which conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of two thouÅ¿and men. Sir Walter Hungerford and Sir Thomas Bourchier (two valiant and worthie Leaders of many a luÅ¿tie man) preÅ¿ented vnto him their Å¿eruice: Å¿o did Thomas Lord Stanley, father in law to the Å¿aid Earle of Richmond, who was accompanied with fiue thouÅ¿and fighting men.K. Richards people reuolt. All theÅ¿e forces were firÅ¿t leuied and prouided for King Richards aide: but God (who purpoÅ¿ed to correct and puniÅ¿h him for his fore paÅ¿Å¿ed wicked deeds) conuerted their hearts, made them to reuolt from a Tyrant, and to Å¿ubmit themÅ¿elues to a more lawfull power; whereat King Richard greeued and tormented him Å¿elfe in vaine. Yet hauing leuied an Armie of more then twentie thouÅ¿and, (few of which, beÅ¿ides his true friend Iohn Duke of Norfolke and his followers, remained firme and faithfull) he marched againÅ¿t his enemies, fully reÅ¿oluing to caÅ¿t all his fortunes in the aduenture of one battaile,K Richard is de â¢ perate. thereby to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h himÅ¿elfe without further feare in his Kingdome, or elÅ¿e (by his death in the open field) to conclude the wofull tragedie of his wicked life.

Iohn Duke of Norfolke.And albeit that many practiÅ¿es were daily vÅ¿ed to haue withdrawen the Duke of Norfolke from King Richards Å¿eruice, yet none of them preuailed. Wherefore to make him iealous and diffident of the caÅ¿e wherein he Å¿tood, the night before the two Armies ioined, this ryme was fixed vpon his chamber doore:
Iacke of Norfolke be not too bold,
For Dickon thy maÅ¿ter is bought and Å¿old.

Yet for all this he perÅ¿iÅ¿ted loyall vntill his death: and the next morrow, being the two and twentieth day of AuguÅ¿t, and in the third yeare of King Richards raigne,BoÅ¿worth field. at BoÅ¿worth in LeceÅ¿terÅ¿hire the two Armies met and encountred each other, and fought for the Å¿pace of two houres.

But when King Richard perceiued that the Å¿malleÅ¿t number of his Å¿ouldiers contended to winne the victorie, and that the reÅ¿idue of them either cowardly left the field, or reuolted to his enemie, or Å¿tood as Neuters, intending to ioine with him who was beÅ¿t likely to ouercome, deÅ¿pairing of his fortune, and knowing that death was readily prepared to attache him,K. Richard is valiant. he left his owne Armie, and daÅ¿hing his Å¿purres into his horÅ¿es Å¿ides, he ruÅ¿hed furiouÅ¿ly into
the Earles battaile, and with his Å¿word he deÅ¿perately made himÅ¿elfe a free paÅ¿Å¿age, vntill he was Å¿trongly encountred by Sir William Brandon, who was Standard-bearer to the Earle: him he Å¿lew valiantly. And then Å¿ingling out Sir Iohn Cheyney, a right hardie man in armes, by meere courage and fine Å¿trength he tumbled him to the ground, and came to the Earle of Richmond, The Earle of Richmond Å¿taieth King Richard. with whom he fought with deÅ¿perate reÅ¿olution hand to hand, vntill hee was by him Å¿laine. And thus by his death this mortall quarrell ended, the Earle hauing loÅ¿t in this battaile not aboue one hundred men, and King Richard about one thouÅ¿and, among which the Duke of Norfolke was the chiefe.

When King Richard was thus Å¿laine, his carrion carcaÅ¿e being found Å¿tarke naked in the field,His bodie rudely vÅ¿ed. and being wounded and filthily polluted with dirt and goarie bloud, was caÅ¿t vpon a horÅ¿e backe behinde a PurÅ¿uiuant at Armes,Gods iudgement on a wicked murderer. to bee carried to the Towne of LeceÅ¿ter, his head and his hands hanging downe on the one Å¿ide, and his legges on the other Å¿ide like a calfe: and there it was interred with as baÅ¿e a funerall as was beÅ¿towed vpon his two Nephewes in the Tower.

His Crowne being found among the Å¿poiles and dead men in the field,The Earle of Richmond is crowned in the field. was brought to the Earle of Richmond by his father in law the Lord Stanley, who with the generall acclamations of the people, who Å¿houted for ioy, and cried King Henrie, King Henrie, crowned him therewith in the open field.

And then the Earle with all his Armie in the field gaue heartie and humble thankes to Almightie God for this great victorie:He thanketh and praiÅ¿eth God. and (with promiÅ¿es of large rewards) the whole Armie was diÅ¿Å¿olued, and the Earle and his Nobles departed to their reÅ¿t. Thus liued and thus died King Richard, when he had raigned as a Tyrant two yeares, two moneths, and one day.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE SEVENTH.
div.p: AS after a Å¿harpe winter men doe receiue the Å¿weet comforts of a pleaÅ¿ant Spring, and like as AduerÅ¿itie is fully recompenced with more ioifull tidings when abundance of ProÅ¿peritie doth follow; Å¿o the hearts of all Å¿uch as were Å¿ad and heauie by reaÅ¿on of the ciuill wars, were now cheered and made iocund by the happie peace and concord which at this inÅ¿tant bleÅ¿Å¿ed all England in the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of King Henrie, The King marieth â¢ he Ladie Elizabeth. who being crowned King, according to his oath and promiÅ¿e, maried the faire and vertuous Ladie Elizabeth, eldeÅ¿t daughter to King Edward the fourth, ioining thereby in one the two great Families of LancaÅ¿ter and of Yorke, betwixt whom (for Principalitie and for the Crowne) infinite contentions and mortall warres had formerly conÅ¿umed and deÅ¿troied many thouÅ¿ands of braue and valiant men.

Now that the Å¿tate of this Kingdome might be confirmed in its happineÅ¿Å¿e, by the Å¿afetie of the Kings perÅ¿on,The King chuÅ¿eth a Guard. and by other requiÅ¿ites, King Henrie (taking his PreÅ¿ident and enÅ¿ample from the Kings of France) Å¿elected a certaine number of warlike men in all places to attend vpon him,Rewards giuen. Noblemen created. whom he termed the Yeomen of his Crowne. He alÅ¿o rewarded with great bountie all Å¿uch as for his Å¿ake had beene eminent in his Å¿eruice; and created his vncle, IaÅ¿par
Earle of Pembroke, Duke of Bedford. His father in law, Thomas Lord Stanley, was made Earle of Darbie. He alÅ¿o made his faithfull and firme friend and fauourite, the Lord Chandew of Britaine, Earle of Bath. Sir Giles Dawbeney was made Lord Dawbeney, Sir Robert Willoughbie Lord Brooke, and Edward Stafford the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne of Humfrey Duke of Buckingham (who in his quarrell loÅ¿t his head) was by him reÅ¿tored to his fathers dignitie and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions.

A Parliament. Acts repealed. The Crowne is intailed. New Lawes. His Pardons.Then hee aÅ¿Å¿embled his High Court of Parliament at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, in which hee fruÅ¿trated, cancelled, and made void all former Acts which conuicted him and his adherents as guiltie of High TreaÅ¿on. The Crowne of this Kingdome was entailed to him and to the heires of his bodie. Hee alÅ¿o cauÅ¿ed Å¿uch Lawes and Å¿uch Statutes to bee made, as were behoouefull and beneficiall to this Common-weale. Hee pardoned all Å¿uch as (hauing conÅ¿pired or borne armes againÅ¿t him) Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿iuely by their oathes acknowledged and receiued him for their true and lawfull King.

His CounÅ¿ellors.Hee elected the moÅ¿t noble, graue, and wiÅ¿e men of this Kingdome, to be of his Priuie CounÅ¿ell, by whoÅ¿e direction and aduice the gouernment of this Realme was eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in proÅ¿peritie and in peace.The Duke of Britaine is recompenced. Hee bountifully recompenced the Duke of Britaine for all his former courteÅ¿ies towards him, and alÅ¿o paid vnto him all Å¿uch Å¿ummes of money as at any time hee had disburÅ¿ed for his maintenance and releefe.So is the French king. The like he did to the French King, and thereby redeemed his two HoÅ¿tages, the Lord MarqueÅ¿Å¿e DorÅ¿et, and Sir Iohn Bourchier, whom he left there.

1486. 2Thus whileÅ¿t King Henry was carefull, willing, and endeuoured to pleaÅ¿e all men, and by his vertuous imploiments laboured to Å¿ettle things in peace,A Rebellion. the malignant Å¿pirits of Å¿uch as tormented themÅ¿elues at his happineÅ¿Å¿e, and placed their owne hope for preferment in rebellious attempts and Å¿editious courÅ¿es, would not permit him to liue at reÅ¿t, and quietly to performe the duties of a gratious King. For Francis Lord Louel, Humfrey Stafford, and Thomas his brother, leauing the Sanctuarie at ColcheÅ¿ter, which for their Å¿afetie they had taken, Å¿educed and animated much people in the North againÅ¿t King Henry, and cauÅ¿ed them (vpon vntrue Å¿urmiÅ¿es) raÅ¿hly and without aduice or counÅ¿ell to put themÅ¿elues in armes.

The King (who was not farre away from them) being Å¿omewhat troubled with this newes,The Kings celeritie in raiÅ¿ing an Armie. began to raiÅ¿e an Armie to withÅ¿tand them; and Å¿uch was his Å¿trange and wonderfull celeritie and expedition to preuent the increaÅ¿e of their further Å¿trength, that haÅ¿tily he Å¿ent againÅ¿t them his Vncle the Duke of Bedford with
three thouÅ¿and men, whoÅ¿e breaÅ¿t-plates were made of tanned leather, for want of other armour: and he himÅ¿elfe trauailed day and night to Å¿econd his Å¿ouldiers with a better Å¿trength. But when the Lord Louel and his aÅ¿Å¿ociates perceiued that King Henry reÅ¿olued to make them fight before they were Å¿ufficiently prepared, and that freÅ¿h forces would giue them a Å¿econd onÅ¿et, if at the firÅ¿t they Å¿hould happen to bee victorious, their courage failed,The Rebels flie. their hearts fainted, Å¿o that in the darkneÅ¿Å¿e of the night they fled, and left their vnarmed Armie to the mercie of King Henry, the two Staffords taking Sanctuarie in the Abbie of Culnham, not farre from Oxford, and the Lord Louel being Å¿hrowded by Sir Thomas Broughton in the North.

The next day the poore diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Rebels (being deÅ¿titute of their Leaders) humbly Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elues to the Kings mercie, and receiued his free pardon. But becauÅ¿e no Sanctuarie could protect malefactors in caÅ¿es of High TreaÅ¿on, therefore the two Staffords were by violence Å¿eized on, and the Å¿aid Humfrey (being indicted, arraigned, found guiltie,Humfrey Stafford is executed. and condemned) was put to death: but his younger brother was preÅ¿erued by the Kings fauour, becauÅ¿e it was conceiued that his tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion was not hatched by his owne malice, but by the peaceleÅ¿Å¿e inÅ¿tigation of his brother.

No Å¿ooner was this flame quenched, but a greater fire was preÅ¿ently kindled by a PrieÅ¿t, whoÅ¿e name was Sir Richard Symond, a man very leaud, but well learned, and in all his actions vniuÅ¿t,Richard Symonds conÅ¿piracie againÅ¿t K. Henry. craftie, and too too cunning. Hee knowing that Edward Plantagenet Earle of Warwicke, and Å¿onne and heire vnto George Duke of Clarence, brother to King Edward the Fourth, being now of the age of Å¿euenteene yeares, had from his infancie beene kept as a PriÅ¿oner by the two laÅ¿t Kings in the CaÅ¿tle of Sherry-hutton in the Countie of Yorke, and that King Henry had Å¿ecretly remoued him to the Tower, got into his tutorÅ¿hip a young boy,Lambert the counterfet Duke of Yorke. prettie and wittie, yet borne of a baÅ¿e parentage and Å¿tocke, whoÅ¿e name was Lambert. Him hee inÅ¿tructed with as much varietie of learning, Court-like complements, and Gentleman-like behauiour, as his yeares would Å¿uffer him to comprehend; and then hee informed him, that by his birth and linage hee was not onely noble, but deÅ¿cended of the royall bloud: that hee was the onely Å¿onne of the Duke of Clarence, and the firÅ¿t heire male of the houÅ¿e of Yorke, and therefore inheritable to the Crowne. This leÅ¿Å¿on, with the daily repetitions of his heroicall Pedegree, hee Å¿o inculcated into his young Scholar, that hee was as able and as ready to diÅ¿courÅ¿e
thereof, as if by inÅ¿piration that knowledge had beene infuÅ¿ed to him from aboue.

The IriÅ¿h were too credulous.Thus when this Å¿ubtill PrieÅ¿t had prepared his Pupill for his purpoÅ¿e, he tranÅ¿ported him into Ireland, where hee firÅ¿t vented and Å¿pred abroad this falÅ¿e and vntrue noueltie, among the wilder and more barbarous Å¿ort of that fickle and buÅ¿ie Nation, who (being too too credulous and flexible to any change) gaue to the youth all honour and reuerence, as vnto their Å¿oueraigne and liege Lord. And within few daies after, diuers of the Nobilitie of that Countrey were taken in the Å¿ame net of follie, and beleeued as the Commons did, among whom the Lord Chancellor, Sir Thomas Gerandine, was the chiefe, who hauing had much familiar conference with the young counterfet, and finding his amiable aÅ¿pect, the trimme compoÅ¿ure of his bodie, his princely preÅ¿ence, his pregnancie of wit, his Å¿ufficient learning, his ingenious capacitie, his quicke Å¿pirit, his diÅ¿creet Å¿peech, and Å¿eemely complements, to be anÅ¿werable and fitting to a Prince, not onely cenÅ¿ured him to bee the true and the vndoubted Å¿onne and heire of the Duke of Clarence, and pitied his eÅ¿tate, but (endeuouring to doe him good) disburÅ¿ed vnto him for the enlargement of his expenÅ¿es, traine, and honour, diuers and Å¿undrie great Å¿ummes of money, and perÅ¿waded many other great Lords of Ireland to doe the like. He alÅ¿o with great Å¿peed and Å¿ecrecie informed the Ladie Margaret, The malice of Margaret DucheÅ¿Å¿e D â¢ wager of Burgoine to K. Henry. Å¿iÅ¿ter to King Edward the Fourth, and DucheÅ¿Å¿e Dowager vnto Charles the deceaÅ¿ed Duke of Burgoine, and the Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Aunt of this counterfet, of his being there. And albeit that Å¿hee was well aÅ¿Å¿ured that this newes was falÅ¿e, yet becauÅ¿e (being of the houÅ¿e of Yorke) Å¿hee mortally hated and enuied King Henry, who was the head and the chiefe of the Familie of LancaÅ¿ter, Å¿he not only gladded her heart to heare thereof, but alÅ¿o pleaÅ¿ed her conceits with infinite delectation, that now an opportunitie was preÅ¿ented to her to execute her furie vpon King Henry, and that Å¿hee might by this plot (if it Å¿ucceeded well) enlarge her true Nephew the young Earle of Warwicke, and make him King. FirÅ¿t of all therefore Å¿hee cauÅ¿ed the falÅ¿e report of this young counterfet to bee noiÅ¿ed thorowout England, that thereby Å¿hee might vnÅ¿ettle the mindes of Å¿uch as were credulous, and might be inclined to take his part. She alÅ¿o publiÅ¿hed, that the IriÅ¿h Nobilitie and Nation had not onely receiued him for their Lord and Soueraigne, and would take his part, but alÅ¿o that Å¿hee her Å¿elfe would Å¿trengthen his attempts with money, men, and armes to the vttermoÅ¿t of her power.

TheÅ¿e vaine and fabulous reports carried vnto her into Flanders
Francis Lord Louel, and her nephew the Earle of Lincolne, Å¿onne and heire to Iohn de la Pole Duke of Suffolke, and of Elizabeth one other of the Å¿iÅ¿ters of King Edward the Fourth,The Traitors land in England. Sir Thomas Broughton, and Å¿ome others: and after many Å¿peeches and much conference touching thoÅ¿e affaires and buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es, the DucheÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿ed to be leuied in her Country about two thouÅ¿and men, which were conducted by Martin Sward an approued Captaine of great reÅ¿olution and much skill. All theÅ¿e (with quicke expedition) Å¿ailed into Ireland, and ioined with Sir Thomas Gerardine the Chancellor, who was in a readineÅ¿Å¿e with more then two thouÅ¿and men of his owne Nation: and they all determined to tranÅ¿port themÅ¿elues into England with all Å¿peed.

Wee may not imagine that King Henry (who was valiant, prouident, and wiÅ¿e) was Å¿ecure, careleÅ¿Å¿e, or negligent in theÅ¿e affaires and weightie buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es.A politicke act. For (to the end that certainly it might bee knowen that Lambert was but a counterfet) hee cauÅ¿ed Edward the young Earle of Warwicke to be publikely brought thorow the Å¿treets of London from the Tower vnto Pauls Church, where infinite numbers of the Nobilitie, Gentrie, and Commons of this Kingdome had the Å¿ight and view of him, and many of them Å¿pent Å¿ome time in conferring with him.The King prepareth againÅ¿t Lambert. Lambert landeth in England. He alÅ¿o made great preparations to repell and to Å¿ubdue all Å¿uch as (in Lamberts aide) Å¿hould either attempt any ciuill warre, or inuade his land. And thus (when he had ordered all things well) theÅ¿e forraine powers arriued neere vnto Lincolne, where they expected more Å¿uccour then they found, or were in any poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie to haue. But when the King was informed that they were come, he marched towards them with a conÅ¿tant reÅ¿olution to trie the vtmoÅ¿t of his fortune in the field, inÅ¿omuch that it was now too late for thoÅ¿e Inuaders to Å¿tep backe: for vrgent neceÅ¿Å¿itie did require,The battaile of Stoke. that either they muÅ¿t flie, fight, or yeeld. But the truth is, though they were not Å¿trong, yet they were no cowards. The IriÅ¿h people were Å¿trangely actiue, and paÅ¿Å¿ing valiant, but they wanted Armes: and their braue reÅ¿olution Å¿o animated their courage, that with haughtie Å¿tomackes and Lions hearts they ioined in battaile with the King. But within leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿pace then one houre,Lambert is ouerthrowen. the vnprouided and vnfurniÅ¿hed IriÅ¿h with their Captaines, the Earle of Lincolne, Francis Lord Louel, Sir Thomas Gerardine, Martin Sward, Lambert is made a Skullian, and then the Kings Faulcone â¢ . and Sir Thomas Broughton, were all Å¿laine, and the reÅ¿t Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elues to the King, who pardoned their offence, and committed the PrieÅ¿t, Sir Richard Symond, vnto perpetuall impriÅ¿onment: and his counterfeited Pupill (being firÅ¿t abaÅ¿ed in the Skullerie) was within
few yeares after chiefe Faulconer to the King. Then was the Kings wife with all honour and princely Å¿olemnities crowned Queene,The Queene is crowned. D. Morton made ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie, and Lord Chancellor, and a Cardinall. and Thomas Bourchier ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterburie died, and was Å¿ucceeded by Iohn Morton BiÅ¿hop of Elie, who was alÅ¿o made Lord Chancellor of this Kingdome: and not long after hee was dignified with the Hat and habit of a Cardinall by Pope Alexander the Sixth.
Now though King Henry (through the benefit of a generall peace at home) was made fortunate and happie, yet forraine iarres among his neighbours prouoked him to new imploiments, vpon this occaÅ¿ion.

The French King quarrelleth with the Duke of Britaine. Charles the French King hauing warred Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efully againÅ¿t Maximilian King of the Romans, complained that he was much wronged by Lewys Duke of Orleance, who had married the Ladie Iane his Å¿iÅ¿ter, and was his next heire apparant to the French Crowne, for that hee with Å¿ome others tooke part againÅ¿t him with his enemie. And not long after, Iames the Fourth, King of the Scots, vÅ¿ed the mediation of Richard Fox, 1501. then BiÅ¿hop of Durham, but Å¿hortly after tranÅ¿lated vnto WincheÅ¿ter, that hee might haue to wife the Ladie Margaret the eldeÅ¿t daughter of King Henry the Seuenth.The Kings eldeÅ¿t daughter affied and after maried to Iames the fourth, King of Scots. And though the King (for many important reaÅ¿ons) might haue beÅ¿towed her vpon the greateÅ¿t and moÅ¿t honorable Kings or Potentates in the ChriÅ¿tian world, yet for theÅ¿e good reÅ¿pects hee cheerefully conÅ¿ented to his requeÅ¿t. FirÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e (by all likelihood and probable coniecture) this mariage would eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h a perpetuall peace betwixt thoÅ¿e two Kingdomes. And Å¿econdly, becauÅ¿e if iÅ¿Å¿ues males and females failed of the bodies of his two Å¿onnes, then the Kingdome and the Crowne of this Realme deÅ¿cending to the Å¿aid Ladie Margaret, and to her iÅ¿Å¿ue, would draw the ScottiÅ¿h King into England, as vnto an eÅ¿tate of greater power, magnificence, honour, and riches; whereas if Å¿he were ioined to a Prince equall, or exceeding her father in thoÅ¿e reÅ¿pects, this Kingdome would then wait vpon the greater and more worthie, and Å¿o might be guided, gouerned, directed, and commanded by a
Deputie, or a SubÅ¿titute, which would bee derogatorie from the maieÅ¿tie of Å¿uch a Monarchie and Common-weale.

TheÅ¿e Halcyon daies,Prince Arthur dieth. which made King Henry fortunate and happie, were Å¿uddenly exchanged into daies of heauineÅ¿Å¿e and of Å¿orrow: for Prince Arthur, within fiue moneths after he was maried, departed out of this troubleÅ¿ome and tranÅ¿itorie vale of miÅ¿erie, and was buried with great pompe and incredible lamentation both of the Nobles, Gentlemen, and common people, in the Cathedrall Church within the Citie of WincheÅ¿ter: by whoÅ¿e deceaÅ¿e without iÅ¿Å¿ue, his brother Henry Duke of Yorke (without Creation) was Prince of Wales, 1502. as vnto him (of right) that dignitie did belong and appertaine: and the next yeare after he was created Earle of CheÅ¿ter by his Father.

The King not long after (by an honorable attendance of Lords, Knights, Ladies, and men and women of eÅ¿peciall note and qualitie) Å¿ent his eldeÅ¿t daughter, the Ladie Margaret, into Scotland, to her eÅ¿pouÅ¿ed husband Iames the Fourth, who receiued her vpon the limits of his owne Kingdome, from the Earles of Surrey and Northumberland, and was the next day maried to her in his Citie of Edenburgh, 1503. to the great reioicing of the people of both thoÅ¿e Nations.

Now when King Henry had thus ouercome his enemies and the Rebels, and had Å¿ettled himÅ¿elfe in peace,1504. hee determined to plucke downe the high Å¿tomackes and Å¿tout courage of his people,The King taketh aduantage of forfeitures vpon Penall Lawes. Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that their wealth and riches occaÅ¿ioned their rebellions, and was the cauÅ¿e that many enormous inÅ¿olencies were done and committed in the Common-weale. And by that meane hee alÅ¿o intended to enrich himÅ¿elfe. And the plot whereby he intended to effect it, was, by taking of the aduantage of the breach of Penall Lawes.EmpÅ¿on and Dudley. And the principall charge of that polling buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e hee committed to Sir Richard EmpÅ¿on and Edmund Dudley, men learned in the Law, but ready enough to execute the Kings commands in a worÅ¿er matter, if occaÅ¿ion did Å¿o require.

TheÅ¿e two being attended by troupes of baÅ¿e Informers, Promoters, Catch-poles, Cheaters, Knaues, and couÅ¿ening RaÅ¿cals,Many are vndone. proÅ¿ecuted and perÅ¿ecuted many of the Kings good Subiects, to their vtter ruine and ouerthrow; inÅ¿omuch that many people in euery Shire of this Kingdome (by their oppreÅ¿Å¿ions) waxed poore, and were vtterly decaied in their eÅ¿tates. But the Kings Coffers were filled, his Bagges were Å¿tuffed, and thoÅ¿e two graceleÅ¿Å¿e and cruell Cormorants got to themÅ¿elues the Deuill and all. But no remedie there was to cure this maladie: for the King authorized
them: and they Å¿o rigorouÅ¿ly, and Å¿o vnconÅ¿cionably executed their tyrannie, that no man could aÅ¿Å¿ure himÅ¿elfe, that hee was free, and without the danger of their laÅ¿h.

1605.In the 21. yeare of K. Henries raigne, Elizabeth Q. of CaÅ¿tile, & wife to Ferdinando K. of Aragon and Spain, died without iÅ¿Å¿ue male of her bodie, Å¿o that her Kingdom not being deuidable among Å¿iÅ¿ters (according to the cuÅ¿tome of that Countrie) diÅ¿cended to her eldeÅ¿t daughter the Ladie Iane, The King and Queene of CaÅ¿tile doe come into England by a Å¿torme. wife to Philip Arch-Duke of AuÅ¿tria, and Duke of Burgoine, Å¿o that hee (being King of CaÅ¿tile in her right) prepared a Nauie of Å¿trong, and well appointed Å¿hips, and entred into the Sea, purpoÅ¿ing to take the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his new Kingdome. But (by the violence of an outragious Å¿torme) himÅ¿elfe with his Queene was driuen into Waymouth in DorÅ¿et Å¿hire: where (at his landing) hee was receiued by Sir Thomas Trenchard a worthie,Sir Thomas Trenchard entertaineth them at his houÅ¿e. and a compleate Knight who inÅ¿tantly importuned the King to accept of the entertainment of his houÅ¿e, vntill King Henrie were certified of his being there, which courteouÅ¿ly he did. Whereof when he had louingly accepted hee was conducted thither, and feaÅ¿ted like (as hee was) a King. The Knight forthwith Å¿ent diuers PoÅ¿ters to King Henrie, who (being much gladded by this newes) becauÅ¿e the Å¿aid King, and he were vnfained and faithfull friends,They are entertained by the King. forthwith Å¿ent for his better direction, and attendance, the Earle of Arundell and Å¿ome others, who inuited him and his Queene, and their Companie to the Kings Court, which was then at his CaÅ¿tle of WindÅ¿or, of which great courteÅ¿ie he accepted with a kind hart: and as he came within fiue miles of the CaÅ¿tle; he was met by the Noble Henrie Prince of Wales, who was accompanied by diuers Earles, Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen of choice reckoning aad account: and within halfe a mile of his iournies end, the King himÅ¿elfe with the greateÅ¿t part of his Nobilitie, Ladies, and PerÅ¿onages of great worth and honour (being richly apparrelled, and brauely mounted) met him likewiÅ¿e, where kind Å¿alutations, and friendly greetings proceeded from the heart; and were performed with moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿ite complements of loue, that by any could be imagined.

From the Kings CaÅ¿tle of WindÅ¿or. the King conducted him and his Queene to the Citie of London: where nothing was omitted, that anie deuiÅ¿e, or coÅ¿t, could make Å¿umptuous: thereby to expreÅ¿Å¿e the heartie welcome of Å¿uch beloued gueÅ¿ts. And thus when (with great contentment, mirth, and paÅ¿time) the King and he had Å¿pent Å¿ome dayes, they renewed the League which was betwixt them, and taking kind farewels, each of other, the Å¿aid
King and Queene, imbarked themÅ¿elues againe, lanched into the Sea, and Å¿afety arriued according to their owne wils. But not long after, King Philip and his wife died, and that Kingdome diÅ¿cended to Charles his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne.

From this time forwards King Henrie waxed Å¿ickly, weake,1506. and infirme, and by meanes thereof, the two Å¿courgers of the Common-weale EmpÅ¿on, and Dudley, tooke larger libertie to extend their villanies, then was giuen to them, and did oppreÅ¿Å¿e, torment, and vex the People of this land.

But when the King perceiued that his time was Å¿hort,1507. hee depriued them of their authoritie: remitted and pardoned all offences, committed againÅ¿t his penall Lawes, and enlarged all priÅ¿oners,The King waxeth Å¿ickly. His deeds of charitie. which were in durance for any offence (treaÅ¿on and murder excepted only) he alÅ¿o paid the debts of all Å¿uch, as for trifling and Å¿mal Å¿ummes, were priÅ¿oners in any Ward, and gaue certaine Å¿ummes of monie vnto Å¿ome poore folkes, who had beene vnconÅ¿cionably deuoured, robbed, and Å¿poiled,He repenteth of his exactions by the penall lawes. by thoÅ¿e two graceleÅ¿Å¿e and vngodly Cormorants. He alÅ¿o was exceeding penitent and Å¿orrowfull for thoÅ¿e wrongs and iniuries which (with too much Å¿eueritie) they had done vnto many:1508. and hee diÅ¿burÅ¿ed by way of loane freely, and without reward, diuers great Å¿ummes of monie to his Merchants.A notable policie. By meanes whereof their gaines and his cuÅ¿tome were mightily encreaÅ¿ed. Finally, when hee had raigned twentie and three yeares and Å¿ome moneths, and when hee had liued fiftie and two yeeres, he died,The King dieth. and was buried with great Å¿olemnitie and honor by Queene Elizabeth his wife, in his owne Chappell at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter: which he had with great coÅ¿t and skill founded, and cauÅ¿ed to be built not long before.

div.head: THE HISTORIE OF KING HENRIE THE EIGHT.
div.p: KIng HENRIE the Eight, 1509. The King marieth his brothers wife. being of the Age of eighteene yeares, began to Raigne the two and twentieth day of Aprill, in the yeare of our Lord God 1509. And being diÅ¿penced with by Pope Iuly the Å¿econd, hee maried the Ladie Katherine, daughter to Ferdinando King of Aragon, Aunt to Prince Charles of CaÅ¿tile, who afterwards was Emperor; when as not long before Å¿hee had beene his brother Prince Arthures wife: by which match, much trouble afterwards enÅ¿ued, as in this diÅ¿courÅ¿e of his gouernement it will appeare.

In his firÅ¿t beginnings he Å¿eemed tenderly to affect his peoples loue, and to execute his Lawes with mercie, and with compaÅ¿Å¿ion.The King is gratious to Å¿uch as w â¢ re oppreÅ¿Å¿ed by Emp â¢ on and Dudley. And whereas oppreÅ¿Å¿ion (in the end of his Fathers dayes) had much vexed and grieued the Subiects of this Land, Hee (by open Proclamations) made it knowne, that he would not only heare the lamentable complaints of Å¿uch as by the Tyrannous Rapine, and greedie CouetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of EmpÅ¿on and Dudley, and of Å¿ome other tormenting Promoters had beene vndone; but would alÅ¿o redreÅ¿Å¿e and recompence their wrongs. By meanes whereof great throngs of People daily reÅ¿orted, flocked, and ruÅ¿hed into the Kings Court: Among whom many complained moÅ¿t who had leaÅ¿t cauÅ¿e, but they receiued Å¿harpe puniÅ¿hment for their impudencie and boldneÅ¿Å¿e; and, to the reÅ¿t, the King gaue liberall reÅ¿titution and amends. And the more frankely and freely to content
Å¿uch as had beene iuÅ¿tly offended by thoÅ¿e extremities, after all legall proceedings finiÅ¿hed, hee cauÅ¿ed the heads of thoÅ¿e two deuouring Caterpillers to be Å¿triken off at the Tower hill:EmpÅ¿on and Dudley put to death. and the reÅ¿t of that raÅ¿call rabble were diÅ¿gracefully corrected by the Å¿tocks and pillories in Å¿undrie places of this Realme.

1511. 3Thus when the King had well buÅ¿ied himÅ¿elfe in the Å¿ettlement of his Kingdome the firÅ¿t two yeares of his raigne, hee was by his wiues father,Ferdinando craueth and obtaineth aid, but did nothing. Ferdinando King of Aragon, entreated to enter into more turbulent actions, by aiding and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting him againÅ¿t the Moores, which willingly he did. But by reaÅ¿on of a ceÅ¿Å¿ation of thoÅ¿e iarres, the EngliÅ¿hmen returned out of Spaine, hauing beene rudely entertained, and Å¿pent all.

The French King warreth on the Pope.About the Å¿ame time the French King Lewys the twelfth (by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome priuate quarrellings betwixt himÅ¿elfe and Pope Iuly the Å¿econd) tranÅ¿ported an Armie into Italie, and by Å¿trength and violence (as a Conquerour) hee poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elfe of the faire and rich Citie of Bologna la GraÅ¿Å¿a, and inÅ¿olently did much harme.

Whereupon King Henry (in fauour to the Pope, becauÅ¿e he diÅ¿penÅ¿ed with his late mariage, and was vnited vnto him by more then by the ordinarie bonds of friendÅ¿hip and of loue, and becauÅ¿e the Pope himÅ¿elfe was vnable to reÅ¿iÅ¿t,King Henry mediateth a peace, but he is neglected. Warres betwixt King Henry and Lewys the twelfth. or to maintaine his owne quarrell) interpoÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe as an indifferent mediator, and as an interceÅ¿Å¿or for amitie and for peace.

But the French King (taÅ¿ting the pleaÅ¿ant and the profitable fruits of his Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull fortune, and longing to extend his gouernment into Å¿o rich a Countrey) turned the deafe eare, and would not hearken to this motion. Whereupon King Henrie (whoÅ¿e bodie was young and luÅ¿tie, and whoÅ¿e high heart was repleniÅ¿hed with true fortitude, magnanimitie, and valour) made it knowen to the ChriÅ¿tian world, that as hee Å¿corned to be neglected in Å¿o good a Å¿uit, Å¿o he loathed to be idle, and a looker on, in a time of Å¿uch negotiation and imploiment, and therefore would attempt by his beÅ¿t meanes to withdraw the French Kings warres from the Popes Countries. Vpon which reÅ¿olution, forthwith, by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors hee required the French King to giue vnto him the full and peaceable poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his two Duchies of Guyen and of Normandie, together with his ancient inheritance of Angeow and of Mayne, which wrongfully was kept and deteined from his AnceÅ¿tors and from him.

The Å¿mall acquaintance which at that time the French King had with King Henry, and the contempt of his youthfull yeeres, made
him to returne a Å¿cornefull deniall to his demand; inÅ¿omuch that King Henrie proclaimed warre againÅ¿t him, and prepared daily to Å¿end a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie into Guyan. Vpon which occaÅ¿ion, and others,Defender of the faith. and in regard that thoÅ¿e broiles were chiefly vndertaken to releeue the Pope, King Henry was by him enÅ¿tiled with this addition to his kingly Title, Defender of the Faith.

This reÅ¿olution being notified to his father in law Ferdinando King of Aragon, (who was craftie, and cunningly intended,Fer â¢ inando promiÅ¿eth aid to King Henry. vnder the colour of much friendÅ¿hip, to vÅ¿urpe, and treacherouÅ¿ly to winne vnto himÅ¿elfe the Kingdome of Nauarre, for which immoderately his ambitious heart did thirÅ¿t) hee made vnto King Henry a large profer of great aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance and helpe, with horÅ¿es, tents, carriages, ordinance, and Å¿undrie other things needfull and expedient for thoÅ¿e warres, if hee would land his Armie within his Countrey of Biskey, and march from thence into Guyan.

The King (who dreamt not of any fraud,The Kings Armie landeth in BiÅ¿key. but was perÅ¿waded of good performance of more then had beene offred) moÅ¿t thankfully accepted of this great courteÅ¿ie, and Å¿ent (for the aforeÅ¿aid purpoÅ¿e) ten thouÅ¿and men into Biskey, vnder the principall command of Thomas Gray MarqueÅ¿Å¿e DorÅ¿et, who was their Generall in that warre.

But Ferdinando (whoÅ¿e owne plot touching the Å¿urpriÅ¿all of Nauarre was not fully perfected,Ferdinando yeel â¢ s no helpe. and who intended nothing leÅ¿Å¿e then according to his promiÅ¿e to aid the EngliÅ¿h Armie) by flattering meÅ¿Å¿ages to the MarqueÅ¿Å¿e maintained his hopes, but yet Å¿uffered both him and his (without imploiment or Å¿uccour) to lie idle, to their great diÅ¿honour and reproch.

In the end he prepared a Å¿trong Armie,The Kingdome of Nauarre taken and conquered by the Spaniards. which was conducted by the Duke D'Alva, and outwardly pretended to vnite them to the EngliÅ¿h forces. But as a Riuer growing outragious by the abundance of much raine, ouerfloweth the low adiacent grounds, Å¿o this Armie with great violence and Å¿trength vnexpectedly ruÅ¿hed into the vnprouided Territories of Nauarre, Å¿urpriÅ¿ed the Citie of Pampalona, and treacherouÅ¿ly (without blowes or reÅ¿iÅ¿tance) Å¿ubdued the greateÅ¿t part of that Kingdome, which (without right or title) the Spaniards doe hold and enioy at this day.

And although that King Ferdinando (by this vniuÅ¿t and deceitfull practiÅ¿e) had eaÅ¿ily attained to the height of his ambitious deÅ¿ires concerning that conqueÅ¿t,Ferdinando a â¢â¢â¢ r â¢ s no helpe or aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance at laÅ¿t. yet did hee continue falÅ¿e and vnkinde to the EngliÅ¿h Armie, whom he aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted not at the laÅ¿t, but Å¿uffred them for the Å¿pace of foure moneths to be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with a thouÅ¿and wants, and to be conÅ¿umed by the flux and other calamities
in the open field: by meanes whereof, the common Å¿ouldiers (being heartleÅ¿Å¿e,The EngliÅ¿hmen returne home without leaue. and hopeleÅ¿Å¿e of better vÅ¿age from the King of Aragon) forÅ¿ooke the field, and (without the licence of their Generall) returned Å¿traglingly into England. And thus was K. Henry groÅ¿ly abuÅ¿ed and wronged by his father in law the Å¿econd time.

WhileÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h Armie was thus vnkindly deluded in BiÅ¿key, the right valiant Knight Sir Edward Howard (Lord Admirall of England, Sir Edward Howard plagueth the Brittons. and a younger Å¿onne to the Earle of Surrey) with a well appointed Fleet of Å¿hips (which were well furniÅ¿hed with braue and luÅ¿tie men) kept and commanded the Narrow Seas, daily tooke the French Merchants, oftentimes landed in Å¿undrie places within the Duchie of Britaine, forraged their Fields, ranÅ¿acked their Villages and their Townes, Å¿et them on fire, and enriched his companies with great Å¿poiles.

The Brittons dare him, but run away.The Brittons (being hourely endammaged, and knowing that no better fortune would attend them, except by true valour and manhood they encountred the EngliÅ¿h aÅ¿Å¿ailants) braggingly dared the Admirall into the Field; of which challenge he ioifully accepted, although that with Å¿ix and twentie hundred (and no more) he was to fight againÅ¿t more then ten thouÅ¿and men. And incontinently with martiall skill and policie hee ordered his battaile in the open field. But when the Brittons approched neere, and with iudicious eies beheld the order and the courage of the EngliÅ¿h Å¿ouldiers, their hearts fainted, their Leaders retired, their common Å¿ouldiers fled, and would not once looke on an EngliÅ¿h face.

The King Å¿endeth him more aid.The King being aduertiÅ¿ed of the valour of his Admirall, and of the haughty courage of his men, & intending to giue them Å¿trength which Å¿hould bee anÅ¿werable to their deÅ¿ires, did Å¿end vnto them Å¿ome of his Å¿hips royall, & many others, which were well ordinanced, and plentifully manned, both for the Sea, & alÅ¿o for the Land.

When the Admirall was thus prouided, and had reduced all his Å¿hips into one Fleet,He fighteth at Sea with the French Fleet. within few daies after he met and fought with the French Nauie; at which time death was deÅ¿piÅ¿ed, in regard that euery man Å¿ought by bloud to purchaÅ¿e honour and renowne: vntill the Regent of England, and in her Sir Iohn Carew of DeuonÅ¿hire, and Sir Thomas Knyuet, with Å¿euen hundred more, and the great Carricke of BreÅ¿t, and in her Sir Pierce Morgan, and nine hundred men of warre, (both thoÅ¿e Å¿hips being faÅ¿t grapped together) were vnfortunately burnt,The Regent and the Carricke are burned. Å¿laine, and drowned in the Sea. The view whereof being vnuÅ¿uall, was Å¿o terrible, that whileÅ¿t men fearfully looked on, the fight ceaÅ¿ed, and the Frenchmen (Å¿cattering themÅ¿elues) returned into the Sea.

The French King (to make his match the better with the EngliÅ¿h Nauie) augmented the number of his Å¿hips and men,The French Fleet entreth into the Hauen of BreÅ¿t. and Å¿ent them thorowly prouided with ordinance, powder, Å¿hot, and other neceÅ¿Å¿aries, into the Hauen of BreÅ¿t. And King Henry (who Å¿corned that his Admirall Å¿hould be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with a greater Å¿trength then he Å¿hould be well able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t) rigged vp the moÅ¿t part of his Royall Fleet, and Å¿ome others,King Henry augmenteth his Fleet. which Å¿afely arriued in Bartram Bay within the Duchie of Britaine. With theÅ¿e, and with all the reÅ¿t, the braue Admirall attempted to aÅ¿Å¿aile the French Bottoms as they lay at ancors within the Hauen of BreÅ¿t. But as he was entring in, the foremoÅ¿t Å¿hip, which Arthur Plantagenet did command, was Å¿plitted in Å¿under vpon a rocke, which made the reÅ¿t doubtfull to proceed, except with better guidance they might Å¿afely enter in.

The French Captaines perceiuing the EngliÅ¿hmens intent,The Frenchmen doe fortifie the Hauen. ancoured as neere to the CaÅ¿tle of BreÅ¿t as they were able, and placed foure and twentie old FlemiÅ¿h Hulkes towards the mouth of the Hauen, betwixt themÅ¿elues and the EngliÅ¿h Fleet, which they appointed to bee Å¿et on fire, and to bee vnmoared when the Å¿hips of England did approch towards them, that by them they might bee endangered. They alÅ¿o raiÅ¿ed and fortified diuers Rampiers and Bulwarkes vpon the entrance of the Hauen, from which their great Ordinance might play vpon their enemies.

The Lord Admirall of England (doubting leÅ¿t the Hauen of BreÅ¿t was too Å¿hallow to Å¿upport his Å¿hips of greateÅ¿t Å¿trength and burden, The Admirall in Boats entreth into the Hauen. and finding that the French cowards meant nothing leÅ¿Å¿e then to expreÅ¿Å¿e their manhood by a reÅ¿olute encounter) reÅ¿olued with oared Barges to be rowed into the Harbrough, and there to doe Å¿ome memorable exploit vpon his enemies Å¿hips. With this determination (which more manfully then aduiÅ¿edly he did put in practiÅ¿e) hee with Å¿uch an haughtie courage and with Å¿uch violence aÅ¿Å¿ailed the three great Gallies of the Rhoads,He taketh the three Gallies of the Rhoads. which were brought thither by a gallant Knight, named Prior Iohn, that hee wonne them quickly, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed them as his owne. But when the Frenchmen perceiued that the EngliÅ¿h Barges were gone out of the Hauen, and were returned to their owne Fleet, they then with great numbers of well armed men ruÅ¿hed into the Å¿aid Gallies, where the braue Admirall with that Å¿mall remnant which were with him, defended themÅ¿elues a long time with great courage. But being ouer-maÅ¿tered, and too much wearied with freÅ¿h Å¿upplies, which euery minute did aÅ¿Å¿aile them,He is drowned. the greater part of his men were Å¿laine, the Admirall with a pike was violently borne
ouer boord, and drowned in the Sea, and the reÅ¿t of them were taken priÅ¿oners by their enemies. And thus were they ouerthrowen, who (if they had beene more prouident, and better counÅ¿elled) might haue triumphed in their victories. And within few daies after, the Lord Thomas Howard, the eldeÅ¿t brother of the Å¿aid deceaÅ¿ed Knight,His brother is made Lord Admirall. was by the King made Admirall, who with all the extremitie of warre became a cruell reuenger of his brothers death.

The King (not minding any longer to trifle or to dallie with the French King) leuied two Armies.Two Armies Å¿ent into France. In the one of them were eight thouÅ¿and men, and in the other Å¿ix thouÅ¿and. The former of them was commanded by George Lord Talbot Earle of ShreweÅ¿burie, and the other by Sir Charles SomerÅ¿et, Lord Harbert, Chamberlaine to the King. TheÅ¿e two Generals with their companies (departing from PortÅ¿mouth) arriued Å¿afely at Calice, from whence they marched to the Å¿trong Citie of Tyrwyn, Tyrwyn is beÅ¿ieged. and beÅ¿ieged it on euery Å¿ide. And within few weekes after, the King himÅ¿elfe (hauing firÅ¿t committed the gouernment of this Kingdome to the generall charge of the Queene his wife, and the particular protection of the Northerne parts vnto the noble and worthie Lord Thomas Howard Earle of Surrey, The King with a third Armie commeth before Tyrwyn. if peraduenture the Scots, according to their cuÅ¿tome, Å¿hould in his abÅ¿ence beyond the Seas, enter into thoÅ¿e Countries) being accompanied with many of his Nobles and Gentrie, and hauing an Armie of eleuen thouÅ¿and luÅ¿tie and gallant men, departed out of England, came to his Towne of Calice, and marched forth in warlike order, vntill hee had ioined himÅ¿elfe with all his other force, which lay Å¿trongly encamped before Tyrwyn.

Now whileÅ¿t King Henry thus lay in this Å¿iege, the inhabitants oftentimes Å¿allied out of their gates, and with great reÅ¿olution skirmiÅ¿hed with their enemies, but were alwaies looÅ¿ers in their Retreats.

The French Armie attempteth to raiÅ¿e the Å¿iege.By the EngliÅ¿hmen likewiÅ¿e daily batteries and hourely aÅ¿Å¿aults were made, and manfully reÅ¿iÅ¿ted by the Citizens, vntill the French King (to raiÅ¿e the Å¿iege) cauÅ¿ed a huge Armie to be leuied, which appeared, and approched neere to the EngliÅ¿h Campe, and made many a boaÅ¿ting and a proud bragge, as if they were determined to doe much: but Å¿till and Å¿till they trifled, not doing any thing which might merit praiÅ¿e. In this meane while,A mariage concluded with Scotland. the aforeÅ¿aid motion concerning the mariage of the young Prince with the Infant Queene of Scotland, was Å¿o well applauded and entertained by the Scots, that in their Parliament it was firÅ¿t concluded, and then confirmed by an InÅ¿trument in writing, vnder the hands and Å¿eales of their Nobilitie, and ratified by their oathes, that the Å¿aid intended match Å¿hould bee effected, and that their young Queene (for that purpoÅ¿e) Å¿hould bee conueied into England. But within few moneths after, by the Å¿ecret and cunning plots and practiÅ¿es of the French King, the Nobilitie of Scotland neglected their Law, their promiÅ¿e, and their oath, which occaÅ¿ioned King Henry with all Å¿peed to make new and vnwonted preparations and prouiÅ¿ions,The Scots doe breake their oath. not onely to inuade that Countrey, but alÅ¿o to make warre vpon his enemie the King of France.

And to effect his purpoÅ¿e in that behalfe, firÅ¿t he Å¿ent a puiÅ¿Å¿ant Armie (which was tranÅ¿ported in two hundred warlike Å¿hips) into Scotland, An Armie Å¿poileth Scotland. vnder the generall command (by Sea) of his high Admirall the ViÅ¿count LiÅ¿le, and vnder the generall command (by land) of the noble and right valiant Earle of Hartford.

All theÅ¿e Å¿hips Å¿afely entred into the Fryth, where they tooke many good VeÅ¿Å¿els, which were exceeding Å¿eruiceable to their proceedings. And then was the whole Armie Å¿et on land: and being well ordered into three battailes, and marching towards Leyth, they firÅ¿t tooke view of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and ScottiÅ¿h horÅ¿emen, with whom they encountred for a while. But when the Scots perceiued that the EngliÅ¿hmen tooke more delight to fight with courage, then to dallie, as being fearefull of their liues, they made a quicke retrait, and Å¿uddenly fled away, leauing their Artillerie and that Towne to their enemies, who appropriated to themÅ¿elues euery good thing which they found there, and then conÅ¿umed the towne with fire. From thence they marched towards Edenborough, the principall Citie of that Kingdome. But on the way the ProuoÅ¿t and Å¿ome of the chiefeÅ¿t BurgeÅ¿Å¿es of that Towne, made offer to
the Earle of Hartford (Generall of the Field) to deliuer to him the keies, conditionally that he would preÅ¿erue it from fire, and Å¿uffer the Å¿ouldiers and the Inhabitants thereof with bagge and baggage to depart.

But the Generall made anÅ¿were thus: That hee was Å¿ent into that Countrey to take reuenge vpon that Nation, becauÅ¿e their Nobilitie (with one conÅ¿ent) by the peruerÅ¿e and vnfriendly inÅ¿tigation of the French King, had violated their owne Law, their promiÅ¿e, and their oath, touching the mariage agreed on, to be Å¿olemnized betweene Prince Edward and their young Queene. And therefore if all the Souldiers and all the Inhabitants of that Citie would come diÅ¿armed into the open Field, and yeeld their Å¿ubÅ¿tance and their liues to bee ordered according to his pleaÅ¿ure and will, he then would doe as he thought good: but if they refuÅ¿ed Å¿o to doe, he then proteÅ¿ted to viÅ¿it the Towne and them with all the extremities which were incident to Å¿uch a warre.

This quicke anÅ¿were Å¿o little pleaÅ¿ed the TowneÅ¿men, that they returned, purpoÅ¿ing to reÅ¿iÅ¿t: and Å¿o they did. But by Å¿trong batteries and fierce aÅ¿Å¿aults, their gates and their walles were beaten downe and entred, Å¿o that many thouÅ¿ands of the Scots were Å¿laine, their riches were poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by the EngliÅ¿h Armie, and a great part of that Citie was conÅ¿umed by fire. Now whileÅ¿t the Armie was thus buÅ¿ied, there came vnto them from the King foure thouÅ¿and EngliÅ¿h horÅ¿emen: Å¿o that when the Å¿poiles and booties were by the Å¿ouldiers imbarked, and by water Å¿ent into England, the EngliÅ¿h Armie coaÅ¿ted thorow a great part of thoÅ¿e Countries, vnfought with, burning, killing, and foraging in all places, as they pleaÅ¿ed: Å¿o that they hauing taken, ranÅ¿acked, and burnt a good part of the Citie of Edenborough, Holy-rood houÅ¿e, and the Kings Palace there, and hauing rifled and defaced the Townes of Leyth, Haddington, Dumbarre, Dyrlaw, Broughton, DudiÅ¿ton, Beuerton, Markle, Hatherwike, Bowland, Blackborne, WeÅ¿t-Crage, CheÅ¿ter-fels, Stone-houÅ¿e, Trauent, Trapren, Belton, Butterden, Raunto, Enderleigh, Crawenden, ShenÅ¿ton, the Fycket, EaÅ¿t-barne, Kyrklandhill, Quickwood, part of Muskelborough, and many other Villages, beÅ¿ides Abbies, MonaÅ¿teries, and Religious HouÅ¿es, (which particularly wee cannot name) they returned powerfully, with rich booties, and with the only loÅ¿Å¿e of fortie men, into England.

Two Armies Å¿ent into France.And thus did King Henry in Å¿ome Å¿harpe meaÅ¿ure correct and puniÅ¿h the vnÅ¿table dealings of the Scots. Which troubles when he had finiÅ¿hed, hee then forthwith made Å¿uch plentifull preparations to inuade France, that he Å¿ent vnto the French Kings Dominions
two Å¿trong Armies, of which the one was commanded by the Duke of Norfolke, and by the gentle Lord RuÅ¿Å¿el, who was then newly made Lord Priuie Seale, who therewithall beÅ¿ieged the Å¿trong Towne of Muttrell, where they loÅ¿t much time,Muttrell beÅ¿ieged and abandoned. and much labour, and were enforced to leaue it in the end. And the other of the Å¿aid two Armies was commanded by the Duke of Suffolke, with which the Å¿aid former Armie inbodied it Å¿elfe: and then they all encamped about the Å¿trong and warlike Citie of Bulleine, Bulleine is beÅ¿ieged. and after many Å¿harpe conflicts and hot skirmiÅ¿hes, they firÅ¿t tooke the Old man, and Å¿hortly after baÅ¿e Bulleine.

To this Å¿iege King Henry himÅ¿elfe (being attended by many a worthie man) repaired, and after his comming thither,The King commeth to Bulleine. Å¿o long as the light gaue leaue, for the Å¿pace of one whole moneth together, he cauÅ¿ed the walles of the Towne and CaÅ¿tle Å¿o cruelly to be battered, and the Towne it Å¿elfe to be Å¿o beaten, and the breaches and the trenches to be Å¿o furiouÅ¿ly aÅ¿Å¿ulted, that the walles in many places lay almoÅ¿t leuell with the ground. No houÅ¿e eÅ¿caped vnhurted: and the Inhabitants with continuall labour, vexation,Bulleine is yeelded. and trauell, were almoÅ¿t tired and worne out: Å¿o that at length, vpon compoÅ¿ition that all the Souldiers and Inhabitants Å¿hould Å¿afely depart with bagge and baggage, the Å¿trong and Å¿tately Towne and CaÅ¿tle of Bulleine was deliuered into the Kings hands: out of which iÅ¿Å¿ued (vpon the Å¿aid agreement) threeÅ¿core and Å¿euen horÅ¿emen, fifteene hundred, threeÅ¿core and three footmen, eight hundred Gunners, foureÅ¿core and Å¿euen men who were hurt, and nineteene hundred twentie and Å¿euen men, women, and children, they all being in number 4444. Å¿oules. But many (who by reaÅ¿on of their greeuous wounds could not depart) were found, and well cheriÅ¿hed and releeued in the Towne.

Now whileÅ¿t the King thus lay at the Å¿iege of Bulleine, King Henry returneth. the Emperour (without the Kings knowledge or conÅ¿ent) Å¿ecretly concluded a peace with the French King; whereat King Henry much greeued: Å¿o that (after hee had taken an exact order for the repairing and fortifying of that Towne and CaÅ¿tle) bee diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed his Armie, and with great ioy, honour, and triumph, he returned into England.

And becauÅ¿e his daily warres (which required continuall Å¿upplies) had waÅ¿ted and conÅ¿umed his treaÅ¿ure,Iohn Stow. 993. which (for the preuenting of future miÅ¿chiefes, and in eÅ¿peciall Å¿uch as were daily offred vnto him by the Scots) he endeuoured to augment, hee therefore demanded a Beneuolence of all his Subiects both Spirituall and Temporall. For which purpoÅ¿e Sir Thomas WryotheÅ¿ley, A Beneuolence. Lord
Chancellor of England, the Duke of Suffolke, and others of his MaieÅ¿ties CounÅ¿ell of EÅ¿tate, (Å¿itting as CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners in Bainards CaÅ¿tle in London) taxed the Citizens and Inhabitants according to their wiÅ¿domes and diÅ¿cretions. And becauÅ¿e one Alderman (whoÅ¿e name was Richard Read) refuÅ¿ed to pay what they had ordered,Alderman Read. he was therefore by them required (on a great paine) perÅ¿onally to Å¿erue the King in his warres againÅ¿t the Scots; which cheerefully be performed, and was (with many others) taken priÅ¿oner and detained by his enemies, vntill that for his ranÅ¿ome hee was enlarged and Å¿et free.

The Dolphins Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e.After the King was departed home, the Dolphin (taking the benefit to a darke night) came with a great power Å¿o Å¿uddenly into BaÅ¿e Bulleine, that he tooke it. But Å¿uch as fled, and had Å¿aued their liues, being aided by the Å¿ouldiers of the vpper Towne and CaÅ¿tle, came fiercely on the Dolphin, and Å¿o manfully aÅ¿Å¿ailed him, that (to Å¿aue himÅ¿elfe and his) he in all the haÅ¿te departed, and left the Towne with his great loÅ¿Å¿e.

The French are ouerthrowen.Within few daies after, MonÅ¿ieur de Bees came on the other Å¿ide of the water before the Towne, with an Armie of fifteene thouÅ¿and men, and began to erect a FortreÅ¿Å¿e there. But by the valiant Earle of Hartford, the ViÅ¿count LiÅ¿le, the Lord Gray, and diuers others, they were aÅ¿Å¿ailed, fought with, and Å¿hamefully put to flight, and were compelled to leaue behinde them their Ordinance, Tents, and other good prouiÅ¿ions, to their great ignominie and reproch.

The French King (intending to worke wonders in England, by way of a reuenge, for that his Å¿trong Towne of Bulleine was loÅ¿t) Å¿ent to the Sea a mightie Fleet,The French Kings Nauie doth nothing. of two hundred tall Å¿hips, and Å¿euen and twentie Å¿trong Gallies, all which were Å¿tuffed (as it was reported) with threeÅ¿core thouÅ¿and men. All theÅ¿e came in good order, and ancoured before the IÅ¿le of Wight, and were oftentimes beaten with the great Ordinance which the Admirall of England liberally beÅ¿towed on them. But as the EngliÅ¿h Fleet paÅ¿Å¿ed out of the Hauen of PortÅ¿mouth into the Sea, a Å¿tately, Å¿trong, and a goodly Å¿hip, named the Marie RoÅ¿e, The Marie RoÅ¿e drowned belonging to the King, (in which was Captaine Sir George Carew Knight, with more then foure hundred men beÅ¿ides) was drowned almoÅ¿t in an inÅ¿tant, by the groÅ¿Å¿e follie of the Gunners, and of the Mariners, the former of them hauing left their Ordinance vntrigged, and the latter hauing left the vnder port holes open, by meanes whereof when the Å¿hip turned, the Ordinance ran backe to the one Å¿ide, and bare the port holes vnder water, Å¿o that the Å¿ea violently and abundantly flowed in, and in a
moment Å¿wallowed vp both Å¿hip, Captaine, Men, Ordinance, and all other things there to the great griefe and Å¿orrow of the King himÅ¿elfe, and of all Å¿uch as were preÅ¿ent, and beheld it.

The Lord Dambalt, high Admirall of France, being by certaine poore FiÅ¿hermen, whom he had taken, informed, that the King in his owne perÅ¿on, being accompanied with an infinite number of valiant men of warre; expected and longed to be made victorious and rich by their landing, feared to hazard all his fortunes in Å¿o deÅ¿perate and hot a Å¿eruice: Wherefore be hoiÅ¿ed Ancors, and without Fame or Honor, returned baÅ¿ely into France.

Now muÅ¿t wee know,The Scots invade England. that no Å¿ooner was King Henrie departed out of England to the Å¿iege of Bullein (as wee haue heard) but the ScottiÅ¿h Nation (obÅ¿eruing their old cuÅ¿tome) entred, riffled, Å¿poiled, and burnt many HouÅ¿es, Villages, and Å¿mall Townes, in the marches of England, without pitty: Wherefore, King Henrie (after his returne) reÅ¿olued to correct their madneÅ¿Å¿e, and their folly, and to take reuenge for thoÅ¿e iniuries and wrongs: And for that purpoÅ¿e, he Å¿ent the Noble Earle of Hartford into that Kingdome,An Armie Å¿ent into Scotland. with an Armie of twelue thouÅ¿and men, where hee hauoked Men, Townes, CaÅ¿tles, and the Countrie, in Å¿uch a furious and fierce manner, that the Scots were extremely damnified thereby; and thouÅ¿ands of them were vtterly vndone.

About the Å¿ame time, the valiant Lord LiÅ¿le, Lord high Admirall of England, Treport. entred into and landed within the Hauen of Treport, and burnt the Å¿uburbs of that towne, and many other houÅ¿es, Villages, and Townes, which bordered vpon the Sea coaÅ¿ts: And at his returne from thence (as a rich prey) he caried with him many Ships, Barges, Boats, and VeÅ¿Å¿els, which he found there.

Now (like as after many ruffe and boiÅ¿terous Å¿tormes, a Å¿weet, and a delectable calme doth follow: Å¿o after theÅ¿e buÅ¿ie conflicts, and martiall contentions,The Duke of Northfolke and the Earle of Surrey committed. whereof wee haue already taken a perfect view: A peace was louingly concluded, and ioyfully proclaymed, betweene the two kingdomes of England and of France. But this joy (as in humane affaires it often hapneth) was quickly checked with an other Å¿orrow: for the moÅ¿t victorious, faithfull, and euer to be honored Captaine, the Duke of Northfolke, and his Å¿onne, the moÅ¿t illuÅ¿trious Earle of Surrey (both which, in this Kings raigne, performed many memorable, and braue Å¿eruices, in Scotland, England, and in France) were Å¿odainely apprehended, and Å¿ent vnto the Tower; For none other thing, but becauÅ¿e they quartered, and bare in their EÅ¿coucheon certaine Armes, which were pretended, properly, and only to belong vnto the King and
Prince (which Armes notwithÅ¿tanding, they and their AunceÅ¿ters timeout of minde had Å¿o borne without controlment, reproofe, or check. For this offence, the Å¿aid Earle was indicted of high TreaÅ¿on, arraigned thereon, and tryed by a Iurie of Knights, and Gentlemen,The Earle of Surrey beheaded. (and not by his peeres) becauÅ¿e he was no Lord of the Parliament) by whom he was found guiltie, and then receiued his iudgement, and loÅ¿t his head, to the great griefe and Å¿orrow of many thouÅ¿ands, who lamented the cauÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e death of Å¿uch a worthy man, as had Å¿o well deÅ¿erued of the King, and of the common weale.

He is deÅ¿cribed.The PreÅ¿ence of this King was amiable, and Princely: for hee was Å¿omewhat more then ordinarie tall, Å¿trongly limmed, proportionably compoÅ¿ed, faire in his complexion, nimble, and full of agilitie in his yonger yeares; and alwaies as reÅ¿olutely valiant as a man might bee: Hee had a pregnant and a Å¿harpe wit, and was generally held to bee well learned, becauÅ¿e hee could, and vÅ¿ed to Å¿peake well: He was exceeding humble, and paÅ¿Å¿ing Å¿tout; applying the former to gentle Å¿pirits; and oppoÅ¿ing the latter againÅ¿t prowd, inÅ¿olent, and rough Mates: He was bountifull, and magnificently liberall (if occaÅ¿ion Å¿o required) Yet in regard that hee was a man: He was not free from all faults; For he was too too much familiar and converÅ¿ant with wanton and light women: And delighted too much in varietie, and in change, as moÅ¿t men did coniecture, becauÅ¿e he had Å¿ixe wiues. From two of them he was Å¿euered, becauÅ¿e his mariages were held to be void, fruÅ¿trate, and of no force: other two of them (for the obiected crime of incontinencie) loÅ¿t their heads: A fifth died in her child-bed: and the Å¿ixt eÅ¿caped fairely by his death.
